talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 43 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That Oksana Meshko, 77-year-old acting chairman of the Kiev based Ukranian Helsinki Group, has been sentenced to six months prison and five years exile by a Soviet court in Kiev, Ukraine, for daring to expose Soviet hypocrisy in the matter of human freedom.
According to the US Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Mrs Meshko suffers from a heart condition, making this harsh sentence of a 77-year- old woman tantamount to a death sentence.
Mrs Meshko and her son Mr Serhiyenko have been attempting to emigrate to Australia to join family members who live here.

On the occasion of World Freedom Day your Petitioners most humbly pray that in the interests of humanity the Honourable Senators in Parliament assembled initiate appropriate action to ensure that the Soviet Union lives up to its commitments under the Helsinki Agreement and allows Mrs Meshko to live out the last years of her life in peace with her Australian relatives, rather than endure the grave hardships of Siberian exile.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 46 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Family Law Act
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia;
concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage
(3) protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the almost bipartisan approach in this Parliament which was adopted in relation to the persecution of Solidarity trade union leaders by the Government of Poland which assumed control of events in Poland on 13 December last. I ask the Minister: Has the present Government, having made protests to the Government of Poland, made any protests in relation to 52 trade unionists who are at present on trial for their lives in Turkey? Is the Minister aware that Turkey, a member of the Western Alliance, is also under martial law? Has the Australian Government taken any steps to protest against this treatment of trade unionists in that country? If so, on what dates and by what means have these protests been registered?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I have some information on this matter but I am not sure whether it is precisely in the form sought by Senator Button's question . My information relates to the report of Amnesty International and to the prohibition of certain trade unions and to detention, trial and, in some instances, torture. I am not able to confirm reports that 60 political prisoners have died while under detention, or the numbers of those injured. I understand the Turkish Government has stated that between 20,000 and 30,000 persons remain under detention. The Foreign Minister is aware of decisions by both the Council of Europe and the European Parliament criticising the situation in Turkey. The resolution of the European Parliament requested the suspension of the European Communities' financial aid to Turkey and requested the Foreign Ministers of the EC member countries to take action in regard to 52 DISK trade union leaders now on trial.

answer.para: The Government, in considering its response to events in Turkey since the military takeover of 12 September 1980, has been particularly aware of the extreme difficulties which confronted Turkey prior to the intervention of the military authorities. Terrorist violence was claiming approximately 20 lives a day and the economy was in a state of near-total collapse. The Australian Government has been very concerned about this and the only really satisfactory solution to the problem of the derogation of personal freedom, of detention without charge and of the allegations of the use of torture is the abolition of martial law and the restoration of civilian rule. In this regard, I note that a constituent assembly has been convened to draft a new Turkish constitution and that the Government expects that elections will be held in 1983. I am not aware of what representations have been made directly by Australia. I will seek that information and see whether there is any information that I am able to add before the end of Question Time to the comments I have made.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. Is it correct that at the moment there are no representations?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I have no information as to what has been done . I will seek that information and see whether I can make an early response.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the impending electricity blackouts and four day working week in New South Wales. Is it a fact that routine maintenance work on electricity generating equipment in New South Wales has been neglected this year during the summer months, when such maintenance is normally done? If a four day working week is necessary now what will the situation be like in the winter? Will it not be an intolerable winter, as it was described by the New South Wales Minister for Energy? In view of the enormous damage done not only to New South Wales but also to the whole Australian economy by these restrictions is there any assistance that can be given to solve these New South Wales problems? In particular, can more power be given from the Snowy River scheme without damaging other users or its output? Is Victoria, with its relatively much more efficient power generation system, doing all it can do to help New South Wales?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —My recollection is that some months ago the New South Wales Government made a public statement that it was proposing to forgo a certain amount of the normal routine summer maintenance of its power plants because it did not want to use excess water from the Snowy Mountains scheme. In fact what happened, assuming that that practice was put into effect, is that at a time when the New South Wales Government would normally be doing its maintenance to take the full weight of the winter, that maintenance was not done . If that is so that must inevitably threaten quite serious danger for the future.

answer.para: The Premier has spoken, as has the Minister for Energy in New South Wales, in the most extreme terms of the perils that face New South Wales, perils which mean that at the moment the New South Wales electricity plants are working at far below their installed capacity-perhaps half or less of their installed capacity-and are perilously dependent not only on electricity conservation by the people but also on drawing upon the Snowy Mountains scheme. It is, I think, a tragic indictment of any government that it, having gone to the electors on a basis that if it were voted for it could provide full employment and growing and massive new industries, cannot within weeks of being elected support its existing industries. It is true that Victoria was providing New South Wales with some 5 per cent of its total consumption during January and February. Victoria has done a great deal. It is presently recommissioning some of its own power plant and, therefore, should not be called upon to do too much.

My understanding is that the Snowy Mountains scheme generated around 20 gigawatt hours on Monday and 30 gigawatt hours on Tuesday and is expected to generate about 35 gigawatt hours today. Almost all of this was drawn for New South Wales. This represents a very large proportion of the total New South Wales demand- of the order of 100 gigawatt hours daily. I am told that at this rate of draw, the Snowy Mountains scheme cannot continue past tomorrow because short term storages will have been drawn down. Today Snowy Mountains Hydro- Electric Authority engineers are meeting and reviewing the situation. They will be looking to see what the scope is for generating electricity in the near future and will be able to draw conclusions as to whether further significant assistance can be given to New South Wales. But I am not hopeful; the situation is most grave.

I must add that the Commonwealth is asking the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority to do all within its power within its terms of operation to assist New South Wales in this situation. The situation is most grave. It will badly affect not only the New South Wales economy, in particular the wages of New South Wales workers and the productivity of industry, but also the national economy. Therefore, the situation threatens the whole of the well-being of the Australian people.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relates to Press reports which allege that Mr Javad Yarjani, the then Iranian Charge d'Affaires, was summoned by the Department of Foreign Affairs of 14 January to clarify reports that eight members of the National Baha'i Council had been executed in Iran without trial. In view of the persistent reports reaching Australia of persecution and ill- treatment of Baha'is in Iran, I ask: Firstly, what did the Minister's discussions with Mr Yarjani reveal about the reported executions? Secondly, is it correct, as alleged in the Minister's Press release of 13 January that ' justifications published in the Press in Iran had clearly shown that persecution was in fact occurring and that its motivation was religious intolerance rather than fear of subversive activities'? Thirdly, what report has the Minister since received from the Iranian Charge d'Affaires about the reported executions? Fourthly, what further action will be taken by the Australian Government to seek a clear commitment from the Iranian Government of its policy concerning the protection of basic human rights?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — As reported in the Press, the then Charge d' Affaires of Iran was called into the Department of Foreign Affairs to clarify to officials reports of the tragic executions of Baha'is in Iran in December and January. The question from Senator Missen raised a number of specific issues. In response to those I advise that the discussions provided no information about the executions. The Charge d'Affaires simply stated that Baha'is had been executed for criminal activities, not for their religious beliefs. It is correct to say that justifications published in the Press in Iran had clearly shown that persecution was in fact occurring and that its motivation was religious intolerance rather than fear of subversive activities. I understand that no report has since been received from the Iranian Charge about the reported executions.

answer.para: On 31 January Australia joined members of the European Community and four other countries in collective representations to the Iranian authorities. At the recently concluded 38th session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights the Australian delegation played an active role as a co-sponsor in having a resolution adopted on 11 March concerning human rights in Iran and referring specifically to the persecution of the Iranian Baha'is and to summary and arbitrary executions. Australia has also supported a resolution on the wider subject of summary and arbitrary executions. The Government will continue to work for an end to the cruel disregard for human rights in Iran, both through direct representations to the Iranian Government and through active support for effective measures in international forums.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and is supplementary to one that I asked her yesterday to which I got no answer. I refer to the headline in this morning's Age which states that this week the Fraser Government intends to allow an increase of one per cent in home loan interest rates. I ask the Minister: Will this add $300 per year to the annual repayment burden of individual home buyers and a total of $238m to the interest bill of all Australian home buyers? Is she also aware that the value of Mr Fraser's much leaked home interest relief package has been valued at $225m, as opposed to $238m which will be the additional cost to home buyers? If so, is there any value at all in the Government's package? Does the Minister agree that to give with one hand what one takes with the other is little more than a cheap confidence trick? If this report is correct did she, being a Cabinet member, know of this package yesterday? Why did she refuse to answer the question that I put to her on this very matter yesterday?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

answer.para: As far as this whole matter of housing assistance is concerned, the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and perhaps the Minister for Housing and Construction have made statements recently that assistance from the Commonwealth Government for those purchasing houses is under active consideration. I have nothing that I want to foreshadow other than that it is expected that a statement will be made tomorrow. Whatever figures honourable senators may wish to draw, examine or have explained they will be able to do so at that time.

talk.start.para: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of that answer I ask the Minister: Why is it that stories similar to that in the Age, coming directly from Cabinet or Cabinet Ministers, are leaked daily to the Press and information is not given to the Parliament when a specific question is asked by a senator of the Minister for Finance, who is a member of the Cabinet?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — Senator Chipp would well know, as a former Minister, that it is not usual for policy statements to be made in advance of an announcement from the appropriate Minister if Cabinet has a matter under consideration. The honourable senator's contention that the stories that have been appearing in the Press come directly from Cabinet is something that I am not able to assert. I would think, in common with many people who work in the political arena, that if we knew exactly the source from which stories come we may be able to stop that source.

answer.para: With regard to a matter of major policy, as we regard it, by means of which we are attempting to give assistance in the purchase of homes, for me to come out, piecemeal, with a package, in answer to questions, as a Minister representing another Minister, would not be to the enlightenment of all. I expect that when the statement is made tomorrow, or at such time as the Government is able to make its complete statement, questions will be able to be dealt with and whatever figures need to be examined will be able to be examined in that context . I hope that when the package is brought forward from the Government we will have the support of Senator Chipp and his colleagues in whatever we are able to do to assist people in the purchase of their homes because it is a very firm commitment of this Government that assistance be given.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to an article in the Canberra Times earlier this week in which Professor Max Brennan of the University of Sydney claimed that Australia faces a dark age in development unless funding for research projects is increased? Is it true, as claimed by Professor Brennan, that 'in the decade of the seventies, support for research diminished to a point where we are now ineffectual in many areas and only marginally viable in others'? Have Commonwealth funds for research been affected in any way by the current restrictions on government expenditure?

—The Minister's attention has been drawn to the article referred to by Senator Jessop. I have some factual information as to the amounts that have been provided for research. The conclusions that Professor Brennan draws from them may be his own personal opinions. I do not wish to get into a debate with him about them. The fact is that funding for the Australian Research Grants Scheme for the last four years has been set to maintain a constant level of activity. In 1982 a sum of $17.98m has been allocated. While funds for basic research under the ARGS have remained constant over recent years, the Government is now also providing funds for research through mission-oriented schemes, such as marine sciences and tech- nological grants, which in 1981-82 amounted to $1. 89m--
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I wonder whether the Minister would like to incorporate that answer in Hansard rather than read it out?
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Bolkus will find that this will not be a lengthy answer. The National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Grant Scheme in 1981 -82 received $19.1m. In addition, the Government has just announced an award for centres of excellence of research grants totalling $16m. The size of the average grant under the ARGS increased by 7.9 per cent in 1982 in response to the Minister's request that the scheme give greater emphasis to excellence. Funds for research have not been cut with the exception of project and commencement grants which operate under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act. Discussions on these reductions are currently being undertaken in an effort to have funding restored. Those are the facts relating to the Australian Research Grants Scheme in recent years and particularly in the current year. I think it will be seen from that that there is a general maintenance of activity. Indeed, with the centres of excellence research there is a new program of a very substantial kind.

question.block.title: ANZAC DAY IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: ARRESTS

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. It relates to the prosecutions arising out of charges against some 64 persons who were arrested on Anzac Day 1981 in the Australian Capital Territory. On 15 October last year the Attorney-General was able to inform the Senate that only four persons had been dealt with by the Canberra courts and that he expected that other cases would be dealt with between that date and May of this year. How many prosecutions have been dealt with, and with what results, in the Court of Petty Sessions? How many prosecutions remain to be dealt with by the Court, and is there any realistic expectation that all prosecutions and any appeals will be concluded by the time of the gazettal of a new ordinance promised to govern Anzac Day and other public assemblies?

—Senator Tate said that he asked me a question on 15 October last and that I gave some statistics. It does not appear that there has been any great development since then. The position then was that there had been two convictions but that both had resulted in appeals. One appeal is part heard and is due to resume early in May, and all the remaining prosecutions have been deferred pending the outcome of that appeal.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. The Minister will be aware of the huge problems at present in the world tin market, which has become destabilised because of the clandestine operation of a group of tin producers who have bought up much of the market supply of available tin. Apparently the activities of this unnamed group have forced those short of supply to pay up to the record price of #Stg9,000, which subsequently, between 16 February and 10 March this year, when the situation was uncovered, crashed to #Stg7,000. Has the Government identified the group causing this chaotic situation? What can Australia do to restabilise the tin market? What consequences for Australian tin producers in general and, of course, Tasmanian producers in particular does the Government see flowing from the present destabilised period?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I have a brief relating to tin. Since July of last year there have been numerous Press reports of support for tin prices by what is described as an influential buyer. There is no doubt that huge tonnages of tin believed to be in excess of some 30,000 tonnes were purchased on metal markets between July 1981 and late February 1982. Although there has been conjecture in the Press as to who might be involved, there is no conclusive evidence, nor has there been an authoritative statement at any time as to who has been behind the support buying.

answer.para: During the period in which the influential buyer was operating the London Metal Exchange price increased by about 30 per cent to the level mentioned by Senator Archer, which was some 6 per cent higher than the 1980 peak. That increase took place despite record stocks on the London Metal Exchange, the biggest statistical surplus for over 20 years and a sharp increase in United States stockpile releases since 14 December last year. However, since late February the unidentified buyer has withdrawn from the market and the LME price has declined sharply to the July 1981 price level, which was about #Stg7,000 a tonne.

Of most interest to Australian miners is what has happened to the peak Penang price, which is the pricing basis for the sale of Australia's mine output. The Penang price has also fallen significantly in recent weeks to a point close to the floor price of the buffer stock price range of the International Tin Council . At this level the Buffer Stock Manager is required by Tin Council rules to support the market by the purchase of tin. In this regard, at a special Tin Council session held on 9 March it was decided that all outstanding buffer stock contributions, equivalent to about $185m, would be called up immediately. Australia will be making its proportionate contribution to the call for funds to finance the necessary operations of the Buffer Stock Manager. I understand the significance of the matter to Senator Archer and Tasmania. If there is further information I will be happy to supply it to him.

talk.start.para: —Will the Minister repre- senting the Minister for Industrial Relations concede that, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in the March quarter 1981 fewer disputes occurred than in the same quarter 1980 and that 63.3 per cent of those disputes in March 1981 were caused by managerial policy or physical working conditions? What steps are being taken by the Minister to alleviate the problems caused by poor management, poor physical working conditions and lack of industrial safety?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I do not have before me the figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics which were referred to by the honourable senator but I have no doubt that she is quoting from those figures correctly. I will refer the substance of her question to the Honourable Ian Viner, who is the Minister concerned, but I suspect that probably those particular matters are not uppermost in his mind at the moment, as indeed they are unlikely to be uppermost in the minds of other people who are concerned with government responsibility, such as the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran. Having been accused of a bit of union bashing last night by my opposite number in this place, Senator Grimes, I was very taken by the Premier's comments reported in this morning's newspaper as follows:

answer.para: 'Some sections of the power workers have declared war on their workmates in NSW ,' . . .
'It would seem they have declared war on the community itself.'
'The community should not bow to this blackmail and I want to assure the community that the Government will not bow to blackmail.'

I wonder whether that might be described by the Opposition also as union bashing . I am sure that there are serious matters to be addressed in the field of industrial relations in terms of fair dealing between employers and employees. I believe that they are matters which are properly addressed by anyone who has a concern with industrial relations. I suspect that at the moment that is not the premier problem which faces the Australian community. Indeed, we have a very real problem with respect to unions which seem to be trying to take a quite unreasonable stance across a range of issues and which can be described by a Labor Premier as indulging in blackmail, a different union being described by him as desecrating their profession. I draw the attention of the Senate to these matters because, quite frankly, I think there could be a lot of use in an approach to this matter which acknowledged the very real difficulties which all governments and all employers face in dealing with trade unions which do not accept that they too have responsibilities to the community.

talk.start.para: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, concerns the spread of tropical diseases within the banana industry. The lady finger species of banana has always been subject to a disease known as panama disease which is widespread among some banana growing areas. However, in recent times there has been evidence of a previously immune cavendish species of banana now becoming susceptible to the disease. Can the Minister please advise the extent of the damage to cavendish bananas in South Africa and Taiwan, two countries which are infested with the disease? Are they having any success in controlling the spread of the disease? If so, can certain measures be taken to ensure that panama disease does not become a threat to the cavendish banana industry in Australia?
—'I just happen to have before me'-come on-'I just happen to have before me'--

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —It will disappoint the Senate to know that I do not have detailed information on the effect of the disease on cavendish bananas in those countries . I have been somewhat concerned about my exposure on this subject when, of course, the banana industry is very important not only in the State of Queensland but also in my State of Western Australia where we produce a particularly fine brand of bananas at Carnarvon. I suppose that Senator Bjelke- Petersen will suggest that the bananas she represents are better bent and in other ways better than the bananas in my State.

answer.para: I need disappoint the Senate no longer as I am able to confirm that panama disease is prevalent in both Taiwan and South Africa and it is a major concern in both of those countries. As I said before, I do not have any detail and would have to seek that for the honourable senator. As to their success in controlling the disease, again I have no detailed information, but I have been informed that there has been an outbreak of panama disease in the Wamuran Basin area in southern Queensland which is affecting cavendish bananas. The honourable senator correctly pointed out that that species of banana has not been affected by that disease before. In the first instance, of course, dealing with problems such as this rests with the State department concerned. I do not think the honourable senator is suggesting that the State department is not able to deal with this problem which is within its responsibility. Should there be an interstate problem, however, mechanisms have been established to enable Commonwealth and interstate co-operation. I am sure that if the Queensland Department of Primary Industries feels that there is a problem which should involve either the Commonwealth or other States those mechanisms will be called in to play. I will seek some more technical and more precise information on the matters raised by the honourable senator. I am sure that she will be able to get an early assurance that the State department involved is indeed tackling this problem in an enthusiastic way.

question.block.title: COMMONWEALTH REBATE FOR APPRENTICE FULL-TIME TRAINING SCHEME

talk.start.para: —I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, by reminding the Minister of the Government's undertaking to employers that for every new apprentice employed between 1 December 1979 and 30 June 1980 additional to the number employed for the same period in the previous year the employer would receive $1,000 tax free. I ask: In view of the fact that the Australian Taxation Office in some instances is now taxing employers on the $1,000 received for each apprentice engaged under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme, will she take immediate steps to ensure that the Government honours the undertaking given to those employers who engaged apprentices in the belief that the amount paid for each apprentice would be tax free?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I am aware that there have been some representations on this matter. I understand that it may have some relationship to exempt income, tax losses and things of that sort. I understand that Senator McLaren has made some representations on the matter. I will refer the matter to the Treasurer to see whether there is some interaction between tax losses, exempt income and things of that sort and whether there is any necessity to look again at this to uphold the undertaking if there is any departure from it. I will see whether I can get some early response from him on the issue and clarify the matter as far as possible.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health inform the Senate whether the tests carried out on cattle held in quarantine at Cocos Island as part of the first shipment last month were absolutely conclusive? Is the Minister aware that the only animals in Australia which could have been affected by the disease allegedly carried by these cattle were six white-tailed deer, the cattle themselves being passive vectors for the disease? Was it really the best solution to destroy tens of thousands of dollars worth of some of the best breeding stock in the world for the sake of a few ornamental non- native deer?

—Senator MacGibbon's question emphasises once again the need for and the value of the kind of facility which has been established at Cocos Island. The question which he asked requires a completely detailed answer because it involves quite minute matters as to whether tests were absolutely conclusive and as to the basis on which certain decisions were made. I will seek that information for the honourable senator.

—My question is for the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Government noted newspaper reports that, with Professor Leonie Kramer in the chair, the Australian Broadcasting Commission plans to axe the Australian Women's Broadcasting Co-operative, the justification being that the ABC should not cater for sectional interests? Can we anticipate that under this new approach to programming we will soon hear the last of the Country Hour, the Stock Exchange Report and the Kindergarten of the Air?

—I think it would be unwise to accept the newspaper reports as conclusive. The latter parts of the honourable senator's question are really predicated upon the accuracy of the statements attributed to Professor Kramer. I will seek to have those checked out.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether he has seen the article in a recent issue of Time magazine relating to the dangers of consuming too much sodium, usually by way of salt. Of course, salt is included in a great number of processed foods that are available on supermarket shelves. In view of the recognised danger of a high salt intake, will the Minister ask the National Health and Medical Research Council to publicise the dangers of a high sodium intake and to suggest to the States that the percentage of salt and/or sodium in a food be printed on the label of the food so that people can have some idea of just how much salt is contained in certain foods and can therefore avoid particular foods if they wish?

—I am aware of the article which appeared in Time magazine and of the rather lurid cover which dealt with the subject of salt and which drew attention to some of its dangers. It has been well known for many years that sodium intake can be harmful to health. In fact, one of the quite helpful things that doctors are able to do is to convince people to eat less salt. Doctors have told me that a lower intake of salt is helpful in dealing with diseases such as high blood pressure and many others. Senator Townley is correct in stating that the facts need to be made well known since a certain amount of salt intake can be controlled easily by people. It is one simple measure to take to keep themselves healthy and well. The honourable senator asked whether the labelling of food was an appropriate way of dealing with the problem. This matter can best be referred to the NHMRC as Senator Townley suggested. It may have a number of comments to offer on the matter he raised.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I preface my question by stating a fact with which the Minister should be well acquainted. For people living in remote towns, such as Mount Newman in Western Australia, it is far easier to establish quickly eligibility for unemployment benefit and then receive that benefit than it is to establish eligibility for special benefit. How many wives of workers who were stood down in remote areas because of strikes claimed and were paid unemployment benefit in Western Australia in the last 12 months? How many dependent children did these women have between them? As there are very long distances between many industrial towns in Western Australia and the nearest social security office, will the Minister tell the Senate how the wives of workers stood down because of industrial disputes will establish their rights to special benefit when they and their children face genuine hardship? Can the Minister assure the Senate that these women and children will not go hungry while their eligibility is being established?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I am aware that for some people living in the remoter parts of Australia there can be longer delays in establishing entitlement for unemployment benefit than applies to people who are closer to regional offices of my Department. That is a problem which has been drawn to my attention in a very clear way and which I am presently examining to see whether we can reduce the delays which such people suffer.

answer.para: Apart from that general point, the honourable senator raised the matter in the context of legislation, which is to be debated later today, restricting the right of the wives of strikers to seek the assistance of the social security system. I am not able to give him the numbers which he seeks. Obviously I do not have that sort of detailed statistical information before me at the moment. Whilst I am prepared to seek that information, I remind him of the figures which were cited in the Senate last time there was a debate on that legislation . Those figures drew attention to the fact that a significant number of cases of payment were recorded in centres which were rather remote, such as Queensland coal centres which are very similar to the Western Australian example which he gave. Notwithstanding any difficulties which may apply generally in this field, clearly people in such centres have been able to gain unemployment benefit in the strike situation. Exactly the same procedures will be available to them to seek special benefit. They will be able to apply in the same way as they are able to apply for unemployment benefit. Again, it would be footling to suggest that there are not greater difficulties where people are remote from regional offices, but those difficulties are not insuperable and special benefit is granted in such circumstances. The statistics which I placed before the Senate last time this matter was debated showed quite clearly that some people had sought and obtained unemployment benefit while others had sought and obtained special benefit. There will be no change to those people who are entitled to seek and obtain special benefit.

As I indicated, I do not wish in question time to anticipate debate which will take place later. One of the features of the proposal which has been somewhat ignored in some of the debate which has occurred is that there is the safety net provision that dependent wives and children who are left without cash resources will be eligible for assistance through special benefit, it not being the intention of the Government to see such people deprived of sustenance. The point is that where such people have resources of their own there is no reason why they should be put onto the taxpayers' payroll in substitute for the income which they would normally have received had their spouse been at work.

question.block.title: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: PARKING OF LARGE COMMERCIAL VEHICLES

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory aware of the growing concern in some parts of Canberra about the parking of large commercial vehicles in suburban streets overnight and at weekends? Is the Minister aware of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly report of April 1980 recommending that this practice should be stopped? Is the Minister taking any steps to implement the report--
—Parish pump again. Are we a local council?

—The Opposition senator interjects and says 'Parish pump again.' Perhaps I should point out that in this Territory the Federal Government represents Federal, State and local government activities. This is an appropriate forum for me to be asking questions of this nature. The Opposition interjects whenever I ask a question dealing with local matters. Is the Minister taking any steps to implement the House of Assembly report to ensure that the danger from this type of parking is eliminated?

—It is entirely appropriate that Senator Reid draws our attention to the place of Canberra in the Australian scheme of things. Obviously she represents this particular part of Australia very well and very forcefully, as demonstrated by this very question which has been asked today. I am afraid that I have no specific information on the matter of commercial vehicles parking in Canberra. The very worth of Parliament is demonstrated by Senator Reid being able to bring this matter forward in this place and draw it to the attention of all honourable senators. Accordingly, I will do my part by bringing this matter to the attention of the Minister for the Capital Territory and making sure that he brings down an appropriate statement on it.

—Can the Minister for National Development and Energy explain to us why, on the one hand, the Government yesterday gave approval for the development of the Jabiluka uranium deposit in the Kakadu National Park region when, on the same day, Senator Sir John Carrick himself admitted in answer to a question on notice that the problem of disposal of nuclear waste is not likely to be solved before the year 2000, and possibly later? Further, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, has said in regard to Jabiluka that although the minimum requirement of 75 per cent of Australian equity and control has not yet been met , that condition will be satisfied before commercial production begins. Can the Minister tell this House what the current equity arrangements are and generally how they will be achieved? Finally, can the Minister assure this House that production at Jabiluka will not begin until satisfactory arrangements have been concluded with the Northern Land Council?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I regret to say that Senator Mason has a habit of not stating correctly answers I gave yesterday. He left out, as he did in a previous question, the key answer. The key answer was that the Minister has no knowledge of any firm proposals to construct facilities for the final disposal of high level nuclear waste. The answer referred to 'final disposal' and not 'disposal'.
—What is the difference?

—That makes all the difference in the world because this is a very important subject. Firstly, it is important to understand that the amount of waste which has been generated by nuclear electric power production throughout the world is quite small at this moment. Secondly, and my statement did not say otherwise, the technology for waste disposal does exist. In saying this it is also true that considerable effort is taking place to improve that technology, and that should be so. In other words, a great amount of research is going on, as with Synroc, the Australian initiative, to get the most perfect solution possible.
—We are leading the world.

—We are leading the world, as Senator Rae has said. In looking at the French program it is important to bear in mind that a part of the French technology at the moment is to hold the wastes in temporary storage for a number of years before disposing of them in vitrified form. I have been to the waste disposal undertaking. I have, in fact, seen the silos. I have observed the metal containers which are placed there in an air conditioned, air cooling situation in order to cool over a number of years before they are finally disposed of. So, the conclusion in the question was drawn from a wrong inference . It is fundamental to understand that techniques for disposal exist, that my answer related to final disposal of the cooled materials.
—Which is the only disposal. Do not equivocate.

—The situation is that the industry is a young industry . The industry will need with this technology-not with the Synroc technology-to have a cooling process over a number of years before final disposal in a known place, presumably in salt caves. The knowledge on disposal exists today. The technology on disposal exists today. The first step in the process is happening today, that is, a cooling off in the silos pending final disposal. The molecular incorporation involved in the Synroc project which we are seeking to develop suggests that we could well shorten that process. As there was some noise, I did not hear in full the detailed part of the question concerning Jabiluka. If Senator Mason would like to ask a supplementary question I would be happy to refer to the matter.

question.speaker: Mason Sen C.V.J.

talk.start.para: —I raise a supplementary question. I confess that I cannot quite see the difference between final disposal and disposal. However, the rest of the question was:

question.para: . . . Mr Anthony, has said in regard to Jabiluka that although the minimum requirement of 75 per cent of Australian equity and control has not yet been met , that condition will be satisfied before commercial production begins.

The Australian Democrats sought enlightenment from the Minister on how that could be done and on what current arrangements are. We also sought an assurance that production would not begin until satisfactory arrangements had been agreed to by the Northern Land Council. Those were the two points that I raised.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I will look at both those matters. The fact is that under our foreign investment guidelines for uranium we have set as a desirable standard a level of 75 per cent Australian equity. We strive to achieve that. Our arrangements have always been that we do not proceed to mining until we have made the appropriate arrangements with the land councils concerned. I will ask the Ministers concerned to look at both those questions and if there is further comment I will have it passed on to Senator Mason.

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, I refer you to the words used by Senator Sir John Carrick in his preamble to the answer he gave to Senator Mason's question. I believe that either wittingly or unwittingly the Minister reflected on the integrity-quite wrongly- of Senator Mason. He said that Senator Mason has a habit, or words to that effect, of leaving significant parts of answers out of the questions that he asks. In this case Senator Mason said that Senator Sir John Carrick yesterday admitted that the problem of disposal of nuclear wastes was unlikely to be solved before the year 2000. On that basis Senator Sir John Carrick made an allegation against Senator Mason and said that yesterday he did not say 'disposal', he said 'final disposal', and that there is a big difference between disposal and final disposal. With my limited intellectual capacity, I confess that Senator Sir John Carrick did not persuade me that there was any difference at all. I suggest that he made a reflection on my colleague. Mr President, I ask that he withdraw today, or that before he makes those sorts of refletions in future he contemplates the importance of them.

—Mr President, I ask your indulgence to speak to the point of order. It would not be my intention to make reflections. It so happens that in a previous question, which escapes me at the moment, a similar situation occurred. A sentence was given in which key words were left out. I simply reminded the Senate and the honourable senator that that happened before. Because the key words were left out, the significance of both the question and the answer were not there. There is a fundamental difference between 'disposal' and 'final disposal'. We are disposing of waste products today in silo cooling situations. We are disposing of them at this moment in order that, when they are cool, they can be finally disposed of in salt mines or elsewhere. There is no intention whatsoever to reflect upon the honourable senator. It was simply to remind him that on a previous occasion a similar misunderstanding had occurred because the question did not relate itself to my answer yesterday.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I do so in the light of two facts. In view of the apparent urgency as a result of the huge escalation in the amount of the liability of Trans Australia Airlines in respect of its employer contributions to the Commomwealth Superannuation Fund, amounting as at 30 June last year to $180m and therefore, at the curent escalation rates, now exceeding $200m, and generally in the light of the disappointing operating results from Trans Australia Airlines as reported in its recent report, I ask: What is the present stage in relation to the termination or determination of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund's application to employees of TAA? Secondly, what stage has been reached in the investigation of the restructuring of Trans Australia Airlines as a public company?

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I think the Senate generally will be aware of the very considerable financial difficulties which have been discussed in this place and revealed recently by Trans Australia Airlines in its report. Senator Peter Rae draws our attention in particular to the problem of superannuation liability with respect to TAA employees. He would also be aware, as would the Senate, that considerable action has been taken by the management and the board of TAA to cut its losses by reducing expenditure in various ways. There has been emphasis on the reduction of staff numbers and the reduction of salaries applicable in that area. Due regard has also been had to the lack of growth in the industry generally in recent times, and cost-cutting measures have been implemented in relation to certain routes which TAA is flying.

answer.para: The superannuation liability is a matter to which the Minister is currently giving attention. I am unable to give the honourable member any further information at this moment except to say that the Minister is taking a very close interest in the matter. I expect that this will be discussed between unions and the Department and/or the management of TAA at various meetings in the not too distant future.

A further matter which Senator Rae raised was the formation of a public company or otherwise to operate TAA. As he would know, there are many complex issues connected with this matter. That involves one point which he perhaps already acknowledges, that is, the question of the superannuation liability of TAA, the capital structure of the company, the staff employment conditions and the renegotiation of TAA's existing loans.

Before proceeding to a consideration of those matters, the Government is currently consulting with both TAA and the Crown Solicitor regarding the necessary draft memorandum and articles of association that are necessary for the company's establishment. As has been stated quite clearly on previous occasions, the company, if formed, will be 100 per cent Commonwealth owned. As the Minister has indicated previously, the Government has not made any decision at this stage about the sale of shares to the private sector. For a fuller explanation of the current situation with regard to superannuation, I will refer that part of Senator Rae's question to the Minister and obtain an early reply for him.

talk.start.para: —Can the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs assure the Senate that he will resist pressure being exerted on him by the Everingham Government in the Northern Territory to exempt the route covered by the proposed Magellan gas line project from the terms of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act?

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I was intrigued to read in this morning's Australian an account of a supposedly secret message which had come to me from the Northern Territory Government. I understand that the reporter must have received the same telexes, as numerous other people have, in which the Northern Territory Government made known its view on this matter. The land involved was promised in 1976 as Schedule I land to be granted to the Hermannsburg people. That is the land to which Senator Ryan is referring. In fact that land is covered by a Bill presently before the Senate which will enable the grant of that land some years later. But the delay has been due to the desire of the Hermannsburg people to have it granted in accordance with their wishes.

answer.para: In view of the promise in 1976 that this would become Aboriginal land, and in the light of the legislation now before the Senate, I think there is no intention to do other than to grant the land as Aboriginal land and to see easements and other matters negotiated in accordance with due process. I understand, firstly, that there is no uncertainty about the route for a proposed easement. Secondly, the traditional owners in the area are waiting to get the benefit of royalties which they have negotiated. They are very keen to see the easement completed because they cannot get the royalties for the gas from Palm Valley until the easement is completed and the gas starts flowing.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that malnutrition kills or disables millions of children every year? Stanley Barnes, author of 200 Million Hungry Children, called for people to face facts squarely and to work for the political will to see that things that ought to be done are done. In the light of these requests, I ask: Will the Minister explain to the Senate what is the ongoing role of the Commonwealth in improving food distribution between rich and poor nations?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — In the current financial year Australian aid expenditure will total over $662m. A significant proportion of this aid is provided for development projects, food aid and training assistance to more than 70 developing countries, including half those countries which are classified as the least developed countries. It is believed that this level of aid reflects the Government's concern to give as much assistance as it is able. We hope that it assists in bridging the gap between the poor and rich countries in helping to overcome the problems associated with feeding the world's population. There are other things that we are able to do, such as provide research aid and projects of that sort. I believe that we are active in world assistance for developing countries. We share our expertise wherever this is possible. As I said, our aid of $662m that was provided in this year's Budget is directed towards the problems that were inherent in Senator Watson's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and follows the question asked earlier by Senator Hamer about power supplies in New South Wales. Has the Minister read an article by Christopher Jay in the Australian Financial Review of 2 March headed: 'Why Victoria Faces Winter Power Failures'? If so, is he familiar with the memorandum from the Assistant General Manager of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria which argues that the Loy Yang project should be deferred in order to ease the financial strains in Victoria brought about by three factors-rising interest rates, wage pressures and Federal Government funding cut backs? If the Minister is familiar with the memorandum, does he recall that it points to the fact that economic growth rates in Victoria will be lower than the national average of Australia? Are these factors, which have been brought to his attention in relation to the power supply situation in Victoria, likely to lead to winter failures?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I do not recall the article. I certainly do not believe that I have had the privilege of seeing any such memorandum. It would interest me to see it. My understanding is quite clear, that over the summer months the Victorian Government has been able to generate not only sufficient electrical power for Victoria, whilst doing its own maintenance work, but also substantially more to provide for New South Wales. I am not aware of the memorandum. I cannot say what it says so I cannot comment on it. I will have a look at it. In relation to the growth rate of Victoria, the fact is that the people of Victoria are being reminded at this moment that the general peformance of Victoria in a wide range of activities is a pace-setter for Australia. Victoria, through the development of its brown coal in particular and its power supply, will be able to offer substantial opportunities to industries to invest and to provide employment. Furthermore, an indication of that is the willingness of the Japanese to invest very largely in a pilot plant in the Latrobe Valley for coal liquefaction. I will have a look at the matter and see whether there is anything further to add. I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

—Earlier in Question Time Senator McIntosh asked a question about the difficulties which might be faced by the wives of strikers in obtaining special benefit. Because I suspect he wants some figures for the debate later today I thought I would give him the figures which are available to me. I quote those as available examples which might be of interest to the honourable senator.

—Because Senator McIntosh is not in the chamber, I ask that the Minister table the document. This will assist Senator McIntosh, who otherwise will have to do without the advantage of the Minister's comment, relevant or otherwise.
