proctext.para: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

interject.para: The Fraser Government's continuing failure to fulfil its economic promises to reduce inflation, reduce unemployment, reduce interest rates, reduce taxation, increase real incomes and economic growth.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: — Last week the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) had the audacity to extol the virtue of government policies marked by, to use his words, balance, vision and realism. He had the effrontery to denounce what he called unrealistic demands and expectations. Nobody has done more to fuel unrealistic demands and false expectations than the Fraser Government and in particular the Prime Minister. I will give some examples by citing extracts from the speeches. The list is by no means exhaustive. The Prime Minister in his 1975 policy speech promised jobs for all. He promised to end the great tax rip-off. He promised full indexation of personal income tax and 5 per cent to 7 per cent real growth in gross domestic product per annum. He also promised to maintain Medibank. In 1977 he promised that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent over the coming year, saying that it was a target that could and would be met. He promised again to end the great tax rip-off. He promised specifically tax cuts in the form of fistfuls of $5 notes. This blazed out of the pages of newspapers in full page advertisements with headings such as ' Liberals offer tax cuts' and showing fistfuls of $5 notes.

speech.para: In 1978 in the Budget Speech the Government stated that inflation would be down to 5 per cent by the middle of 1979. In the 1980 policy speech the Prime Minister promised the great resources boom-the $29 billion resources boom. What actually happened? Jobs for all were promised but unemployment last month hit the highest level ever recorded since the Australian Bureau of Statistics has been collecting statistics. Incidentally, unemployment has been at higher levels continuously since the Fraser Government took office than it was prior to its taking office. I cite the great tax rip-off. Not only has it not ended but it has been extended, widened and deepened. We have the highest income tax ever. The tax indexation promised was buried completely in May 1981. It was never fully applied. It was promised there would be 5 per cent to 7 per cent real growth in gross domestic product but no single year since the Government came to office nor in any 12-month period, whether a calendar year or financial year, has real growth of gross domestic product equalled the lower end of the range that the Prime Minister promised in 1975.

For three of the calendar years since the Fraser Government came to office real growth in gross domestic product has actually been negative. The 1977 promise was that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent over the coming year. The Prime Minister stated that that target could and would be met. Interest rates are now 3 per cent or 4 per cent higher than they were then. They are at record levels and still rising. Taxation remains at record levels and is still rising. The tax cuts of 1977, the fistfuls of $5 notes that stared at us from full page advertisements in all the newspapers in the country, disappeared in June of the next year when the infamous surcharge was applied-as a temporary expedient for one year only. It remained in force for one and a half years and then was replaced by fiscal drag, by the secret tax of inflation, as the Prime Minister used to call it, which continues to maintain and extend the highest taxation rates we have ever seen.

The 5 per cent inflation predicted in the 1978 Budget for mid-1979 turned out to be 9.8 per cent-an error of almost 100 per cent. The great resources boom, the jewel in the Liberal Party crown for the 1980 election, is in the process of becoming the great resources bust. The Prime Minister, again in his 1980 election policy speech, said:
A new confidence is alive in Australia's men and women.
Our financial position is the envy of many industrialised countries.
Business expectations are high.
The optimism of overseas investors has been restored.
That is what the Prime Minister was saying in 1980. This is the man who had the effrontery last week to denounce those who raise unrealistic expectations. In 1980 he said:
Manufacturing exports are growing strongly.
Last year rural exports were the highest for the decade.
Last year, our balance of trade was the best result for the decade. And, under the Fraser-Anthony Government, Australia has won a respected place in world affairs.

That is what he promised only 18 months ago. What is the reality? What do we actually have today? We have a consumer price index and the inflation rate well above double figures; by far the highest levels of income tax and other taxation ever imposed in peacetime; record interest rates; record unemployment; a balance of payments crisis; and an economic growth rate that is either falling rapidly or may even, on the latest indicators, be stagnant or negative. What about business confidence? What about the one area where the Fraser Government would claim above all else to have respect and to inspire confidence? What about business confidence? Yesterday, the all ordinaries index on the stock exchange hit 463 points, which is down 200 points on what was said to have been an unrealistically low level prior to the 1980 election, which situation was caused , according to Mr Fraser, by the fear of an impending Labor victory. If the fear of a Labor victory was responsible for the fall in the week before the 1980 election, obviously the reality of a Fraser government is far more frightening than the prospect of a Labor government. All of those crucial, economic indices- growth rate, inflation, unemployment rates, interest rates, stock exchange index levels-are moving in the wrong direction.

Two events above all others-the release of the December 1981 consumer price index figure, which was the highest for five years, and the February unemployment figures, which are the highest ever-were such a devastating indication of the failure of this Government that the truth could no longer be successfully denied. The economy is sick. Even the Government has finally admitted it. Its excuse for the sickness was that it is externally caused; it is part of a world scene. The Prime Minister claimed last week:

We cannot but be affected by factors such as the present slackness in world demand, and the high cost of funds, nor can we avoid being affected by the protectionism which strikes at many of our exports, especially our farm products .

Like his Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) he is an innocent victim of circumstances, or so the Prime Minister would have us believe. I might add that this is a very different view of the world to that which he boastfully asserted at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference in 1975 when he was making his run for the Liberal Party leadership and the prime ministership. He said:

When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature, they would be saying 'We can overcome'.

The Prime Minister certainly is not saying now: 'We can overcome'. He has the effrontery to denounce others for allegedly raising false expectations and feeding false hopes. This innocent victim of circumstances excuse is accompanied by a repetition of the boasts, false assertions, misrepresentations and wishful thoughts which have characterised statements by this Government on the economy for the last six years. Central to that diversionary tactic is the assertion that Australia has done very well since the mid-1970s relative to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as a whole and the major industrial powers. I quote again from the Prime Minister's speech last week. He said:
It is an undoubted fact that as a result of our policies Australia has prospered in recent years while the rest of the world has been stagnating.

That statement simply is not true. It is presented as an alibi. In fact it is a piece of fiction. I have in front of me a series of tables taken from the OECD Economic Outlook No. 30 published in December 1981 which gives on a calendar year basis-all OECD figures are presented in this form-unemployment rates, gross domestic product growth rates and consumer price index changes for Australia, for the OECD as a whole and for a number of individual OECD countries. That publication shows that in every one of the years from 1976 to 1981 inclusive the unemployment rate in Australia was higher than it was in Austria, Germany, Japan , Norway and Sweden and is higher also than the OECD average as a whole for those same years, with one minor reservation, namely, the OECD composite figure for 1981 is not yet available. If we look at real GDP growth-the 1981 figures again are not available-for the four years from 1977 to 1980 we see that Australia's average growth rate was 2.3 per cent. The average growth rate for the OECD as a whole was 3.1 per cent. In every one of those years Norway had a higher growth rate than Australia. In all but one of those years both Japan and West Germany had higher growth rates than Australia. The consumer price index for some of those years was marginally lower in Australia than it was in the OECD as a whole, a situation which, on the most recent available statistics, has been reversed. In other words, throughout this period where the Government boasts that Australia has performed very well relative to the rest of the OECD the plain fact is that our unemployment record and our economic growth record are below the OECD average.

talk.start.para: —It is not. It was 4 per cent last year. It is estimated to be 3 per cent next year.

—Just a minute, sweetie. Throughout that period Australia's average growth rate has been significantly lower than that of the OECD as a whole. Throughout that period, for every one of those years, the unemployment rate was higher than the OECD average. In every one of those years it was higher than the rate in Austria, Germany, Japan, Norway and Sweden. I suggest to the honourable senator, if he is numerate enough to understand it which, judging from some of his previous statements in the Senate, is probably open to doubt, that he consult the OECD Economic Outlook No. 30 published on 30 December and verify those figures. Certainly in the financial year 1980-81 growth rates in Australia were above the OECD average. That situation has very quickly been reversed. In one year only have we managed to perform better in terms of growth rate than the OECD as a whole. The Prime Minister said:

speech.para: It is an undoubted fact that as a result of our policies Australia has prospered in recent years-
He said 'years' in the plural-
while the rest of the world has been stagnating.

The truth is the reverse. The Government's response, at a somewhat more sophisticated level or from a different direction to these realities, is to boast about the large increase in household income-a $2.7 billion real increase in household income in the financial year 1980-81 over that of the previous year . That is a dishonest figure, firstly, because it makes no allowance for the increase in the number of households, which accounts for about half of that aggregate increase. Nor does it present the most recent statistics, which are for the September quarter of 1981 over the September quarter of 1980. When looked at on that basis, real disposable household income expressed in September 1981 dollars has fallen from $5,023 to $4,994. On the most recent available statistics real average disposable household income has actually fallen compared with what it was a year earlier, something which reflects to a very substantial degree the massive Fraser Government tax rip-off and the effects of what Mr Fraser used to call 'the secret tax of inflation'. More recently we have had Professor Pollard's figures cited to us. Professor Pollard-I eventually tracked this down-an Emeritus Professor of Statistics at, I think, the Macquarie University, in a publication called Australian Economic Trends, dated February 1982, stated:

My text is taken from the February 1982 publication 'The Hayden Health Plan'. The text is the first sentence of that publication which reads as follows: 'The living standards of Australian families have fallen dramatically over the last six years.' what do the figures show?

That is a rhetorical question. Pollard's figures certainly do not show changes in living standards over the last six years; Pollard's figures show changes between December 1974 and December 1980. We need to bear in mind that he wrote this article after the Hayden health plan was released, after the figures for December 1981 were available. Pollard claims to have disproved Labor's claim by selecting figures for a different time period. There was, of course, a good reason for that. The figures for the real period, December 1975 to December 1981 -the last six years at the time Pollard produced his figures-showed not only the reverse of what Pollard claimed they show but the reverse to a very dramatic degree. Pollard has long been a toady of the conservative establishment. He has now shown himself willing to misuse his academic prestige and title to give a facade of credibility to a fraudulent misrepresentation of the facts. He is an academic prostitute. The final diversionary tactic is to say: 'Well, tax might be high but it would be $7 billion higher if the Hayden scale were still in operation'. Why pick on the Hayden scale; why not the McMahon scale? If that were still in operation taxes would be $15 billion higher.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —Today's debate on a matter of public importance is the latest in a series of debates on the economy that has been brought forward by Senator Walsh and his colleagues. A number of themes constantly appear in these debates. They seem to seek to denigrate Australia and the efforts that are made by Australians and they are apparent in the approach that was taken again today. There is always, in a speech from Senator Walsh, the absolutely irresistible impulse to denigrate individuals, to attack them rather than to discuss policies. I think we saw that in the closing stages of Senator Walsh's speech. To have spoken of an academic, Professor Pollard, in the terms that he did shows that he has very little understanding of the information and expertise that can come from people of long years of experience-far longer than Senator Walsh has or perhaps many of us in this place have been able to show-in a field of endeavour about which we have informed ourselves.

speech.para: Time and again we are faced with the selective use of statistics-quotes being given to back up a particular assertion, the careful use of a particular year. Selectivity is addressed in an obvious way so that some particular point can be made. Above all, there is always the utter failure to offer any credible alternative. The obvious denigration of the achievement of Australia in economic terms, in terms of contribution to the world community, is brought forward by Senator Walsh and his colleagues without any credible alternative. If the problems facing the Australian economy are of the order and magnitude that are suggested by Senator Walsh it could rightly be assumed that anyone posturing to be a member of an alternative government would have at least developed some policies to deal with these matters. The fact is that the Australian Labor Party has no credible alternative; it has no alternative policies. Indeed, the very programs put forward by ALP spokesmen could only exacerbate economic difficulties leading to higher interest rates, higher taxation, less investment and more unemployment in Australia.

An article in the Bulletin released today pointed out that Mr Hayden had declared on a television program that he found economics 'boring and irrelevant' . I think we can safely assume that Mr Whitlam had the same attitude to economics because the Budgets during his term of office led Australia into many economic difficulties. If Mr Hayden, as the present Leader of the Opposition, finds economics boring and irrelevant I would expect that some of his colleagues would attempt to put into effect policies that any alternative government ought to develop and present. The sort of speech that we heard from Senator Walsh today-linked with our knowledge that the Leader of the Opposition sees economics as boring and irrelevant-makes us feel rather fearful of what would happen if they were ever entrusted to put policies into effect. The article in the Bulletin went on to say:
. . . by opting out of rational economic debate Mr Hayden was able to climb on to every passing bandwagon.
Senator Walsh attempts to climb on to a very destructive bandwagon.

talk.start.para: —Who was the author of the article?
— The author of the article is one of the journalists who write for the Bulletin magazine.
—Alan Reid, I suppose.

— I am not sure whether it was Mr Reid. The article appears in today's issue. The author may be Mr Max Walsh or one of the journalists who write constantly for that journal. Mr Hayden is not alone on the passing bandwagon, because the sorts of things that Senator Walsh says in this place show that he will be on the same bandwagon, playing the same tune without any respect for the realities and the needs of the Australian people. The Bulletin article concluded-I think it is highly relevant given the tone of the speech we have just heard-by stating:

speech.para: The way in which he (Mr Hayden) has allowed emotive factors to set the tone of economic debate suggests either an unwillingness or inability to bring intellectual honesty to bear.

Perhaps that is what we ought to be on about if we are looking at the economic difficulties of this country and of many countries in the developing world. I think that a debate of frankness, honesty and perhaps an endeavour to lead to better things would be far more useful than one which simply denigrates every aspect of Australia's achievement. Many of the issues that we face today are complex. More than ever they demand rational debate and they need a very careful analysis. If we were to take the other side of the argument and look at the strong points in our economic position and then at some of the problems we might have a more informed debate on the whole matter of the Australian economy and the Australian community.

There can be no doubt that our economy has recorded significant achievements over the last two years in terms of economic growth, investment growth, creation of jobs, rising real incomes and the sharp reduction in the size of the Budget deficit. They are all strengths in the economy; they are all positive achievements. Yet there was no mention of any of them. These achievements were made at a time when the world economy was running down and in very serious difficulties. Therefore the advances that have been made are even more creditable. We can swim against the tide if we have used the right economic policies. As a result of our policies Australia as a whole has prospered. This should not be ignored at any time that we are talking about the economic difficulties, the economic debate or the consequences of certain policies.

In contrast to the picture painted by Senator Walsh, I will cite a number of statistics which illustrate our Government's record. In some cases the figures were used by Senator Walsh so I do not think there will be any doubt about them. The honourable senator chose to look at unemployment. I do not deny that there is a difficulty in finding sufficient employment opportunities for all people who seek employment in Australia. But we should look at the fact that almost 400 ,000 new jobs have been created in the last three years, about 90 per cent of those being in the private sector. We can hardly suggest that there is not a business confidence that underlines whatever difficulties we may face. The new jobs are real jobs in which people will be able to use their skills and contribute to the development and growth of the economy.

Senator Walsh spoke about family incomes and questioned the growth in them. There was an increase in real household disposable income of about $2.9 billion after tax in 1980-81. We can cite an increase in real household disposable income of almost $3,000m. An after-tax increase of almost $3,000m in family disposable income is very significant.

talk.start.para: —What about the inflation rate?

— Inflation is important, but we cannot ignore the growth in real household disposable income, the rewards enjoyed by people who have been in employment during that time and the additional 400,000 people who have found new jobs in the last three years. Another matter that was raised was investment. This is crucial to the health of the economy. The 1980-81 rate of increase was the highest for 30 years. That figure should not be denigrated; it is a very considerable achievement in light of many of the difficulties that face modern economies. The 1981-82 rate is also likely to be over 10 per cent in real terms. It should be remembered that business investment is the way in which we create employment. It is the way in which the vital creation of new jobs is able to be undertaken and it is the basis on which real improvements in the standard of living will come about.

speech.para: Rather than talking down our achievements, let us look at the confidence that has been shown by those who wish to invest their capital, seek a return on it and provide the much needed employment opportunities. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) recently pointed out that we are one of the few countries which has been able to reduce total Budget outlays as a percentage of the gross domestic product and to bring about a significant improvement in balance between revenue and expenditure . That has been one of the important aspects of this Government's policy in creating its Budgets. We look at the Budget outlays and we find it a primary responsibility of government, on behalf of the Australian people and the use of their funds, to see that the total Budget outlay as a percentage of the gross domestic product is as low as possible in order to maintain the services that people expect from government. We have carried out this policy constantly, probably with very great effort, and we will continue to do so.

In the short term, Australia is facing the future from a position of comparative strength, provided that it does not squander its advantages and it is able to overcome its current difficulties and face the future with confidence . It is that confidence that we ought to be trying to develop and not the spirit offered in the terms of the matter of public importance before us. We are facing a downturn in world trade and our export markets must inevitably be affected. As competition becomes tougher on export markets we are facing renewed inflationary pressures at home which can only reduce our competitive advantages. Last week the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) sought to address the nation on these matters and even that statement was the subject of denigration. The fact that a prime ministerial statement addressed itself to the position of Australia and to its prospects in world terms is something that ought to be welcomed because it can open up public debate and discussion. Apparently, there was something wrong even in putting facts forward as we see them. In that speech the Prime Minister made it clear that excessive wage rises and damaging strikes were placing economic progress at risk. It does not need very great economic expertise to understand that excessive wage rises for those who have jobs make it very difficult for those who do not have jobs, when one looks at the profitable employment of capital needed to provide employment opportunities.

In view of the difficulties facing New South Wales today-these were mentioned during Question Time in the Senate-I would think that any Australian Labor Party spokesman who is prepared honestly to face up to reality would undoubtedly agree with the Prime Minister that excessive wage rises and damaging strikes are placing economic progress at risk in that great State. This is the spirit that ought to be adopted in this chamber. The threat to family incomes and job security in New South Wales has not been laid at the unions' door by none other than the President of the Australian Labor Party, the honourable Neville Wran, who is the Premier of New South Wales. That great State is in difficulties with regard to providing continued and full employment to the millions of people who live in it because of the lack of responsibility shown by union members. Their actions are causing untold disadvantage to the people in that State. The risks that are facing that State are so grave that all of us can only hope that reason will prevail.

In the context of the debate today, the point to note is this: How can the ALP ever hope to portray itself as a credible alternative government if its key economic spokesmen, such as Senator Walsh, fail to analyse and boldly confront the real issues? Senator Walsh raised the issue of taxation. The present taxation levels are of concern to many people and to the Government. The Government certainly understands the community's hope for reduced taxation and it will make further taxation reductions when it is economically responsible to do so. That, of course, has to be linked with the expenditure of government and the way in which we are able to raise the revenue to meet that expenditure. In contrast to our policy, which is clear and absolutely unequivocal, the Labor Party believes that it can increase the levels of taxation. The shadow Treasurer and others have certainly made that point clear in statements over the years. Not only personal taxes would need to be raised but also wealth tax, capital gains tax, probate tax and all the other things that ALP spokesmen talk about. If we are looking at after tax income we need to look at the policies of an alternative government and wonder what level of taxation would be needed to fund them. A very good reason why the Labor Party must talk about increasing taxation levels is the string of promises which have been made which would inevitably lead to some source of funds from the Australian taxpayer.

talk.start.para: —They might break them like you did yours.

— If that is what the honourable senator is suggesting, if that is the way in which he makes promises, then so be it. That is his statement, not mine. The honourable senator says he can make promises and not pay for them. Senator Walsh also mentioned inflation in the discussion today . The Government believes that inflation remains at the forefront as the principal threat to this economy and to our competitive position on world markets. That is why we recognise the dangers posed by constant demands for higher wages and shorter working hours and the strikes which threaten the livelihood of many Australians. None of these issues were addressed by Senator Walsh. Given the nature of his party, he would not be in a position to raise such matters as the demand for higher wages, shorter working hours and strikes. He would probably find himself off the front bench and not able to confront an issue which is basic to economic security and health. Senator Walsh would not deny that we have reduced inflation from the record levels under the Whitlam Government and that by international standards our record in this area has been among the more successful in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.

speech.para: Another matter mentioned by Senator Walsh was economic growth. He was prepared to admit that last year Australia's growth rate was significantly higher than that in most industralised countries. In OECD countries there was a growth rate of only just over one per cent while Australia recorded a solid 3 per cent rate of growth. Of course, he did not acknowledge the high investment figures which I mentioned earlier in this debate. On the figures that come from comparable countries in the OECD area we must recognise that our solid 3 per cent growth last year in comparison with just over one per cent of other countries is something again which shows the inherent strength and development of the Australian economy. Senator Walsh discussed interest rates. Interest rates are high; no one denies that. Given the international environment, particularly the American interest rates, there is no magic wand, as Senator Walsh might like to have us think, to bring the level of interest rates down.

Indeed, the sorts of policies that are put forward by the Australian Labor Party can only exacerbate the current economic difficulties. The policies that were followed by the Labor Party when in government, which caused such economic devastation to this country, continue to be expressed as the policies of the present ALP Opposition. The ALP policies of high deficits and lax monetary policies could only compound the difficulties that we now face. In view of the fact that Senator Walsh mentioned world economic trends on the domestic economy during the term of the Whitlam Government, it is worth bringing a few points to his attention. Our criticism in 1974 was directed not so much at the disruptive state of the world economy but rather at the extent to which the policies of the Labor Government aggravated and encouraged, through expansion of the money supply and expenditure, encouragement of the wage explosion and deficits, the influence on the Australian economy of world economic trends. We criticised that aspect and not the fact that the world economy was in a particular state. The way in which the Whitlam Government attempted to address the questions and the policies that were at that time operative with regard to the money supply and the expanson of expenditure-its approach to economic responsiblity was completely reckless-was the matter that we had under debate. We are happy to debate that at any time.

I have tried to bring some balance into this debate today to get away from the purely negative and denigratory statements that have been made by Senator Walsh. I acknowledge that there are economic difficulties, but prospects and opportunities are also before the Australian people. If we indulge always in abuse and exaggeration, I think we only cloud the real issues. The Opposition has failed to come up with any credible alternative policies. I think that highlights the continuing irresponsibility of the party to which Senator Walsh belongs and the party which would aspire some time to be the government of this country. I argue that when debating the state of the Australian economy we should look to its strengths, its achievements and the undoubted investment confidence that has been shown and hope that by working together in a different way from that put forward by Senator Walsh we will ultimately provide the opportunities for employment for all Australians.

speech.speaker: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

talk.start.para: —Senator Walsh was criticised by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for allegedly attacking and denigrating Australia's efforts. Senator Walsh was seeking rather to protect Australia and the Australian people from the inadequate and unsatisfactory economic performance of the Fraser Government. He was, in fact, setting about to denigrate the policies that that Government has been performing in its seventh year of office.

speech.para: The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) only a week ago came to the Parliament with a most pessimistic portrayal of the state of the Australian economy. He sought to tell the Australian people that they should reduce their expectations, tighten their belts and put up with the state of affairs facing the Australian economy. This is a marked contrast to his public statements on the eve of the 1980 elections when he promised a $25 billion resource-type development of Australia in which all Australians would profit. Clearly, after seven years in office, this Government has failed to deliver the goods and now, after constant pricking by the Australian Labor Party about the state of the economy, the Prime Minister is forced to come to the Parliament and say that his policies are not working.

I will make a few points in order to prove the Opposition's point of view. When the British journal, the Economist, recently surveyed the prospects of Australia 's economy in 1980 it did so under the heading 'It will need more than luck.' Indeed, the survey pointed out, very clearly, the fact that our economic development depends very much on the strategy that we, Australia, map out now in this crucial period of an uncertain international climate. In the wake of the voters' condemnation of the Government's policies in the Lowe by-election, Mr Fraser and the Minister for Finance have made it clear that they do not intend to reconsider their economic strategy; that is, the economic strategy that has directed Australia's development for the past six years. The Prime Minister, in his most recent radio talk, said plainly that the thrusts of his monetary economic policy would be maintained. In other words, he will follow the policies of President Reagan and Prime Minister Thatcher and will continue in the belief that those policies are of benefit to Australia. Yet these are the economic policies which have brought many Australians misery and hardship, put thousands more out of work and brought production and growth to a virtual standstill. These policies have brought every major economic and social indicator to their lowest ebb in years.

I would like today to draw the Senate's attention to some of these indicators and to point out to the Minister that her figures are to be challenged and refuted. For example, the most recent figures on unemployment released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show unemployment officially at 482,600, some 7 per cent of the work force. We know that many other thousands can be added to that because of hidden figures.

Let us look at taxation. This Government came to office with a welter of anti- tax statements claiming that it would reduce the tax burden on the Australian people. This has been proven to be the biggest lie of the Fraser Government. Taxes have not been reduced. They have increased, and the burden has fallen heavily upon the average wage earner. In the years 1980, 1981 and 1982 the total Commonwealth tax receipts as a portion of gross domestic product increased by over 2 per cent. Net pay-as-you-earn receipts-that is, tax collected from Mr and Mrs Average Australian-have risen from 41.7 per cent of total tax revenue to 45. 7 in the current year. At the same time taxes collected from non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers-that is, those with incomes from business, property or dividends-have fallen from 13.1 per cent of total tax revenue to 9.5 per cent. So there has been a redistribution from the poor to the wealthy. In the years 1975-76 to 1980 -81, the last year for which statistics are available, tax payments by PAYE taxpayers increased by 101 per cent, while total wages, salaries, supplements, et cetera have grown by only 72 per cent. Over the same period, payments by non- pay-as-you-earn taxpayers grew by 56 per cent, while their incomes grew in the same period by some 94 per cent. These figures underline the fact that the tax system under this Government is working against the average PAYE taxpayer.

Let us look at the cuts that have taken place in living standards-the social wage. With cuts in most areas of government spending, assistance and welfare, particularly those that benefit people in their day to day lives, it is estimated that the average tradesman has lost something like $22.50 per week in cuts in the social wage, as we call it. That same tradesman has lost an extra $ 31 per week through tax hikes. In total, $53 per week has been taken out of the wage earner's pocket by the Fraser Government.

Let us look at inflation which Senator Walsh referred to in his matter of public importance. It is now well into double figures. The most recent figures released in the December quarter show that inflation is running at 11.3 per cent . In the area of growth and employment several key factors of the economy have witnessed a downturn. Generally employment growth has slowed while in sectors such as building construction, iron and steel production, motor vehicle production, primary production and the textile industry there have been significant downturns. Let us look at some of the specific figures in these areas. In the building construction industry in December there was an 11.7 per cent decline in the seasonally adjusted number of private dwelling approvals. In the area of government building there was a 23.3 per cent decline in approvals for the month of December last. There was a 19 per cent reduction in pig iron production in the year from December 1980 to December 1981. One of today's papers indicates that Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd will retrench some 3,000 people from the steel works. The figures for raw steel production for that period show a 15 per cent drop. In the motor vehicle and related manufacturing industries car and station wagon production fell by 34,229 units in 1980-81 and tyre production dropped by 683,000. In primary production whole milk production went down by 231 million litres in 1980-81; cheese production went down by 17,477 tonnes; and beef and veal production went down by 98,400 tonnes.

Let us look at the mining sector-the cornerstone of the Fraser Government's economic strategy, as the Government says. The so-called resources boom has not fulfilled the expectations suggested in the Liberal Party policy statements only some 18 months ago. The fact of the matter is that whilst resource development has moved ahead it has not done so at the speed predicted and it cannot solely provide the basis for sound, overall economic development in this country. Yet this Government has relied solely upon that sector as a source of growth in the Australian economy. The top eight mining companies, in the year 1980 to 1981, were facing an enormous downturn in profit of $550m to $150m. The share market, of course, reflects such downturns. The slump in recent weeks is related in part to this failure in the resource sector along with international trends. Let us look also at capital inflow. Another key element of the Government's economic strategy has been the dependence on a large inflow of largely resource-related foreign capital. However, this inflow has fluctuated wildly and unpredictably. February's figures show a sharp rise in capital inflow from $252m in January to $674m in the next month. Much of this has been caused by heavy borrowing overseas because domestic credit has been too tight.

I have touched on just some of the problems in our economy today. The picture is one of gloom, one of decline and one that was painted pessimistically by our Prime Minister only last week. Falling living standards combined with high taxes , falling production, high unemployment, a credit squeeze and a shaky Australian dollar would surely underline the need for a new economic strategy. But no, not for the Prime Minister; it is the same old recipe for him, a continuation of the monetarist policies. The Fraser Government's economic approach can be characterised in three words-chaos, conflict and confrontation. There is chaos because there is no real organisation in the Government's approach and because no one in our country is really sure of where we are going. There is a downturn in some sectors while others prosper. There are moves for deregulation in some sectors and confusion in others. The point is that the Australian economy is being allowed to drift in line with international trends. The manufacturing sector continues to be pushed aside; public sector endeavours are relegated to irrelevancy while some export oriented concerns are profiting. The stalling of the world minerals market means our resources sector stalls too.

There is conflict between the competing interests in the economy with no attempt by the Government to resolve this conflict. Recent statements on the one hand, by the Australian Industries Development Association which urged deregulation along the lines of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and comments, on the other hand, by the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia predicting low production, low sales and high import competition for manufacturing illustrate the conflicts which are unresolved as a result of the attitudes taken by the Fraser Government . The Government has no ability to resolve these conflicts; it seems to have no desire to resolve these conflicts because there is conflict in its own ranks. Fraser, Howard and Anthony cannot agree on the key economic issues before us. The Government can only drag out its well-worn tactic of industrial confrontation with belligerent behaviour in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and hard-nosed new industrialised legislation.

The situation before us points surely to the need for the Federal Government to take hold of the situation, to grasp the nettle and to intervene in the economy in an orderly and organised fashion. Labor would seek to do this, not just let economic trends wash over us without any aim or purpose. Central to Labor's approach to economic management would be a program to attack inflation, stimulate production, increase employment and maintain real living standards. In such a program key elements would include a prices and incomes policy which would seek to regulate the inflationary trends of ad hoc, unco-ordinated price and wage rises while guaranteeing the maintenance of existing living standards. Labor agreement and negotiation with the union movement and with employers would be crucial here.

We need a policy of tax relief for the average taxpayer combined with a no- nonsense approach to tax avoidance which would assist in maintaining real incomes and taxing those with real wealth. We need a firm commitment to public services and benefits in health, education and welfare. We need to work in co- operation with the States. We need a planned policy of overall industrial development and financial regulation which would allow Australia to create and maintain a wide range of industries for employment and production. This could include, and probably should include, government involvement in some key areas but would revolve mainly around government encouragement for private sector development.

I have given some indication of the way we will go with our more expansionary policies built on a prices and incomes policy. Labor intends to proceed that way . We have been prepared to look at new policies and initiatives. That is one of the reasons why the Australian electorate is turning towards the Australian Labor Party. It is doing this because our policies stand in marked contrast to the failed policies of the Fraser Government which have led to the sad deterioration in confidence and performance in recent months and years. One only has to say: This Government, which will have served more than eight years when it faces the electors in 1983, will have had ample opportunity to put some stability into the Australian economy, to restore some business confidence in the Australian business community and to restore some confidence in the Australian people in their national government. This Government has failed dismally to do just that. It ill becomes a government spokesman in this place to seek to denigrate the constructive opposition of the Labor Party, which seeks constantly in this place to suggest the course of action that ought to be taken by a national and sensible Australian government. speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating a matter initiated by the Australian Labor Party Opposition whereby the Liberal-National Country Party coalition is required to justify its economic policies which have an impact on such matters as inflation, interest rates, taxation, real income, economic growth and unemployment. The incorporation of so many important issues in a debate with such tight time limitations, I believe, is a reflection of the lack of appreciation by the Opposition of many of these critical issues of our time. Indeed, I think that at the same time it is timely that we have had the opportunity to put on record some of the facts and some of the achievements of our Government. I thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for so succinctly and so clearly putting these achievements before the people listening to the broadcast of these proceedings.

speech.para: Whilst the Minister for Finance puts on record these achievements I think we have to recognise at the same time that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, has virtually turned his back on economic reality. Regrettably, the shadow spokesman on finance, Senator Walsh, stands alone in his personal economic rationalism. Unfortunately, he has had to hide these virtues behind a cloak of vitriolic attacks on the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). To suggest that we can achieve regulated low interest rates in a world of high interest rates at the same time as achieving a necessary inflow of capital funds from overseas to the tune of $8 billion to $10 billion I think is parallel to trying to defy the laws of gravity. Mr B. T. Loton, the managing director of Australia's largest manufacturing company, the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd, said that the surplus world steel capacity was the biggest single issue for Australia's steel making. He went on to say that 'while other steel producers in the countries in which they are operating seek to sell steel at almost any price, we do not really see a diminution of our difficulties unless we can keep some of the imports out'. This BHP story can be told a hundred times over. The threat to Australian jobs is ever present when other countries adopt such policies and when a vocal number of people in Australia stress that Australia should take advantage of such depressed world prices and import such competing goods. This is at the cost of local jobs and at a time when the economy, we believe, cannot afford it.

Despite the magnitude and the proliferation of some recent wage claims, our Government is determined to prevent a wage explosion which could be so destabilising to the other relativities. We are determined to prevent a repeat of the 1973-74 experience of wage leapfrogging. Personally I regret the decision last year to discontinue wage indexation, because now we have a system of collective bargaining without the United States-style penalties for breaches. Coupled with that we have national wage decisions. I submit that we now have almost a jungle situation, with some people getting the best of both worlds and with the stronger unions able to secure wage rises which inevitably lead to situations in which people with the same qualifications but employed by different industries receive vastly different rewards for their services. This happens not because one is better in his trade than the other, but simply because one is employed in a situation in which one union has much more industrial muscle than the other. I believe we now have a situation of industrial difficulties which is a far cry from the comparative wage justice we had up to the late 1960s when there was a basic wage plus margins for skill. This was generally accepted community philosophy, and I believe the sooner we return to that sort of equity the better we will be.

It is regrettable that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has disbanded its concern for obtaining wage justice across the board, is pandering to the whims of the strong and the militant and is disregarding the unemployed and those who are likely to be unemployed in the near future because of excessive wage demands . The Australian Economic Review, fourth quarter 1981, chapter 1, under the heading 'Domestic Outlook' acknowledges that the short term prospects for the economy have become more uncertain because of the abandonment of wage indexation and the subsequent proliferation of wage claims by the stronger unions in their so-called bid to restore certain relativities.

Let us look at some of the positive things that have been achieved. The rate of increase in business investment in Australia in the last financial year, as the Minister for Finance said, was the highest for 30 years. Of the 27 manufactured items reported by the Australian Statistician, 19 registered increased product levels over the last quarter and the major growth sectors were energy and the construction industry. If we look at petroleum exploration development, a key area of resource development, we see that it is predicted that between 280 and 300 wells will be drilled in Australia this year compared with 27 in 1975. That 1982 estimate is double the 1981 exploration program and will involve the expenditure of in excess of $800m. Mr Orchison, the director of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, says that 'the very significant increase in exploration effort predicted for 1982 reflects Australia's healthy political climate compared with the rest of the world'. That is a very significant matter. It has already been claimed that Australia's household disposable income after tax rose by nearly $300m. It is true that there has been an absolute growth in terms of numbers-we acknowledge that-but significant growth is there. So, let us recognise that it does exist. In the last two years to the December quarter average weekly earnings increased by over $13 in real terms. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development predicts a growth of over 3 per cent for Australia in 1982. The value of retail sales last December was 13 per cent higher than in 1980. Investment is healthy. Generally overall aggregate of taxation is lower than for most of our trading partners. The OECD predicts a further growth of 3 per cent for Australia in 1982 compared with the OECD average prediction of only one per cent. Consumer demand continues to be relatively strong. In 1981, 83,000 extra jobs were created. Our aim is to try to create a climate in which real tax cuts will be a viable proposition. The Prime Minister has said that the Australian dollar will continue to be devalued in line with the market. It has fallen about 6 per cent in recent times. This is indeed good news for primary producers who have been hard pressed to get realistic prices for their livestock.

One of the problems we have to acknowledge in this debate is that the instruments available to any government, be it a Liberal government or a Labor government, unfortunately are very blunt. Let me give an example of some of the problems that individuals face as a result of industrial dislocation. I come from Tasmania, for which the waterfront presents major difficulties. I instance the situation of a small beekeeper at Mole Creek. I think we can appreciate the difficulties when we come down to specifics in a dimension that we can appreciate. This honey producer has built up a nice export market. He produces a quality product and is shipping honey to the United States. But what happened recently? A container of his sat on the mainland wharves for three months because of a demarcation dispute. Being a small businessman, he had a problem of lack of capital; he had to finance a wages bill of about $70,000 per annum. Honourable senators might say that that is not much, but in a small country town in Tasmania that is a very significant amount. We have to overcome these types of demarcation disputes because small businessmen and small entrepreneurs in small country towns are very much at risk because of the industrial muscle of some unions fighting over demarcation issues.

I used that example because I think it brings home quite significantly and pointedly some of the problems that small businessmen are facing. The BHPs and the Utahs can probably face a bit of dislocation without fear of going out of business, but the small businessman is being pushed out of business daily by strike action. If we are to meet high wage demands with tight monetary policy, one of the fall-outs unfortunately will be an increase in unemployment. That is why I said that inevitably it is unfortunate that the instruments available to governments, irrespective of their political colour, are fairly blunt.

In my closing remarks I express regret that we use this chamber to denigrate distinguished Australians in their professional capacities. Professor Pollard used certain years to make his comparisons-I suppose everybody has to do that- but he examined real rises in household incomes and compared them with average weekly earnings. He not only examined the ownership of motor cars, which has increased, but also compared the cost movements of the vehicles. Using 1980-81 figures, as was mentioned, he selected an income of $10,000 for a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and found that the tax rate had fallen 21 per cent. In any analysis one has to select certain years and Professor Pollard may have selected years which suited his particular argument.

As my time is limited, I challenge the Treasury officials and economists to examine the philosophy of the economic consequence of the supply of and the demand for credit, which is recognised as being highly elastic, and of the impact of the elasticity of interest rates on borrowings at various levels of government budgetary deficits. For example Peter Crawford, Vice-President of the Economics Department of Citibank, has suggested that while the United States Federal Government deficit is increasing money supply growth, the 'crowding out' effect, to use his words, 'is mild'. I think the economic debate in Australia would be enhanced if economists could devote some time to looking at these relativities.

World leaders are seeking single solutions to solve their problems and bring their economies out of the recession. Mrs Thatcher has strongly pursued a monetary policy but at the same time she has presided over large increases in wage payments to public servants. In the United States supply theory economics was supposed to overcome that country's ills. In more recent times a new-found enthusiasm has emerged for the gold standard. I have read of my father's public concern about poverty amidst plenty during the midst of the cruel Depression of the 1930s. Surely that type of situation is one in which we find ourselves today , not only with the Third World and the Western world but also within our own nation. I believe that much of this imbalace is based on greed.

To introduce a policy of gold standard for coin would bring about austere restraints. The theory is to dampen the increase in money supply and inflation, gold having a limited supply. It is true there was significant inflation during the 1850s when there were large gold discoveries in Australia but gold is a sensitive indicator of monetary policy. It does represent a store value and has a number of inherent characteristics which are significant in this debate. I believe any debate on this issue can only enhance the understanding amongst people in trying to solve not only Australia's problems but also the world economic difficulties in which Australia is playing a very significant part. Australia has provided a lead to many other nations by its sound economic outlook. Other nations are looking to Australia to provide the lead and I believe our Government is doing just that.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —We are essentially debating the basic economic approach of the Government. Is that approach right or is it wrong? I well remember the first time that Milton Friedman visited this country. We were invited to a large dinner and we waited with baited breath to hear what the great man would have to say. We expected it to be complicated and difficult to follow. In fact it was a deceptively simple message. Milton Friedman said that good economic management required only one thing, the control of the rate of increase of the money supply. Providing the rate of increase in the money supply was controlled everything else fell into place. We did not need to worry about excessive demands by trade unions, we did not need to worry about excessive profits by big business and we did not need to worry about interest rates. That was Milton Friedman's very simple message. It is not surprising that the Government adopted this approach hook, line and sinker.

speech.para: The Government has for five years adopted a very firm monetarist policy. If it is going to be successful we should be seeing results by now. What in fact do we see? We see that we have record inflation; unemployment is at a record level; interest rates are at record levels; taxation is the highest in our history and real income and economic growth have fallen. The Government is turning to international events as the cause of this problem. There is no doubt that the international climate is serious and that the world is in danger of falling into a very extended and deep recession. But there are countries that one can point to that have been successful in controlling inflation without creating large unemployment. I refer to countries such as Austria and Japan. What Australia needs is a basic new approach to economic management; no less than that. Using unemployment to control inflation is a crime against society.

A well-known economist of my acquaintance said in private conversation some little while ago that there was no way to control inflation other than through a deep and sustained period of unemployment. The Australian Democrats reject absolutely and flatly that approach to economic management. We rejected it in 1977, at a time when it was fashionable to be a monetarist and to adopt the monetarist approach to economic management. We still reject it now when it is becoming increasingly apparent to most people that the Government's approach to economic management has to be changed, and changed quickly and urgently.

The Australian Democrats' approach to management of this economy has three basic initiatives. The creation of full employment must be the first objective; a genuine partnership between the interests of labour and capital must be the second objective and long term national indicative planning, which clearly sets out national goals so that we know when we are working in the interests of the country and the State, must be the third objective. Such long term planning is essential in the modern world. It is the only way that we can control our destiny. Those who do not plan are inevitably swamped by the tide of history. Those who do plan effectively build a dyke against which fortune beats as she will.

I well remember, in my company some 20 years ago, suggesting to my board of directors that we had to have a five-year plan. At that time the older members of the board pooh-poohed the idea. They said: 'How on earth can you plan five years ahead? Who knows what is going to happen tomorrow, or next week let alone what will happen in five years time'. Today there would not be a successful business enterprise that did not involve itself in very careful and detailed planning on an annual basis, a five-year basis or a ten-year basis. The sorts of arguments against planning that I heard in the boardroom 20 years ago are precisely those arguments that I have been hearing recently from certain sections of the Government and certain sections of the Department of the Treasury. They are worried about predicting what is likely to happen. For instance, if tomorrow Australia discovered sufficient oil to make it self- sufficient or if we discovered more oil here than there now is known to be in Saudi Arabia that would not be an excuse for not planning; it would be a reason to change the plan. We must quantify our long term objectives, we have to involve ourselves in round table discussions with vital sectors of the community and we have to continually update our plan in the light of circumstances as they occur.

In August last year the Democrats brought down an alternative Budget. At that time we said that the economy was heading down and what was needed was not a deflationary Budget but a reflationary one; the economy had to be selectively stimulated. We criticised the size of the Government's domestic surplus and said that within the confines of a balanced Budget there could be a 7 per cent increase in spending on education, health and social services. We said that personal income tax could be indexed. We suggested that a special fund should be set up for small business, that preference should be given to manufacture of our defence equipment in Australia, that home buyers should be helped and that spending on roads, public transport and sewerage should be increased by at least $100m in real terms. Above all we said that the home building industry had to be stimulated because this was one area that was efficient, Australian-owned and would respond quickly to additional government stimulation. If that had happened late last year the Government would not now be facing the problem of decreasing revenue. If the economy had been stimulated at that time we would now be seeing revenue increasing and the problem of budgetary deficits would not be occurring.

At present the rate of unemployment is running at about 7 per cent. The real rate of unemployment is probably of the order of 10 per cent. Because we have under-utilised resources, it is not unreasonable to predict that the gross national product is of the order of 10 per cent less than it could otherwise be if we had full employment. That represents an enormous amount of money, something like $20,000m. We should pause for a moment and consider the easier task that the Government would have if we were fully utilising our resources. While the economy is hampered with this 10 per cent under-utilisation of resources, in total terms it cannot be operating effectively and efficiently. Having large scale unemployment makes a mockery of productivity and increases inefficiency.

The other aspect of economic management that I refer to, a genuine partnership between the interests of labour and capital, can hardly be over-emphasised. We have an appalling industrial relations record in Australia. Senator Watson referred to the problems of a small beekeeper in Tasmania. I can only sympathise with the beekeeper. This sort of thing is happening every day of the week. We have to get a basic new approach to industrial relations. I suggest that this can only be achieved by a genuine partnership between the interests of labour and capital. Why should we not have enterprises that are partly owned by the employees? The nineteenth century confrontation between the interests of labour and capital does not have to apply indefinitely. We can get a co-operative attitude. It is amazing what can be achieved when every individual in an organisation uses his or her abilities to the maximum degree. That sort of involvement with people has got to beat a dictatorial approach by management every time. It will certainly minimise the problems of industrial relations in this country. If people were working in an industrial environment that would allow them to use their qualities of initiative, imagination, technical expertise and sociability, and if this sort of environment were engendered in our industrial enterprises, in the Public Service and in the economy generally, we would be amazed at what this country could achieve.

It is significant that the United States is now beginning to realise that the fundamental reason why the Japanese are building better and more reliable cars than are coming from Detroit is because the management of human resources in Japan is far more enlightened than it is in the United States. The United States is trying to do something about this. Alistair Cooke said on 'Letter from America' recently that he was surprised in Detroit when he saw the cream of management in that citadel of manufacturing sitting down at a seminar and being lectured by the Japanese on how they could decentralise their management and how control of their enterprises could, to a greater degree, be put in the hands of the workers. This is the new and enlightened approach; this is the approach that the Japanese have proved works. It is the approach that some of the more enlightened companies in this country have proved works. It is an approach that we in Australia have to adopt rapidly if we are to compete, if we are to avoid becoming an industrial backwater. Unless we look at the long term future, unless we worry about unemployment and unless we try to get a genuine partnership between labour and capital, this country will lumber along under the twin strains of tight money and spiralling wages. We can have a new approach. But this requires men and women of imagination and vision. In this country we need a Franklin Roosevelt to cast aside the tunnel vision of the Herbert Hoovers.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating an omnibus subject covering a number of different matters. I interpret the central core of this discussion of the matter of public importance to be economic management. It surprises me somewhat that the Australian Labor Party wants to debate economic management because, as my colleagues before me have shown-I intend to reinforce their views-the economic management of the Fraser Government since it came to office in 1975 has, on any basis, been sound and, on an international comparison , has been most impressive. On the other hand, there is no other area in which the Labor Party is so devoid of policy. For that reason, to the Australian public it lacks credibility. It criticises but offers no real alternative. We hear from the Labor Party a cry of pessimism and gloom. But its pessimism and gloom on this subject does not stand objective analysis. I invite the Senate briefly to consider an objective analysis of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development, the OECD, which, as the Senate knows, compares the economic performances of the highly developed Western nations and makes predictions as to their economic future. In its most recent publication in January this year, the OECD, on the subject of gross national product in Australia said:

speech.para: Since 1978, real GDP has increased at more than twice the average rate for the OECD area as a whole.
On unemployment, the OECD said:
. . . employment has risen strongly contrary to experience in many other Member countries.

What does it say of the future? Again, in respect of the gross national product, it forecast moderate growth over the next 18 months. That, in the current world economy, is a compliment. Its future prediction for Australia's employment figure is for a further steady increase. That is an overview of the objective analysis of independent experts. How does the OECD come to these conclusions? At least, in part, it must have looked at the statistics that are available for the last full year, 1980-81. On any interpretation they must be regarded as impressive.

I draw to the Senate's attention a number of economic indicators. The growth of the non-farm economy for 1980-81 was faster than in any year since the 1970s. The figure was approximately 4 per cent. Where does that lie in relation to the other OECD countries? According to a report put out recently by the National Westminster Bank, it put Australia at the top. There has been a 4 per cent growth as opposed to such countries as Austria which had a negative growth rate of 0.7 per cent. Belgium also had a negative growth rate of minus 0.8 per cent; Canada had a growth rate of 2.5 per cent; France had a negative growth rate of minus 0.4 per cent; Greece had a growth rate of one per cent; Italy had a negative growth rate of minus one per cent; the Netherlands had a negative growth rate of minus 0.5 per cent; New Zealand had a growth rate of 2.5 per cent ; Norway had a growth rate of one per cent; Spain had a growth rate of 1.8 per cent; Sweden had a negative growth rate of minus 0.5 per cent; Switzerland had a growth rate of one per cent; the United Kingdom had a negative growth rate of minus 2.5 per cent; the United States had a growth rate of 1.8 per cent; and West Germany had a negative growth rate of minus 1.5 per cent. Australia is at the top of the ladder. Probably no better indication could be put to the Senate of the economic management performance of this Government.

Production, employment, investment and consumer demand were all stronger in this last full year, 1980-81. Private business fixed investment grew by more than 20 per cent in real terms. As the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) said a little earlier, this was the largest growth for more than 30 years-a most impressive figure in anyone's language. Private dwelling investment continued to grow firmly with a real increase of about 11 per cent. Real wages-I repeat, real wages-rose by over 4 per cent. Real household disposable incomes rose by $2.9 billion after tax. There was a strong lift in personal consumption expenditure of about 3.25 per cent. That also is in real terms.

Total employment increased by 2.6 per cent-140,000 extra jobs. Growth in the consumer price index was kept at 9.4 per cent, which, when compared with many other countries in the OECD was above average. I draw the Senate's attention, for comparative purposes, to the inflation rate in Canada for the same year, which was 12.4 per cent. In Italy the inflation rate was 19.5 per cent, France, 13.1 per cent, Sweden, 12.1 per cent, the United Kingdom, 11.9 per cent, and the United States of America, 10.4 per cent. That is another example of how comparatively, on that major economic principle, Australia is performing soundly . As we are often reminded by the Opposition, business profits during that year grew strongly. On all of those indices the Government performed well. Do we hear the Opposition give credit for that performance in that year?

talk.start.para: —What year?

—For the year 1980-81. We hear no credit for that performance. In the current year, 1981-82, it is, of course, more difficult to obtain statistics because the year is only part-completed. The statistics that are available indicate a trend in the same direction. That is the important thing. One of the accepted guides of consumer confidence is the registration of new motor vehicles . I invite the Senate to look at the changes that are occurring in that field. Last year registrations rose by 4.54 per cent. So there was a rise in 1980-81. The latest figures reflect a continuing confidence. The seasonally adjusted figures for December were still 3.9 per cent higher than for November and 6.1 per cent higher than for the previous December.

speech.para: I will expand the argument into the subject of general retail purchases. Seasonally adjusted retail sales generally increased by 3 per cent in December and were 12 per cent higher in the December quarter 1981 than in the December quarter 1980. What of average weekly earnings? Last year they rose by 13.5 per cent-a substantial increase. That rise was budgeted to be repeated this year. Increases in the September quarter of 12.4 per cent indicate that performance is much in line with Budget. Provided that the Government can keep its inflation prediction of 10.75 per cent the result again will be a surplus in real household disposable income. The only estimates that are available for the six months to the September quarter show that a rise of 3.2 per cent is likely and that this is likely to continue.

I turn to the area of business investment. This also continues to rise. Private business gross fixed investment expanded strongly at a rate of 22.2 per cent in the six months to last September. Figures issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on 24 February this year show that during the first six months of the current financial year new fixed capital expenditure by private enterprises topped $8 billion. That was 29.3 per cent higher than for the same period in 1980-81. The Bureau survey of what businessmen plan to invest for the remainder of the financial year found that the 1981-82 total was expected to reach $16.53 billion. Obviously this is an indication that businessmen see the economic management of this Government to be more than satisfactory. A good indication of the state of the economy is always overseas confidence in the economy. The figures just released for the December quarter last year show an increase of $ 498m above that of the previous quarter.

On the basis of the figures I have mentioned Australia is in an economically sound position. As an economic manager, the Government has a successful record. That does not mean that we do not see problems. We recognise the problems and we move to find remedies. The OECD sees our main economic concern, in both the short and the medium term, as inflation. But again the Organisation gives credit to the Government. It said in the report to which I referred earlier, the one published in January this year, that the current stance of macro-economic policy seems the only possible way to cope with the containment of inflation in the immediate future. In the longer term it suggests that we need to look at both our protection policy and our wage determination system. In other words, it says that we must moderate protection and restrain wage increases if we are to continue to control inflation and cope with the major economic problem that faces us. That is the policy of the Government. Yet this Government is condemned for that. The Labor Party advocates greater protection and criticises us in our attempts to restrain wages. It is no wonder the Labor Government was able to achieve an inflation rate in 1974 of around 16.4 per cent. Yet today Opposition members are determined to criticise us for an inflation rate which, as I stated, is so substantially lower.

The Government accepts unemployment as a problem. Although our economic policies have played a part in the creation of 102,200 new jobs in the last 12 months to January and 242,200 jobs in the last two years to January-they are figures that should not be forgotten-we as a government accept that the rate of unemployment remains too high. However, no solution to overcoming that problem that is put forward anywhere in the world is better than the Australian approach of creating a climate for strong economic growth. It is interesting to note the endorsement we received at the recent meeting of OCED Employment Ministers held in Paris only a fortnight ago. They decided, as it has been reported, that efforts to combat unemployment could be successful only in the framework of competent and effective anti-inflationary policy. Again I remind the Senate that that is the policy of this Government. Those Ministers also said that unions and employers should realise the importance of wage restraint in the current circumstances. This Government, as opposed to the Opposition, recognises that. Under this Government Australia has been able to swim against the tide of international economic adversity. That has been primarily due to the sound economic management of its government. This is a record of economic management that is applauded throughout the world. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.title: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —The States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill 1982 which is before the Senate amends the revenue sharing arrangements contained in the principal Act, which was introduced last year to account for revisions in the assumed population numbers in several States and one Territory. It lists also the amounts which will be paid to the States and the Northern Territory during the financial year 1981-82 after the passage of this Bill. This Bill is not opposed by the Opposition.

speech.para: I think it is fair to note that the major decision relating both to the aggregate payments and to the relativities between the states for this financial year came from the infamous Premiers Conference of June 1981, after which it will be recalled the Treasurer (Mr Howard), at the bidding of the Prime Minister (Mr Fraser), leaked boastful statements about conning the Premiers out of the $ 70m that the Government had been otherwise willing to give them and he effectively said to the media: 'The Premiers are a bunch of mugs and we are very macho, tough and clever operators'. The only time that the Treasurer has been in real trouble in his political career was when he was doing the Prime Minister's dirty work. I think he has learned a lesson from that and he will decline from doing the Prime Minister's dirty work in future. It is the last time he will take the rap for Mr Fraser. Since then he has backed away from Mr Fraser's unpopularity-no doubt he has good personal and political reasons for that-just as Sir Phillip Lynch did a couple of weeks ago.

The aggregate increase in funds to the States will be 9 per cent over 1980-81, a year in which the consumer price index, on the Government's own forecasts, will increase by 10.75 per cent and wages will probably increase by something of the order of 13 per cent. Wages are a more accurate indicator of State governments' financial needs than the consumer price index because wages comprise such a very large part of State governments' total expenditure. Either way there is a very significant squeeze in real terms on the States. I might add that in the same year Commonwealth tax collections from pay-as-you-earn taxpayers will increase by 22 per cent and payments to the States will rise by 9 per cent.

We have just finished debating a matter of public importance on the series of promises made and subsequently broken by this Government and the false expectations raised by those promises. The award for the most spectacular raising of false expectations among the States would, of course, have to go to Senator Sir John Carrick. He was asked, on 27 April 1976, whether he would guarantee, pursuant to a statement he had made the day before, that total payments to the States in real terms would increase by more than 57 per cent in the following three years as they had in the previous three years. He replied: ' My answer is an unqualified yes'. In 1976 Senator Sir John Carrick gave an unqualified guarantee that real payments to the States would increase by 57 per cent.
