Far from increasing by 57 per cent in real terms total payments have slightly declined.

Despite all the spectacular promises contained in the federalism policy and the false expectations raised by those promises from 1976 right through to mid-1981, in nearly all States in nearly all years the floor on payments to the States was that provided for by the Whitlam formula-the formula much reviled by the State Premiers and governments and, of course, by Mr Fraser and the Liberal Party in Federal Opposition. This year the squeeze has been intensified with this increase in payments of only 9 per cent in a year when the consumer price index is expected to increase by nearly 11 per cent and wages by around 13 per cent.

The aggregate entitlement of the States for future years is established as being the proportion of total Commonwealth tax revenues, not just income tax revenue, provided for in this Bill. On the vexed question of relativities, sharpened by the release of the Commonwealth Grants Commission report in the middle of last year, this Bill marks time, as was observed by Ralph Willis in the House of Representatives. That question has been shoved into the too-hard basket for the next 12 months.

talk.start.para: —What is the Labor Party's view on that?
—On relativities?
—No, on the report that came down last year?

—When the report came out last year I made some criticism on the public record of some of the assumptions contained in the report. I was about to come to that. Honourable senators opposite will probably be surprised by what I am about to say. I have absolutely no sympathy for this Government when the Premiers and the State governments revile it and complain about its promises to them, which it has broken in the aggregate. The Government has not come good on the false expectations raised by Mr Fraser and most spectacularly, of course, by Senator Sir John Carrick. However, I have a good deal of sympathy for any national government on the separate question of the relativities between the States. No matter what a national government does there will be complaints from some States, or even from all States, that they have been treated unfairly vis-a -vis some other State. That is independent of the general and unanimous complaint about the total level of funds not being high enough. State governments have rarely been averse to spending any amount of money which a Commonwealth Government would provide.

speech.para: On this question the Commonwealth is certainly in a no win position. No matter what it does it will get complaints from some States, or even all States, about the relative share of the total amount which has been more or less arbitrarily determined by the Commonwealth will be distributed to the States. I do not think there is any easy solution to that problem. I am sometimes tempted by the thought that the Commonwealth should invite the States to reach mutual agreement on the relativities or, if they cannot reach unanimous agreement, at least to make some majority decision and submit it to the Commonwealth. However, I suspect that we would have to lock up the State Premiers in a padded cell without food or water for a considerable time before such an agreement would emerge. That, I concede, is an area in which even some of the present Commonwealth Government's more vigorous critics could have a certain amount of sympathy for it, although I might add that the magnitude and intensity of its problems are partly the product of its own failure to deliver what it has promised-quite irresponsibly. I cannot imagine a more irresponsible promise from a Minister in even this Government than that made by Senator Sir John Carrick on 27 April 1976; that is, that in real terms total payments to the States would be increased by more than 57 per cent in three years.

The other general criticism which I want to make of the Government's policy over the last six years towards funding the States is that for reasons of political expediency it has squeezed the capital expenditure areas much harder than it has squeezed the recurrent expenditure areas. The reasons for that, of course, is that the effects of a neglect of capital expenditure take a good deal longer to become apparent to the electorate than do the effects of reductions in recurrent expenditure. In this area, as in so many other areas, this Government and its Prime Minister, despite their bold rhetoric about taking unpopular decisions and behaving in a statesmanlike way, have behaved as political opportunists to the long term sorrow and damage of the nation.

speech.speaker: Hamer Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: —The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 to provide, firstly, for the payment of additional tax sharing grants and special allocations totalling $69m to New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland and, secondly, the payment of a fixed tax sharing grant of $315m to the Northern Territory. At the Premiers Conference last June at which the Commonwealth Grants Commission report on State tax sharing entitlements was considered it was decided that there would be no change in the relativities contained in the Act in respect of the year 1981-82 and it was agreed to ask the Commission to produce another report on the assessment of State relativities in the light of further submissions put to it by States and by the Commonwealth. The Commission is expected to report by 31 May this year. Because of the likelihood-I would say the certainty-that following this further review the States' relativities will be adjusted in favour of the three most populous States, including Victoria, it was agreed at that Premiers Conference to provide additional grants of $24.5m to New South Wales, $15m to Victoria and $20.5m to Queensland in 1981-82. This Bill implements that agreement. It goes some way towards redressing the disadvantage, perhaps the injustice, which Victorians have suffered for some years under the previous formula for tax sharing grants.

speech.para: Victorians pay the highest income tax per capita and the State Government receives the lowest amount per capita of all the States. There is an extraordinary tendency at the moment for people to knock Victoria including, I must admit, some Victorians. Victoria should not be knocked. Let us look at what we have in Victoria. We have the highest per capita income in Australia. We have the lowest unemployment rate of any State in Australia. We have by far the most valuable single mining venture in Australia-Bass Strait oil-which incidentally provides $3 billion a year to the Federal Government, much of which is distributed to other States. We have the most modern container port in the world . We have the largest general cargo port in Australia. We have the best roads and rail network in Australia. We have by far the best metropolitan public transport system. I was astonished in Melbourne the other day to see someone going around with a car sticker which read: 'I am the owner of the worst public transport system in the world'. He is one of the most ignorant people I have ever seen. In fact, we have by far the best in Australia. If he had travelled the world he would have realised that we have one of the best in the world. We have enormous assets because of our central position.

How has this been done? It has been done partly through the highly efficient management of the State of Victoria over many years. It has also been done by the State Government, in the areas where State governments can impose taxes, imposing nearly the highest rate of income tax of any State in Australia. That is, I submit, unfair to Victorians. We have heard-sometimes with irritation- other States boasting about how they are not using the types of tax that the Victorian Government finds necessary. We feel, and I think justly, that those States are able to do that only because of the subsidy granted by Victoria to them which enables them to get away with lower taxes. This Bill is starting the process of redressing that imbalance. I am sure that when the Grants Commission reports next May it will go further to correct the situation and that the inquiry into health grants will do the same. Victoria will get more revenue, justly, out of Commonwealth reimbursements. This will achieve a great measure of financial fairness. What we have done and what we have achieved in Victoria up to date is quite remarkable. All the knockers should stop knocking. Victoria is the greatest State in the Commonwealth and will continue to go from strength to strength.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —in reply-I thank honourable senators who have contributed to this debate for the general support they have given to the propositions before the Senate. The States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill is a Bill to provide additional grants to the States. Without the passage of this Bill through the Parliament the States would be worse off to the extent of $70m. So to that extent it is a Bill which is conferring benefits upon the States and is a further example of the determination of the Federal Government to assist the States wherever possible. The figure contained in the Bill was settled at the June 1981 Premiers Conference and was contained in a Press statement released after that Conference. Further reference to the formula which is to be used is contained in Budget Paper No. 7, which came out with the last Budget, which covers the subject and which gives in detail the formula by which the different calculations concerning the States will be made.

speech.para: The only point that requires specific reply is that raised by Senator Walsh. It was really a throw-away point. He mentioned that the increase for the States was only 9 per cent while inflation was running at a higher level. I am advised that if we take the 9 per cent increase and look at additional grants which are being made to the States, including grants covered by this amendment, the Bill gives an increase of around 11 per cent. The Commonwealth Government can say that it has kept faith with the States in terms of reimbursement. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
SOCIAL SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982)
Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: —This Bill has come into the Senate for the third time. It has twice been rejected in this place and in reintroducing it the Government has given no grounds for treating it differently on this occasion. The second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), in setting out the purpose of the Bill, stated:

speech.para: . . . for so long as a person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of involvement in industrial action; or unwillingness to undertake suitable work; or failure to take reasonable steps to obtain such work, that person will also be ineligible for unemployment benefit. Additionally, a person will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to the person's spouse is postponed because of their misconduct as a worker; because they have become voluntarily unemployed; or because they have failed to accept an offer of suitable employment.

Not even the Minister's first description of the Bill is honest. The word ' involvement' is deliberately misleading. Involvement, by the Minister's definition, includes people thousands of miles away in the same union who have been laid off by a dispute of which they have no knowledge or information. This subjective use of language extends to the spouses of those whose benefits are postponed because of misconduct or voluntary unemployment; both reasons being the results of subjective judgments and different interpretations in different offices of the Department of Social Security throughout this country.

It is a Bill which is firstly an attack not just on the families of strikers, as it claims, but also on the families of all trade union members. It is designed to turn belonging to a trade union into a personal liability. As I said , even if a unionist lived thousands of miles away from an industrial dispute and was completely ignorant of the fact that one had occurred, if his factory closed down as a result of the dispute, the fact that he had trade union membership would stop his family claiming social service benefits. If he was not in a union he and his family would be all right. It is the fact that he is a union member that draws the Government's fire. This is not social services legislation; it is a Bill intended to weaken trade unions and trade union membership without entirely forbidding their existence. This legislation comes from a government which weeps crocodile tears about the rights of Polish workers . I will in general refer to a trade unionist as 'he', although of course the legislation applies equally to women unionists with unemployed spouses. It has, however, been labelled by several Ministers and the Press as a Bill affecting the wives of strikers. The Minister has been tediously trotting out examples of payments to wives of unionists in dispute in assorted isolated mining towns to back up his emotional rhetoric, trying to identify these families in the Australian work force as enemies of our society.

The second feature of this Bill is a further restriction on the unemployed so that the spouse of an unemployed person who is stopped from receiving unemployment benefit for between six and 12 weeks cannot herself-or himself- receive social service benefits during that time at the single rate or their children receive the allowances normally paid to the children of those on unemployment benefit. Both features of this Bill, as they apply to the families of union members and the families of persons allegedly failing the work test or becoming voluntarily unemployed, are extensions of similar vindictive legislation passed by this Government in 1979.

I turn to the industrial action provisions of this Bill. The Minister has claimed that he is not discussing the merits of strike action, yet almost every word of his second reading speech is devoted to categorising strike action as an assault against the community, the taxpayer and the law. He states that the Government will not be swayed by what he calls emotional and misleading arguments which direct attention from the Government's fundamental concern. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that he has not heard such arguments in this chamber. He has heard a reasoned case based firstly on the premise that membership of a trade union should not be a punishable offence, and secondly on the strong belief of everyone on this side of the chamber that wives and children should not suffer because this Government, which has so mishandled the economy, is determined to put the screws on two of its favourite scapegoats-the trade unions and the unemployed. We hear continuously in this chamber, in another place and outside the Parliament, rhetoric about the evils of trade unionism and statements about the unwillingness of the unemployed to work. It was this Government which dredged up the term 'dole bludger'. It was this Government whose former Treasurer told the people of this country that unemployment was a myth. Those are empty words after all these years.

Because the Government continues to raise the question of the payment of unemployment benefit to spouses in isolated mining communities, let me deal with it now. Workers in isolated mining communities, if married, are in a family situation in which that family is totally dependent on the money the miner brings in. Only their union membership puts them in any kind of bargaining situation with their employers. If we are talking about mining companies in this country, we are talking, in the main, about overseas owners who direct their work practices towards maximising profits, not necessarily towards towards economic justice. The families in general cannot have a second income, for there are few jobs for women in these male dominated communities. Throughout Australia 21.5 per cent of married women are in the work force. Excluding older women who have never worked and younger women with very small children, most married women take jobs if they can find them for a great part of their working lives. A good many Australian families would find it impossible to have home ownership and an adequate living standard without that second income.

But this Bill does not attack the two-income family unless the partners are unluckily members of the same union. The two-income family has a backstop if one spouse is getting no pay during an industrial dispute, although it notices the financial chill. It certainly notices the drop in income which occurs with the loss of one income during industrial disputation. The single-income family with a working husband and non-working wife, the ideological favourites of this Government in the family stakes, has no such backstop. We are continuously told about the concern of this Government for the single-income family. This is legislation which says to that family: 'If you want to stay alive in the rough and tumble of a strike, give up your union membership'. I have no doubt that if the man's job had been in metropolitan or regional areas where work is available a good many of the households which Senator Chaney is complaining about would have had two incomes and therefore would have been ineligible for unemployment benefit on income grounds.

The Minister wants the wives and families penalised when they have no access to other paid work in their small towns and in their settlements or in company towns in the mining areas of this country of ours. He refers to them as having ' no genuine intention' of joining the work force. I suggest that this is a totally unsubstantiated statement. To say that they should apply, though they know there is little chance of being offered employment, is one thing, but they are realists who know that if they are offered a job and refuse it they will not pass the work test. To say that they will not accept work if it is offered is to make an unwarranted assertion and is an unnecessary slur on such women in these communities and is unworthy of the Minister and the Government.

The Minister knows that most of the figures he has produced-and I dare say will produce again in this debate-are from company towns where there is only one employer and essentially only one industry. He wants to withdraw all economic assistance from the family of a worker in a company town where that worker is engaged, whether willingly or unwillingly, in industrial action or is affected by industrial action in another company or even in another State. The Minister has absolutely no knowledge of how many wives or spouses of striking or stood- down unionists receive unemployment benefit during any year. He admitted that ignorance in an answer to a question on notice last December. He has simply taken out what he sees as dramatic figures for disputes in isolated areas to reinforce this prejudice against unionists.

I would like to recall for the Senate some figures I cited last November in the second reading debate on this Bill. In 1980, 65 per cent of all industrial disputes lasted two days or less, involving 79 per cent of all workers; that is, only 21 per cent of strikers were involved in disputes lasting longer than two days. Only 8.9 per cent of all strikers were involved in disputes that lasted 10 days or longer. It is worth remembering that unemployment benefit is obtainable only after a 7-day waiting period. The major causes of disputes in the statistics I cited were directly attributable to management. In 39.7 per cent of the disputes, managerial policy was given as the prime cause and in 19.6 per cent of the disputes, physical working conditions were given as the cause. Only 21.5 per cent of the disputes were about wages. Senator chaney, in his second reading speech which was incorporated in Hansard, referred to union members choosing to strike. He stated:
. . . knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions.

He also referred to the absurdity of any argument that benefits should be paid to strikers or their families. I would like to point out how little the families are, in fact, insulated from the consequences of industrial action as things now stand. If a worker is taking part in an industrial dispute, willingly or unwillingly, or is stood down for a period in which unemployment benefit is normally payable, his family loses considerably. I instance a family where the breadwinner is on average weekly earnings. In the present situation where the wife can claim unemployment benefit at the single rate, her entitlement is $69. 70 for two people, or 21.6 per cent of the income to which that family is accustomed. That couple will be down $254.50 a week. If there are children in the family, the couple will be entitled to $99.70 a week for five people or 30.9 per cent of their accustomed income; a drop of $225.50 a week. The present legislation will reduce their income to nothing.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before the suspension of the sitting I pointed out that this legislation is, in fact, aimed at trade unionists, aimed at those whom the Government is trying to use in its propaganda in trying to convince the community that our economic woes are due to the small group of people who are involved in industrial disputes. The sad thing is that the legislation is aimed primarily at single-income families; two-income families are not affected. This policy is, in fact, a substitute for a lack of an industrial relations policy. The examples that the Minister for Social Security has used-I dare say he will use them again tonight-were, of course, particular isolated cases of people in company towns with no other recourse to income. I pointed out the difficulties that those people will face if this legislation comes into effect.

speech.para: Of course, the Minister will point out that-we all admit this-there are hardship grounds for the receipt of special benefit under this legislation. There are, in fact, very severe criteria. Half the applications for special benefit by workers' wives during the recent coal strike at Maitland were rejected because those applying had money in excess of $300 in the bank. Under this legislation a family of five could get nothing until its money in the bank got down to $300; then they would be given a weekly payment of only $99.70, whether or not they were party to the industrial action.

The second reading speech states that there is no good reason why the community should automatically and immediately be expected to assume through unemployment or special benefit payment 'the normal financial responsibilities' of people who are not willing to work. The Opposition proclaims that the community does not expect innocent people to go into penury to appease the prejudices of the Government and its conservative supporters. By no stretch of the imagination can a social services payment of $99.70 a week to a family of five be called assuming that family's normal financial responsibilities. By no stretch of the imagination can stood-down unionists in another workshop or another industry whose families would suffer by this legislation be called people who are unwilling to work. They are people who, being caught up in an industrial conflict not of their own making, are being victimised because they are trade union members. If they are not trade union members they are not affected.

I now give some actual examples of families in Victoria affected by the legislation of 1979 and leave it to honourable senators with some imagination to envisage how such families will get on if this Bill is passed. I give first of all the example of a couple whom we will call Mr and Mrs N. In fact they are Vietnamese refugees in their late twenties with two pre-school-age children. Mr N. is employed by Carlton and United Breweries Ltd and was involved in a two- week strike late in 1980. At that time the family had been in Australia for only five months and Mr N. had been working for approximately six weeks. The family had recently shifted into private sector accommodation from a migrant hostel with all the expenses such a move entails and consequently with no savings to fall back on. As well as the normal commitments of rent, food, gas and electricity, they were giving support to other members of the family still living in a refugee camp overseas. The dispute caused a total and unexpected loss of income which placed great financial stress on the family and led to considerable anxiety. By the time the strike was settled Mr and Mrs N. had fallen $140 behind in their rent.

The Department of Social Security referred the family to a voluntary agency for financial assistance. The agency was able to give the family $60 in relief money out of its limited emergency relief funds and negotiated with the landlord regarding payment of overdue rent. The wife applied for unemployment benefit for herself and the children but no payment was ever made although she theoretically was eligible for benefit for the second week of the dispute. Once Mr N. was back at work the family did not want to pursue the claim for unemployment benefit, preferring to put its energies into making up lost earnings. It should be noted that the maximum payment of unemployment benefit to this family would have amounted to $89.70 once the seven-day waiting period had been served.

Mr and Mrs A. are a young Turkish couple in their early twenties who live with their baby in a tiny flat for which they pay $55 a week in rent. The husband is employed at the Ford Company's Broadmeadows plant as a production line worker and earns approximately $165 a week nett. Apart from the rental commitment of $ 220 a month, paid in advance, the family expends approximately $60 a week on food, $10 a week on gas and electricity and $10 a week on petrol. The family car is used for transport to and from work. The family has no telephone and nothing on hire purchase. Once the family has met its basic commitments roughly $35 a week remains to meet all other family needs. It is virtually imposible for the family to save any part of this amount and it is generally spent on things for the baby, clothing, cleaning materials, et cetera. Mr A. was involved in a six- week dispute at Ford. I remind honourable senators that that is an unusual length for a dispute, even in this country. He and his wife had paid a month's rent just prior to the dispute and sought assistance from their local community health centre only when they were faced with gas and electricity bills which they could not pay. They had $3 a week when they made that approach.

Their friends, Mr and Mrs Z, were in similar circumstances except that they did not have a car. In this case the husband had been stood down because of the dispute but was no better off than his work mates since he was a member of the same union and was deemed ineligible for benefit. In both cases the family situation could have been improved if the wives had been able to obtain unemployment or special benefit on their own behalf and on behalf of their children--

talk.start.para: —He belonged to the same union?

—He belonged to the same union. The wives would have been able to obtain roughly $79.70 a week-roughly one-third of the gross salary which their husbands would normally have earned. Neither woman received any payment from the Department of Social Security although both were willing to work. At the end of the dispute both families were facing eviction and both had commitments for fuel bills which were difficult to meet.

speech.para: These couples and other couples which have been drawn to my attention by the Australian Council of Trade Unions had pay of about $160 a week-hardly a payment which enables a family to accumulate savings. Nor would, I suggest, such families likely jeopardise their earnings to go on to social services payments. They would not take part in industrial action, as it is so charmingly put, in the second reading speech, 'frivolously or maliciously'. In fact, since the 1979 punitive changes to this legislation I believe it is the Government which is malicious in treating stood-down unionists as though they were active participants in a strike, and more so in this Bill in putting their families, their wives and children, at risk as well.

As I have remarked before, and as the Minister tries to state, there is no deep division between taxpayers and trade unionists in this country. Trade unionists are workers who pay taxes, who pay pay-as-you-earn taxes and, as we know, that group of taxpayers is shouldering an increasing share of the tax burden in this country. They are taxpayers who generally take prolonged union action only when industrial conditions-do not let us forget that twice as many working days are lost through work injuries as are lost through industrial disputes-force them to take action or they believe they have no other redress. They are willing to make sacrifies for principles, safety, or economic justice, despite what the Minister thinks.

The community is, of course, inconvenienced by some disputes, but other disputes actually benefit the community if they result in better safety measures and end exploitation of some categories of workers. Of course, the Minister gives the example of those people who take industrial action and, as a result of that industrial action, receive increases in wages or improved conditions from the day on which they took the industrial action. He complains that it is most unfair that their wives and their children should get the basic payments that his Department provides. Of course, in that situation the unionists were right and if anyone should pay back to the community the costs of the unemployment benefits and the meagre payments that are available to their wives and children, it should be either the Government, which frequently prolongs industrial disputes in this country, or the companies which prolong those disputes.

I now turn to the provisions of this Bill which would deny unemployment benefit to spouses of unemployed persons who, in the view of the Department, have walked out of jobs, have lost their jobs through misconduct or have failed the work test by turning down work offered to them. Senator Chaney in his speech made this remark:
This Bill prevents them from manipulating the social security system to shift the consequences of their actions.

Nothing points out better the wealth of prejudice of the Minister and his colleagues than that statement. I point out that it comes from a government which condones record amounts of tax evasion in this country. First of all, it is worth while pointing out that the Department of Social Security is all too often highhanded in its judgment on these matters. Only a small proportion of persons taken off social security benefits appeal against the Department's decision to terminate their benefits, but the most recent figures that the Minister has given me show that over half the appeals against the Department succeed. In 1980-81 the Department made wrong decisions in over half of those cases. I suggest that that is not a good record. If the Department cannot have a better record, I am not happy about allowing the Department of Social Security to decide that not only those unemployed persons who have their benefits stopped for six to 12 weeks should receive no benefits but also that their spouses and their children should not receive such benefits. The number of people who were deprived of benefit because they refused employment last year was only 500 out of the 782,000 who were granted it. They represent only 0.6 per cent of the determinations. I suggest that this is hardly a blight on our society and that it hardly deserves the emphasis that it gets from Government spokesmen in this place.

Many of the women who will be affected by this section of the legislation are in fact married to persons who have psychological problems, drinking problems which may not be obvious or emotional problems which put them in situations in which they are likely to be considered to be out of work through misconduct or voluntary action when they are seen by officers of the Department of Social Security. These are the sorts of people who may abuse a foreman or boss in anger or who throw in their jobs on the spur of the moment in times of stress. Not only these people but also their wives and children will be deprived of benefits under this legislation and will receive assistance only if they can comply with the very strict criteria which the Department applies to people seeking special benefits, criteria which vary from office to office of the Department and from State to State.

Are we, as a Senate and as a Parliament, seriously suggesting that a wife and her children should suffer through being married to such a person? Are we saying to her that she should leave him to get social security benefits and thus worsen the situation for him and, in many cases, for her and her children? The Government has given no thought to the complex interpersonal relationships which lie behind this group of the unemployed. To satisfy the crude prejudice of the Government and of some of the Government's supporters, the Government will throw these people on the scrapheap. We believe very sincerely that the Government should think again about this matter. This is a further reason why we will oppose this Bill.

This legislation, I repeat, is in fact aimed at trade unionists in the first place. It is aimed, secondly, at a group of unemployed who, as a result of subjective judgment by public servants, by officers of the Department of Social Security, are deemed to have voluntarily become unemployed, to have lost their jobs through misconduct or not to have sought work properly; in other words, to have failed the work test. They are too often subject to moral judgments by public servants. I suggest that people who seek to be in a position to make such moral judgments are in fact the last people who should be given a right.

talk.start.para: —That is hardly fair, is it?

—I do not think that is unfair at all. People who seek to make moral judgments and seek to sit in moral judgment on their fellow men and women, I believe, are probably the last people who should be given that right. I contend that that is so. I make the final point that of those few people who do appeal against the bureaucracy, which is not an easy thing to do in this country , over 50 per cent succeed; in other words, the Department has been wrong. This is an amendment to the social services legislation which has nothing to do with social services. It has to do with the Government's lack of an industrial relations policy. It has to do with the Government's prejudice against trade unions. It has to do, in fact, with the Government's prejudice against those in this community who it sees as being unfit to receive benefits such as the unemployment benefit. We have rejected it twice before. I suggest the Senate should continue to reject it, despite the rhetoric and despite the threats by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that this is a piece of double dissolution legislation. We should continue to reject it.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: —We are presently debating the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982). The purpose of this Bill is to prevent the spouse of a person who is involved in industrial action from getting unemployment benefit. It is the third time this Bill has been brought before the Senate. On the two previous occasions the Opposition failed to pass it. On those occasions Senator Haines spoke in an emotional fashion and said that some unions were irresponsible and some unionists were irresponsible, but that that was no reason for governments to be irresponsible. She claimed that the Government was acting irresponsibly in bringing forward this Bill, even though it is protecting the taxpayers' dollar. Senator Grimes said that the intention of the Government is to make belonging to trade unions a liability. Of course, that is a lot of rot. The Government is very supportive of moderate trade unionists and has never been otherwise. We are more than a little concerned about the Halfpennys, the Carmichaels and Gallaghers, and the Opposition is not. We recently debated in this place the interim report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It was pretty obvious on that occasion that the Opposition did everything possible to support the painters and dockers.
—That is an outrageous statement and you know it.

—I will explain why I said that. The interim report on the painters and dockers which was brought down in this place discussed four areas investigated by that Royal Commission. One area was tax evasion, the next was the gross abuse of social services by painters and dockers, another was the gross abuse of workers compensation by painters and dockers, and another was the intimidation, violence and coercion by painters and dockers. Senator Button, the only speaker for the Opposition on that occasion, spoke about tax evasion only. He said not one word about social service abuse, not one word about the violence and corruption in that union and not one word about the abuse of workers' compensation. He spoke only about tax evasion. He said that because the Government taxed people to such a high extent painters and dockers resorted to tax evasion. If Senator Grimes does not believe that that is supporting the painters and dockers, the Australian public certainly would.

speech.para: Let us have a look at the extent of industrial action by some of the more radical unions in Australia today. In the week ending 27 November 1981 we had 153 strikes; in the week ending 19 February 1982 we had 112 strikes and in the week ending 5 March this year we had 86 strikes. We had 153 strikes in one week. I think it is fair to say that not all of those strikes went for a long time but many strikes go on for months. If anyone is interested, I can table the relevant document. As I have said, the majority of union members look after themselves during strikes. The legislation before the Senate really applies to prolonged strikes only. Let us remember a few things. Firstly, a person has a choice about going on strike.

talk.start.para: —That is rubbish.

—Senator McIntosh says 'rubbish' and the last time this legislation was debated Senator Haines also said 'rubbish'. Some time ago certain legislation was passed in this parliament and, indeed it has been acted upon many times in this country when members of unions have refused to go on strike. Honourable Senators will remember the national strike that Bob Hawke called about Medibank. Many unionists refused that call and worked through the strike. It was a complete fizzer, a complete debacle. In this country a striker has a choice and it is up to him to make it. Sometimes it is a difficult choice to make. If an employee belongs to such unions as the Builders Labourers Federation or the Painters and Dockers Union he must have a fair calibre of character to go against decisions made by those unions.

speech.para: In this country we have a conciliation and arbitration system and that should effectively stop all prolonged strikes. But the militant unionists will not abide by the decisions that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission brings down. Of course employers must abide by them and indeed they do. They do not lock out their unionists. If radical unions do not like a decision made by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commision they say 'No, we are going to continue this strike' and they do. I believe that we have reached the stage in this country where people demand that unionists are responsible for the actions they take. Many people-and indeed members of the Opposition-are asking this Government for tax cuts. Tax cuts can come only as a result of cutting government expenditure. There is no other way that this responsible Government is willing to do it. Of course the last Labor Government printed money. That was its way of giving the people what they thought the people wanted in terms of handouts. The Labor Government also had tremendously large deficits and borrowed from sleazy overseas countries.

talk.start.para: —They didn't borrow. That is a complete untruth and you know it. They didn't borrow from overseas. Stick to the facts.

—The Labor Government attempted to borrow money and to leave a legacy to our grandchildren that they would never have paid off. Tonight we have been accused in this chamber of creating extreme hardship for families of striking workers. Senator Grimes brought tears to our eyes when he talked of alcoholic husbands and husbands who had tempers which made them liable to throw something at their boss and so lose their job. Tonight we have been told of wives and families of these husbands going without. That is a complete falsehood . Anyone who has followed this legislation would know that we have made arrangements for families in extreme hardship to be able to claim special benefits. Of course to a large extent this has been ignored in speeches from the Opposition side.

speech.para: This Bill does not prohibit strikes. What it does do is stop enforced payment by the taxpayer for those people who are causing the taxpayer such difficulties. I believe that the Opposition is suggesting that we subsidise strikes. Do not tell me someone who is on strike should be able to put his hand out to the Government. If honourable senators opposite say that it is the striker's wife and children who will suffer, do they mean that the wife will not feed him? Of course he gets some of the money. So he would be putting out his hand to the taxpayer and thus receive a subsidy and enable the strike to be prolonged. As I have said, we have seen that the taxpayer is absolutely fed up with being abused by strikes in this country. We have seen marches; we have seen thousands of people assemble in Sydney and Melbourne. (Quorum formed). The thousands of people who congregated in the streets of Melbourne and Sydney showed their displeasure, their distaste for the inconveniences that they were forced to put up with.

I ask members of the Opposition-indeed, I ask the Australian Democrats-whether they would be prepared to introduce a levy to force taxpayers to pay for prolonged strikes. Would they be prepared to face the people and say: 'We are willing to introduce a levy this week so that every time we have a strike over a week's duration you will put your hand in your pocket to help those poor strikers maintain their family finances'? I think they would get pretty short shrift if they tried that. Suppose they asked the Tasmanian honey producer that Senator Watson talked about a little while ago who had his honey export produce sitting on the wharves for three months. I wonder how happy he would be to put his hand in his pocket to supply the levy for the Opposition. Would industries in New South Wales be prepared to contribute to a levy should the Opposition be game to carry forward its suggestion that taxpayers should pay for this?

talk.start.para: —It is hard when you only work a four-day week.

—I was going to say that the members of the moderate unions of New South Wales could now well lose $70 a week out of their pay packets simply because they are being forced to work a four-day week. I wonder whether they will be prepared to put their hands in their pockets. I wonder whether they would appreciate it if it were noted on their taxation forms that the Government took X-number of dollars out of their pay packets to pay for the people who are on strike. I wonder whether the Labor Opposition would be prepared to ask them to foot the bill. What happens with the families in Sydney who are, at present, facing blackouts? We have been lead to believe that they will be able only to use two lights in their homes in the coming weeks and that there will be regional blackouts. They will be able only to use two hotplates on their stoves and not all of their appliances. Perhaps we could consult Mr Wran. He may be interested in putting up a levy. He might be prepared to say to the people: 'You people, put your hands in your pockets and pay for these people who are on strike. After all, that will encourage these people to hold even more prolonged strikes.' Mr Wran may even put his hand in his pocket and fish out a dollar or two.

speech.para: This is all rubbish. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats know that if they had to put on the taxation forms how much each taxpayer had to pay to support these strikers they would get no support whatsoever from the taxpayer. This Government is at least trying to protect the wages earned by the Australian people and to limit the taxes that they have to pay. We have found that most strikes are held to encourage extra wage demands and better conditions. Let us consider the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd. As a result of intimidation by its workers it has had to grant them a 38-hour week. We know only too well what the result of that will be. It will result in more expensive cars. The people will, once again, be down the drain. They will be paying more for their cars. Actually , the union representative said: 'Yes, it will result in more expense for this company. We will see what we can do to help, but we do want our 38-hour week'. If the people are asked also to pay for the strike that brought about that 38- hour week then I think the people of Australia will let the Opposition know how they feel.

It is time, I believe, as I said earlier, that the Australian people accepted responsibility for their own actions. This Bill also applies to the spouses of people who are not willing to earn. Again, I have no problem at all in this area . If people want to live the alternate lifestyle, if they do not want to work, if they want to go out in the bush and support themselves off the land and not accept any of the facilities for which the taxpayer pays, then I am all for them ; I am on their side. If they are not willing to work or to make themselves available for work then they should not put out their hands for money from people who are working. That is not justice and this Government will not have a bar of it. Of course, the unemployment benefit is available to people who cannot get jobs. Unfortunately, there are many such people in Australia today. Anyone who is legitimately looking for work has no problems about getting the unemployment benefit. They, their wives and their children are supported by the taxpayers, and supported willingly. There is no problem there at all.

Senator Haines will be introducing an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill. This amendment reveals quite strange thinking. It will prohibit payment of benefits to spouses of strikers for two weeks-not one week, but two weeks. That seems to me to be rather illogical. I do not understand the thinking behind it. We have been told by the Australian Democrats that it is cruel not to give the unemployment benefit to spouses of strikers. But, of course, they are willing to take away the unemployment benefit for two weeks. It seems to me that that will end up as a bonus to those unionists who intend to strike for three weeks, If they strike for two weeks they will not get anything but if they strike for three weeks they will get a bonus. If they strike for four weeks they will also do all right. It is no good for strikers to strike for two weeks. It seems that this will be an encouragement. It seems that the Australian Democrats agree in principle that it is not a good thing to give the unemployment benefit to the wives of strikers otherwise they would not be suggesting that this benefit be withheld at all. So they obviously agree in principle but they think it would be nice to give them a bonus if they strike a little longer. Senator Grimes made some extraordinary statements.

talk.start.para: —He always does.

—Yes, he usually makes one or two clangers. He said that the Government prolongs strikes. According to him it is never a confrontation. ( Quorum formed). I was saying that Senator Grimes made a few extraordinary statements tonight. He said that the Government causes strikes. It is never the unionists who act in a confrontationist manner who cause strikes. He says that the Government prolongs strikes and therefore the Government should pay for them . Senator Grimes said that the Government should pay because it prolongs the strikes. He reminds me of a story that he may well remember.
—Tell us the story.

—Let me tell the story. It happened at a Senate Standing Committee hearing. I think Senator Grimes was present on that occasion. Some women were giving evidence and suggesting that we should double this, treble that and quadruple something else.
—Was that a public hearing?

—It was a public hearing. I asked the woman whether she had costed all the proposals that she was putting to the Committee and whether she could tell me the cost to the taxpayer. She said: 'Oh, I am not suggesting that the taxpayer pay: I am suggesting that the Government pay'. That is what Senator Grimes is saying tonight-not that the taxpayer should pay for it but that the Government should pay for it. I am quite sure that Senator Grimes will appear quite as silly to those people reading the Hansard as he sounds to honourable senators here.

speech.para: I have before me details of some of the payments of unemployment benefits to wives of strikers, and some of the detail of the costs to taxpayers and industry . In February and March last year a strike at Broken Hill lasted for 20 days. The cost to the taxpayer of that little effort was $396,274.

talk.start.para: —Where was that?

—That was at Broken Hill and the strike lasted 20 days. A strike during July and September by members of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union employed by the Utah company in central Queensland over use of apprentices in industrial action lasted 76 days at a cost to the taxpayer of $ 444,934. Those two little strikes in 1981 cost over $800,000-an incredible amount. It seems to me that if the Australian people knew their tax dollar was going into the pockets of striking workers they would be absolutely furious and would consider that the Government was irresponsible. I believe we should act in this fashion to stop this irresponsible payment.

speech.para: I believe the people of Australia are demanding a more responsible use of their tax dollar. Already in 1975 they overwhelmingly expressed their view of governments who use their tax dollar irresponsibly. They overwhelmingly expressed the view that no matter how often a government offers to hand out more and more money that they will say: 'No. We want a responsible government. We want our economy run in a responsible fashion. We do not want the inflation rates of 16 per cent that we had in the 1975 era'. The people expressed that view very clearly by throwing the Whitlam Government out. They do not want their hard earned dollars squandered by any government anxious only to hand out money to gain more votes. This Government will never indulge in that type of exercise.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —Although I was scheduled to be much lower on the speaking list than third I could not contain myself any longer; following Senator Walters is not a bonus that most honourable senators get. For the third time in six or eight months we are debating a Social Services Amendment Bill which seeks to extend to the spouses of people involved in industrial action the same penalties as apply to the strikers themselves. It is in fact an identical Bill to the one defeated in the Senate on 25 November last year. It has been reintroduced by the Government, one must presume, in order that the Government may have more than just the rejection of the sales tax legislation up its sleeve in the event of its wanting to call a double dissolution. After all it is much easier for the Government to get emotional about strikes, strikers and strike action than it is to convince the electorate it is doing the right thing by putting its hand in the electorate's pocket again . I suppose this is fair enough. If the Government wants to engineer an election it needs to have something pretty emotional to go to the electorate on.

speech.para: This legislation is iniquitous for a number of reasons. For a start it means that the wives and hence the children of strikers-it concerns the wives and children because, as Senator Grimes pointed out, more men are involved in industrial action than are women-will no longer be eligible to apply for unemployment benefit after one week, which is what obtains now. Of course, the same situation applies under this legislation to the families of people who fail the work test for a variety of reasons. I recall, in either my October or November speech on this legislation last year, questioning just how subjective some of those work test values were. It is very difficult to work out objectively, for instance, exactly what voluntarily taking oneself out of employment means. This is particularly so in the case of women who, for instance , suffer some form of sexual harassment. I raised this matter in my speech last year. I do not want to canvass it again. I make the point that voluntarily leaving a job is often something which is very hard to pin down.

talk.start.para: —Do you think Senator Walters has ever been sexually harassed.

—I do not even want to canvass the question of the sexual harassment of Senator Walters right now. We acknowledge the fact that special benefits are available, but the point has to be made that they are available only in cases of extreme hardship. I think that phrase bears repeating because extreme hardship under these circumstances really amounts to absolute penury and nothing less. It is a Dickensian type of alternative to offer people who, up to now, have been entitled to unemployment benefits after their spouses have been on strike for one week. I point out to the Senate that the majority of strikes last 10 days or less. If this Bill has not altered since last year-it has not- neither has the Australian Democrats' stand changed in any way at all. We still believe that social security legislation should not be used as an industrial relations weapon.
—Any way at all.

—Any way at all. If Senator Teague just waits a moment he will find out. I know he does not pay attention to most speeches in this place. We believe that social security legislation should not be used as an industrial weapon particularly when, as Senator Grimes pointed out, that weapon is directed at the most vulnerable units in the community-single income families with two or more children. We believe that there still exists the situation that I posited last year when I said that some unscrupulous members of the Government-at this point I specifically exclude the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney)- are gearing up to use the legislation or the Senate's failure to pass the legislation as a means of whipping up general public hysteria over the question of strikes. We believe that this is not in the short term or the long term interests of the Australian community generally. We still believe that it is immoral to penalise financially people who are not the cause of or party to industrial action simply because of their relationship to a person who is involved.

speech.para: On a number of occasions the Minister has raised the mythical powers of persuasion that some wives have over their husbands. He said something to the effect that if a unionist knows that his wife is not going to be able to claim unemployment benefits and therefore presumably cannot feed him-according to Senator Walters-he will have second and third thoughts about going out on strike , presumably because the wife will take some steps to point out that they are in a rather parlous predicament. I point out with due respect to the Minister that he is applying middle class values to people who, in essence, are not bound by those values. This morning's Sydney Morning Herald carried an interesting editorial. It referred to the inequities in consortium rights between men and women. It referred to a 1930s High Court decision in which a majority of judges put forward the theory that at common law one accepts the fact that the male has domination over the female but at common law it is not accepted that the female has domination over the male. In the majority of Australian families who are not socially aware, whose education is not up to middle class standards, whose values are not middle class values, that situation still pertains. If a wife presumed in many of these situations to chastise her husband for obeying a union dictate, she would be more likely to get a belt around the ear than to get him to oppose the union's requirement.

Furthermore, we believe that it is iniquitous to add a further financial burden to a group of people who are struggling for wage justice under an industrial system which has seen government action remove wage indexation and then oppose collective bargaining. We think it is unfair for a further financial burden to be placed on people who are in a social system which, because of direct Government actions, has seen huge increases in the cost of living and increases in the order of $34 a month in mortgage repayments over the last 12 months or so . We cannot blame these people for seeking some sort of security or some sort of balance for that. If they have to resort to strikes they should not be additionally penalised by the Government.

Senator Walters brought up that cute canard that the taxpayer, through the Government, should not be expected to subsidise strikers. With respect to the honourable senator I suggest that, boring though she may find it, she should read the speech that I made last November when I made what I thought was a fairly pertinent point-it certainly holds up arithmetically-that before one can strike one has to have a job and that if one has a job one is paying taxes. Therefore, we could look at those taxes as some sort of down payment on whatever social security requirements are necessary in later life not only to protect the individual but also to protect the individual's family. There is no question about that. It is about the one piece of scientific evidence that can be brought up in this debate.

The second reading speech makes a great deal of the fact that this legislation is primarily aimed at one industry town disputes where the women do not normally work and that, therefore, it is a charade that they then apply for unemployment benefit when their menfolk go out on strike. That overlooks entirely the other phenomenon of a one industry town. The industry which predominates in the town is rarely the sort of industry in which most women can get employment. Therefore , like it or not they are stay-at-home wives. There is no question that most of them would work if they could. So there is no point in the argument that this limited opportunity for work in a one industry town should be further compounded by the fact that, when their menfolk are out of work because they are on strike, after one week they cannot then apply for unemployment benefit.

The value of this legislation as it stands is extremely limited. I do not believe it was ever intended to have any sort of positive action. I draw the attention of honourable senators to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 14 August 1981 which points out the following:
Intervention by Federal Government officials--
That is, by definition, the Federal Government--
did not lead to the settlement of one industrial dispute during 1980.

Figures released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the year show that 21 per cent of disputes were solved by negotiation and 7 per cent by industrial tribunals under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
In 65 per cent of the disputes, work was resumed without negotiation.
Federal intervention has not led to the resolution of one dispute in the last five years.

So why the Government should expect this piece of legislation to be some kind of magic wand in solving industrial disputes when it has been able to do nothing about them over the last five years, despite the fact that some State governments, most of which are Liberal, have been able to do something, defies comprehension. A case in point exists in New South Wales at the moment. Let us suppose that this legislation had been passed last October or even last November in its most draconian form-that is, specifying that women who are married to men on strike cannot apply for unemployment benefits at all. Even supposing that, nothing would have changed in New South Wales or in any other situation similar to that which exists in New South Wales at the moment for the simple reason that the problems there have been caused not by strike action but by unionists engaged in go-slows or work bans. Whilst those sorts of actions can cause massive disruptions-nobody is arguing about that-neither of them is covered by this legislation. There can be no question that the motivation behind this legislation had nothing to do with ending or limiting industrial disputes. There seem to be no reasons behind the Government's reintroduction of this legislation other than to try to intimidate some unionists, to cause family disharmony, to punish innocent women and children or-this I believe to be the most likely reason-to take advantage of the average person's ignorance about industrial or legislative matters in order to induce hysteria in the community and then, what is worse, to prey upon this for political advantage. It appears to us to be nothing more nor less than a cynical exercise in scare tactics.

talk.start.para: —Pure mischief.

—It is this mischief making behind the legislation which led my colleague Senator Mason to suggest last year that a compromise might be found. There is nothing worse in a community than division between one group and another, particularly when it is bolstered by an outside source for reasons of its own. I refer honourable senators to Senator Masons's speech of 25 November last year in which he said that there were two extremes. He mentioned the case of the New South Wales petrol strike and the number of people who were disadvantaged, who suffered, who were indignant and upset about it. He made the point also that on many occasions family resources are stretched to the limit because of a strike, despite the pontifications by Government senators to the contrary, often the men have no choice but to take part in a strike. He emphasised the point by saying:

speech.para: . . . I think this makes it evident that there should be, between the two extremes we have heard in this chamber today, some middle ground which perhaps would be more acceptable to the community at large and which would take some sort of heat out of this situation.

I put the suggestion before the Senate yesterday with an appeal that it be seriously considered as a compromise position acceptable to all parties. It is something I thought the Government might have considered.

Had it any desire whatsoever to avoid anything other than a direct confrontation on this issue, I would have thought it something it might have said it would negotiate on. But that has not been the case.
He was referring to the situation last year. He continued:

As a result, I have been induced to the belief that the Government is raising this matter at this stage not because it wants this legislation or because it wants a solution to this problem but purely in a spirit of mischief to cause political trouble and dissention and perhaps also as a sop to its extreme right wing supporters in the community who regularly scream for strikers to be starved out.
Earlier we had the incredible statement from Senator Walters that if we paid them the unemployment benefit they might be able to feed their families.

talk.start.para: —What about the special benefits?

—I have already referred to special benefits. We acknowledge that they are there but they are there under the most extreme of hardship situations. The compromise which we suggest-I do not apologise for putting forward a compromise and I am sure that the concept of a compromise is not alien to people such as Bob Hawke, who made his living for many years out of finding compromises to situations-is put forward in an attempt to find what Senator Mason referred to last year as the middle ground. It is an attempt to take the emotionalism out of this Bill and to limit as much as possible the resentment which is likely to result in the community, with all the attendant divisiveness that this will cause in the country.
—So you have changed your mind after all.

—I have just finished quoting from Senator Mason's speech of last year. How can that, even in Senator Teague's warped and twisted mind, be construed as a change of mind? The compromise proposes not the total removal of eligibility for unemployment benefit for spouses of strikers but the extension by one week of the existing ineligibility period. In other words, instead of the wives of strikers being either eligible after one week, as is the situation now, or not being eligible at all, as would be the case if this Bill passed the Senate, the period after which they would be able to apply for unemployment benefit would be 14 days. I know that Senator Walters may not have a brilliant mathematical background but she ought to be able to see the difference between two weeks and an infinite period. There is a vast difference between doing something for one or two weeks and doing it for an indefinite period.

speech.para: We believe that this is a perfectly reasonable and responsible compromise. It avoids the potential for trumped up anti-union hysteria without unduly punishing the women and children at whom it is directed. To that end I have had prepared an amendment very similar to that which Senator Mason moved last year providing for the extension of the term from one week to two. A similar amendment will be moved in the Committee stage if we get there. I point out that if the amendment to the motion for the second reading is defeated we will oppose the legislation as it stands. I believe that this is something that would be done by any thinking person in the community. If people were given the choice between allowing somebody to go on unemployment benefit after one week of a strike or not at all, and if that were their only choice, I believe that the average Australian of compassion would opt for the operation of the one week provision. In a spirit of what my erstwhile colleague Senator Evans persists in calling 'co -operation and friendliness'-there has been precious little of this in any of the three debates that have taken place on this legislation-in regard to the motion for the second reading I move:
At end of motion, add:

', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should be amended so as to provide that married persons who would be disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit by clause 3 of the Bill shall receive such benefit after a waiting period of 14 days, and that during that period a special benefit is payable to such a person in a case of extreme hardship'.

I make it quite clear that I move that motion in an attempt to diffuse an already horrendous situation, in an attempt to find a compromise. I am becoming more and more appalled that the word 'compromise' is being treated with ridicule in this Parliament. I move the motion in the hope that in the coming months we will not see a situation in which neighbours are set against neighbours, towns are set against towns and sections of the community are set against each other because of some draconian legislation introduced by this Government. If the amendment is not accepted by the Senate we will oppose the legislation as it stands. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: —We are debating the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982). The second set of brackets in the title has been included for some particular administrative reason. The Bill has a familiar ring to all of us because this is really the third time that is has been before the Senate. Granted, the first time it was introduced it was not in the form of the Bill before us tonight. The elements of this Bill first appeared in the omnibus Social Service Amendment Bill 1981 following the Budget but they were rejected in this chamber. After they had been rejected in this chamber they reappeared in the form of the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981. That was rejected before the Senate went into the summer recess. Once again we have the Bill in front of us. It is no different from last year's Bill and I predict that its fate will be the same as that of the Bill which was before the Senate before Christmas.

speech.para: I shall outline the principal elements of this Bill. I think that Senator Walters in particular did not cover the objectives of the Bill in full. They are to deny the single rate of unemployment benefit, firstly to spouses of trade unionists who are involved in strike action, secondly, to spouses of the unemployed who have not satisfied the work test; and, thirdly, to spouses of those who are alleged to be voluntarily unemployed or who have allegedly been dismissed for misconduct. Even though the spouses may be eligible for unemployment benefit in their own right, the provisions of this Bill would remove that right from them.

I wish to go back to look in detail at those three basic objectives of the Bill . The first one is to deny unemployment benefit to spouses of trade unionists who are involved in industrial action. If those spouses have work when the breadwinner goes on strike they can, of course, continue to work and to support the family but if they do not have work and are willing to work and register for work they will not be able to obtain unemployment benefit. Let us take the case of the spouse of somebody engaged in industrial action who lives in a metropolitan area where some work is available. If she can obtain work, that is fine for her, but if she lives in a place where there is no work available-we have heard a lot tonight about isolated communities and mining communities-even if she is looking for work and wants to obtain it, under the provisions of this Bill she will not be able to obtain unemployment benefit.

Senator Walters, when she was speaking earlier, dwelt on the area of strikes. She spoke almost totally about people being on strike. She did not mention the other two areas. At one stage she said that if people are not willing to work, if they are on strike, they should not put out their hands to obtain unemployment benefit. We are not talking about the people who are engaged in industrial action receiving unemployment benefit; we are talking about spouses and their children being able to obtain some social service payment so that they can continue to live in a reasonable way. We are not talking about the person on strike getting some benefit; we are talking about the spouse. Of course, the spouses are usually the wives, so we are mainly talking about the wives and children.

There is another objective of the Bill. It will deny the single rate of unemployment benefit to the spouses of those who are unemployed but who have not satisfied the work test. What if a wrong decision has been made in relation to the work test? Most honourable senators would have had people come to them who have allegedly failed the work test and after some degree of negotiation with the Department of Social Security they have found that a wrong assessment has been made and the person should have been obtaining unemployment benefit. But many people do not come to members of parliament when this happens. If a person has been deemed to have failed the work test, even though his wife may want to obtain unemployment benefit by registering for employment and trying to obtain a job, if she is unable to find a job then under the provisions of this Bill she and her children will not be able to get anything from the Department of Social Security.

The third area in which the unemployment benefit will be denied is to spouses of those who are alleged to have been voluntarily unemployed or who have been dismissed for misconduct. In those circumstances the breadwinner will not be able to obtain any unemployment benefit for a certain period. If the spouse looks for work and finds it, that is fine. However, if she genuinely looks for work and cannot find it, under the provisions of this Bill she will not be able to obtain any benefit. As Senator Grimes asked, why should we deny the benefit to a wife and her children because she is married to a person who becomes voluntarily unemployed or is dismissed for misconduct? Senator Grimes rightly pointed out that if the couple separates they might be able to obtain the unemployment benefit but should we make people separate for that particular reason? We should not have such a provision which punishes the wife and the children.

The unemployment benefit will be denied to spouses under three basic conditions : If their husbands are involved in strike action-I am presuming it is the male who is the breadwinner but it might not necessarily be so; if they have not satisfied the work test, or if they are voluntarily unemployed or dismissed for alleged misconduct. That denial extends, with extremely minor exceptions, to the special benefit. Spouses who would have received the special benefit would not be eligible for it if they failed on any of the conditions which I have mentioned. This legislation should be seen for what it really is-a blatant, cynical attempt to divert public attention from the real issues facing Australia . It is an attempt to cover up the economic morass into which this Government has steadily steered this country over the last five years.

The real issues facing the Australian people are housing, high interest rates, high rates of unemployment, pensions and inadequate health and taxation policies . These are the issues which this Bill that has come to us for the third time is trying to cover up. They are issues for which this Government has no answer. They were not issues which the Government could cover up in the Lowe electorate. The vote in the Lowe by-election was a clear indication to this Government that it no longer has the confidence of the people. The electorate will not have the wool pulled over its eyes by a Bill of this nature. What is the Government's answer to all the problems to which I have referred? It brings forth a piece of legislation that has twice been defeated in this chamber. It was defeated just after the Budget presentation and previously it was defeated in a separate Bill which was introduced in an attempt to divert attention from the grave problems faced by this nation.

The defeat of this measure-I presume it will be defeated-will mean that it will be another Bill which can be used by this Government for a double dissolution. It already has the conditions for a double dissolution if it wants one. When this Bill is defeated, as I presume it will be, the Government will have another Bill which it can use if it wishes. But will the Government go to the people? I hardly think so. If it went to the people at this stage it would be decimated and it knows that. The Government will sit on this Bill and hope that something will happen to its popularity so that it will be able to go to the people. I predict that between now and the time when a normal election can be held in 1983 , the popularity of the Government will not increase to such an extent that it will want to go to the people. Of course, we on this side of the chamber would welcome a double dissolution because we know that after the election we would be in government and we would be able to get this country back on to the rails where it should be.
I will make some comments on certain parts of the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). At one stage it stated:
. . . we are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action as contrasted with other means open to employees in dispute with their employers to resolve these disputes.
Those are nice words indeed but that is all they are. I repeat that the speech stated:
. . . we are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action . . .

Of course the Government is concerned with the merits of strike action. It condemns it out of hand. The spouses of those engaged in industrial action will be penalised irrespective of how justified that industrial action may be. The Government's attitude to strike action was made clear in the Minister's second reading speech. It stated:

So, the Australian public is attacked from two directions. First, it has to bear the personal disruptions, inconveniences and associated costs that result from the strike. In addition, it is then called upon to meet the cost of providing income support for the families of those involved in the strike.

So much for not being concerned with the merits of strike action! The Government 's attitude is made quite clear in that statement. It wants to have nothing to do with strike action. It is not surprising to me that this Government should have a fixation that in industrial conflict the worker is always to blame; the worker is always wrong. But is that the case? Certainly it is not the case and the official figures show that it is not. In August last year the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported on industrial disputes for 1980. That report showed that 39.7 per cent of disputes-that is, about two in every five-were disputes over managerial policy. Were the workers to blame for this? The report showed that 19.6 per cent of the disputes-that is, about one in every five-were over physical working conditions. The Government conveniently uses the argument that workers and their industrial unions are to blame for every industrial dispute that occurs. The official ABS figures indicate otherwise. As I said, about two in every five disputes were over managerial policy and about one in every five were over physical working conditions. So three in every five disputes were over conditions about which the worker had every right to be concerned and every right, in the final analysis, to withdraw his or her labour.

The Government's attitude towards workers was shown clearly from 1976 to 1981 in wage indexation hearings. Despite the galloping inflation for which this Government has no answer, it tried to deny at Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearings any wage justice for Australian workers.
