I can well remember the first hearing at which the Fraser Government made a submission . Early in 1976 the Commission was deliberating a 6.4 per cent consumer price index increase. The Government proposed that only half of that should be granted . In other words, instead of getting a 6.4 per cent increase to cover rises in the consumer price index the Government felt that workers should receive only a 3.2 per cent increase. I sat in for some of the hearing when it was held in Melbourne. It was illuminating to do so. I almost felt sorry for the Commonwealth advocate. The advocate had his instructions to put a case for a 3.2 per cent increase rather than a 6.4 per cent increase, but he had no argument; he really floundered. Unfortunately by the time the next hearing was held the Commonwealth advocate had got his act together. He did not have his act together on the previous occasion so the full 6.4 per cent increase was granted.

At the 15 wage indexation hearings between February 1976 and January 1981 the Commonwealth made 10 submissions for no increases in the national wage, two for rises equivalent to a 30 per cent indexation and three for rises of between 50 per cent and 60 per cent of the CPI movement. In 15 hearings no submissions made by the Commonwealth supported full indexation. I mention that because anyone who looks at this type of record would fully understand that the Australian worker will not receive any sympathy or any attempt at understanding from this Government. I would like to mention another part of the Minister's second reading speech. He said:

There have been numerous cases where the wives of strikers, who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the workforce themselves, have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them. This has enabled them, under the existing legislation, to obtain unemployment benefits-

I ask the Minister: What are these numerous cases where wives who have had no intention of joining the work force have registered for work? In the vast majority of the cases that the Minister has referred to where wives have registered for work they would gladly have taken the work if it had been available. Yet the Minister says they had no genuine intention of joining the work force themselves. If the work was there, the majority of the wives in these areas would have taken work. The Minister said that there were numerous cases where the wives have had no intention of joining the work force. Let us be given a list of how many people are involved and let us be told the cost of these numerous cases and of the mining and construction towns referred to by the Minister. It is very easy to make a sweeping statement like that and talk about numerous cases, but let us be given a list of what they are. My assessment is that the numerous cases can almost be counted on one hand. If they cannot, they are but figments of the Minister's imagination.

The strike in central Queensland in 1981 has been mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech. Much is made of the $450,000 paid to over 400 spouses. Is any assessment made in the Minister's speech of what a great multinational company which made $160m profit in that particular year did to solve this dispute? No mention is made at all of that. It is apparently of no concern to a government which enjoys its own anti-union rhetoric. I would like to refer again to the Minister's second reading speech. He said:

The legislation as it stands at the moment permits a situation where trade unions can choose to strike, knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions.

Does the legislation as it stands at the moment-it would be changed by this Bill if it were passed-allow those engaged in industrial action to be largely insulated? Let us examine the extent to which they would be insulated. Firstly, we must be mindful that no social security payment would be made to these people in the first week. Secondly, let us consider a family of three and presume that the male is the breadwinner. If he is engaged in some industrial action and if his wife registers as unemployed and is eligible to receive benefits, at the moment she would receive a total of $79.70 a week. Of that $79.70, $69 would be for herself as a single person, plus $10 a week for her child. Is the family largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions, as has been stated by the Minister? They have less than $80 a week, which is well below the poverty level. The amount that they have for all their weekly commitments is $18 less than a Minister of this Government receives in travel allowance for one overnight stay in a capital city. How can it be said that these people are insulated from the financial effect of their actions? A family of three has to live on $80 a week. They are not largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions.

While I am speaking about that matter I am reminded of something Senator Walters said a little while ago. She was talking about Senator Grimes making some extraordinary statements. She then made a statement therafter which I think was an extraordinary statement, par excellence. She said that if we had a system whereby, after 14 days, people were able to obtain some unemployment benefit, they would then say: 'We will now strike for three weeks to get our bonus'. I emphasise the words 'to get our bonus'-a bonus of $80 to keep three people for one week. What an extraordinary statement that is. It is worth examining how many workers who take industrial action would be affected by the passage of this legislation. The number is so small that the Government's motivation for bringing this matter forward must be suspect.

The publication of the Australian Bureau of Statistics which I referred to earlier indicated that only 9.9 per cent of strikers were involved in strikes of five or more working days. Only 4.8 per cent of those involved in industrial action, which is less than one in 20, were involved in strikes of 10 days or more. This gives an indication of how small the number is that we are referring to. The fact that some of the spouses would already be working gives an idea of the small number of people who would be involved or affected by this legislation if it were passed. I noted that my colleague in the other place, Dr Blewett, had calculated that about 500 or 600 families would be involved in one year. I have not seen this figure contested.

talk.start.para: —What is all the fuss about?

—The Minister asks: 'What is all the fuss about?' How magnanimous for the Minister to say that when I say that only 500 or 600 families would be involved. If one wife and her children were disadvantaged by this piece of legislation, I would still create some fuss. The relatively low number of lengthy strikes are an indication that, on the whole, workers in this country do not in embark on long strikes unless they feel that they have strong and distinct grievances. Yet it is the spouses and children who would be affected by this Bill. We must remember that it is because of not only industrial action-this was dwelt on by one speaker on the other side-but also other reasons that the spouses and their children would be affected.

speech.para: Before I mention the amendment that was moved by the Australian Democrats, I refer to the use of a social services Bill as an industrial relations weapon. It is an indictment of a government that is so devoid of ideas for a responsible industrial relations policy that it uses a social services Bill as a substitute. If the Government is concerned about the level of industrial action in Australia , why does it not do something positive rather than pursue a negative course through the Social Services Act? It could do something about the managerial policies which the ABS records, as causing so many disputes. Similarly, it could attack the physical working conditions which are so poor that they result in strike action. A realistic wages policy would go a long way to reducing the numbers of disputes. This sort of positive action would be much better than using a Social Services Bill as an industrial relations weapon.

At this stage I mention something about the amendment that has been moved by the Australian Democrats. The Australian Labor Party will, of course, be opposing the Bill, but it will not be supporting the amendment which was moved by the Australian Democrats. The amendment in itself singles out some punishment to wives, and their children, because their spouses are members of a trade union . It extends the waiting period from seven to 14 days. We in the Australian Labor Party would not accept that. The amendment has no real teeth. I presume that if the amendment were passed at the second reading stage amendments would be moved in the Committee stage to add some teeth. All the amendment does is express an opinion. The amendment seeks to add at the end of the motion that the Bill be read a second time the following words:

but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should be amended so as to provide that married persons who would be disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit by clause 3 of the Bill shall receive such benefit after a waiting period of 14 days, and that during that period a special benefit is payable to such a person in a case of extreme hardship.

If the amendment were passed, of course, it would express an opinion of the Senate. But it would not mean that the Government would have to do anything. We would have to go further in the Committee stage and add something so that that opinion would be backed up by some legislation. The Australian Labor Party does not support the amendment, because it punishes spouses and their children. In fact, Senator Haines said that it does not unduly punish women and children. But there is an element of punishment there. Therefore, we will not be supporting the amendment and we will certainly be voting against the Bill. The legislation which we have before us is nothing but a cheap political stunt. I anticipate that it will be defeated. It certainly deserves to be.

speech.speaker: Martin Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: —I take up the point raised by Senator Colston last; that is, the statement that he made and the inferences that have been in other statements made by other Opposition senators tonight that this amendment to the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982) is intended to be some sort of punishment. I put an alternative view: To take away unemployment benefits under certain circumstances is not a punishment. It is to take away an entitlement which should not in justice exist.

speech.para: The Opposition has ranged far and wide in the debate tonight. In the matters raised many points have been covered-very few of them justified. It is all too easy on this subject to skim over the surface of the amendment, to create a false case for the amendment and to ignore the real issues. We have had statements made by Opposition senators in which they quote other people and accept as fact figures given by other people, figures which they have not checked themselves. Senator Colston quoted what Dr Blewett of the House of Representatives said. He said that according to Dr Blewett 500 to 600 families a year would be involved. Senator Colston was saying that very few people were involved and that therefore the amendment was not justified. I point out to Senator Colston that, in just one strike in Broken Hill in 1981, 1,171 spouses claimed and received unemployment or special benefits. That is not the 500 to 600 a year ranging over all strikes which was apparently stated by Dr Blewett and quoted by Senator Colston. If that is the best that Opposition senators can bring up it shows how superficial their approach to the subject has been.

Senator Colston said that if one family were deprived unfairly it would be one too many. The Government has said that if one family were in hardship as a result of this that family would be looked after-it and all other families in real hardship. The Government is saying that the issue is: Why should strikers with spouses and with their own cash resources be subsidised by the taxpayer? There are two issues there. First of all, the striker must have a spouse. That is the striker whom the Opposition seeks to protect. The single striker does not have the advantage of the married striker. The single striker goes without benefit. That is all right apparently, according to the Opposition. This is an issue that has not been addressed. We have been told of heart-rending individual instances from which we have had a false conclusion drawn about how those families would be affected. The range of issues has not been touched. The fact that single strikers are in a different position and that taxpayers are affected was not touched by Opposition speakers on this issue.

The second point is that these strikers also have their own cash resources. It is entirely possible that people with very low cash resources who are working and paying tax are subsidising people in a superior position. I suggest to Senator Colston that if there is any taxpayer who is unfairly being deprived of part of his or her income as a result of present practices that is one taxpayer too many. What is sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander in this matter.

Senator Colston made a statement relating to the profits of the Utah Development Co. The point of his statement was not clear to me because the logic was not followed through. He said that he was making a point in general terms earlier in his speech about the number of strikes that are the consequence of disputes over managerial issues. Further on in his speech the honourable senator made a reference to Utah and its profits as though those two things were connected. I remind Senator Colston that in his State of Queensland in Blackwater in 1980 there was a strike by coal miners which affected Utah as well as the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd and Theiss Toyota Pty Ltd in which 523 wives- nearly the annual total, according to Dr Blewett as quoted by Senator Colston- received benefits at a total cost of $431,475 on the issue of subsidised housing , which had nothing to do with management. There was no managerial dispute at all. But the penalty went in the first case to the strikers because they lost $ 22m in wages. The lost production to Utah was worth $190m in revenue and the loss flows on.

We forget apparently that there is another side to the equation; that is, that employers and people who provide capital in order to provide employment have some entitlement too. These strikes can have an effect on shareholders, shareholders who are not necessarily wealthy people. It would be as logical this evening to point to individual issues of people who depend on share income, say, in their retirement and their deprivation because of loss of income and profits to companies. I shall not pursue that matter, although it could be pursued, but it is as logical as the case put up by the opposition side. There is another side to the equaton which is just conveniently overlooked. It is also not enough for me for Senator Colston, whose credibility is not good on the basis of what he quoted from Dr Blewett, to say that certain statistics show that a percentage of disputes are about managerial issues. It may well be claimed that the disputes are about managerial issues. That does not mean that the union that went on strike was correct in its assessment of management. I return to the central issue.

talk.start.para: —About time.

—Well, there are two responsibilities in this debate. One is to deal with the amendment that has been proposed. There is also some responsibility on Government senators to pay a little attention to what has been said in opposition to the Bill. If it were not said, honourable senators opposite would be the first to say that we had no answer. It is certainly impossible in the course of this debate to cover all the points raised by the Opposition because of constraints of time and because they were many, varied and rambling. That does not mean that they were all true. It does not mean that any of them were true. The central issue is the question of responsibility. We have heard some extraordinary statements. Senator Haines, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, said that the Government wants to cause hardship and to deprive strikers of their incomes. She said that if people have to resort to strikes they should not be additionally penalised by the Government. Senator Grimes said that people would be deprived of income through no fault of their own.

speech.para: That comes to the issue of responsibility and fault, which is a word that Opposition senators want to bring up. I would like to know how one can extend the argument of Senator Haines that the Government could be causing hardship and depriving strikers of their incomes. I will accept that people have the right to withdraw their labour and to go on strike. But it was always accepted in that industrial situation, even from the beginning and at the most militant times of union difficulties in the past, that there was a price on both sides of that. When labour was withdrawn, so were wages. That was the other side. The unionist could strike and deprive himself of income at the same time as he deprived his employer of income. There is an issue of responsiblity in deciding to go on strike. It may be that industrial issues are justifiable, but it is not for unemployment beneficiaries or social security officers to be the judges of that. It is not for taxpayers willy nilly to be subsidising that issue, right or wrong .

talk.start.para: —There is always a work test.
—There is a work test. There is a serious intention to work indeed.
—And the right of a woman to it.

—The honourable senator is very chatty. Why does he not go to his Whip and get on the speakers' list? Perhaps he does not think the honourable senator is good enough. He should take his turn. I promise I will not interrupt him if he does that. Senator Haines says that the Government is causing hardship , as though in an industrial situation where decisions are taken not to work the Government causes hardship because the employee no longer gets wages and as though the Government is intervening in that situation. The Government stands back in that situation and allows people to make that decision. In more extreme industrial situations the Government may become involved. There is no automatic responsibility on government to come to the aid of people who make decisions, the consequences of which they know full well at the time they make them.

speech.para: Senator Haine's second point was that if workers have to resort to strikes they should not be additionally penalised by the Government. There is a penalty in resorting to strikes; it is the loss of wages. Not getting a supplement in place of wage is not an additional penalty. Getting a supplement is a benefit. The logic is back to front, as it comes from the Democrats. Senator Grimes made a very appealing speech, I will admit. He showed, I think, a genuine concern for people in hardship. He gave us many examples of what would happen to people deprived of income. But in all such speeches from members of the Opposition they overlook the fact that the Government has said, and provides in this amending legislation, that in cases of hardship people will qualify for a benefit. But they have to prove hardship. As it stands, people can go on strike and the spouse can register for unemployment benefit. They can be people with very substantial assets, with cash in hand, but they can draw unemployment benefit from the public coffers. That is not the sort of case that the Opposition talks about, but those cases exist just as much as the cases that the Opposition chooses to talk about. The hardship case that the Opposition chooses not to recognise is looked after in the Government's proposal.

What are the effects of the present situation? There is an easy option for people when they decide to take industrial action. I would have thought that industrial action was considered by unionists traditionally to be their ultimate weapon, in many cases their last resort weapon. We have many and intricate systems of arbitration and negotiation and it has always been thought by employer and employee alike that strike on behalf of the employee or lock-out on behalf of the employer was the weapon that was resorted to in the last instance. But if employees know that they will have a guaranteed income-they do know it in single industry towns such as mining towns-it becomes less of a last resort, and the question of responsibility disappears. It is too easy to regard the taxpayer as some vague person one never sees. It is too easy to consider the public purse as something that is bottomless, as though one had no responsibility towards either. The easy resort to unemployment benefit is--

talk.start.para: —You have never been on strike. You wouldn't know what it's like.

—No, I have not been on strike, but I do know what it is like. The responsibility has to go in all directions. It is not enough for Opposition senators to say that the Government has an automatic responsibility just because people are on strike and have families. The responsibility in the other direction-not to want an abuse of the system and an easy resort to taxpayers' fund-is the counter-responsibility. Many of the things said in today's debate by Opposition senators about the issue of entitlement brought with them an implicit notion that someone on strike and with a family was entitled to benefit, regardless of other issues. We have heard reference made to a number of single industry towns. Senator Grimes said that families in Queensland mining towns cannot supplement their incomes as there is no employment available, so that if the wives of coal miners-it is wives in that case-register for unemployment benefit, they are clearly not seriously registering for employment. They know, according to Senator Grimes, that there is no employment available. They cannot supplement their incomes by taking alternative employment, so they register for employment and in due course claim an unemployment benefit. In that case, under the amending legislation, special benefits are still available in the case of hardship-if people do not have other resources such as cash or other income.

speech.para: Senator Colston also addressed himself to this issue and wanted to know which towns were involved in point of fact. Senator Colston is a senator for Queensland and he may have thought that another senator from Queensland would not like to point the finger at a couple of places. Senator Colston, as a senator, should know that there was a strike in Blackwater, a coal mining town, from June to September 1980 on the subject of subsidised housing, during which time 523 wives received benefits.

talk.start.para: —A good example.

—That is right. It is a single industry town. I recall as well as Senator Colston would the almost carnival atmosphere that was portrayed through the media surrounding women registering for unemployment benefits. They made it clear that they did not expect to be offered a job. Indeed, they did not want to be offered a job. They did not want that alternative and the fact that there was not alternative employment, there was not a risk of their being offered a job, was an incentive to registering. The public saw that and understood very clearly what the issues were. That fact cannot be dodged. In Gladstone, Queensland, which is not a single industry town, there was a strike from January to March 1981 in which 53 wives of 176 strikers-presumably not all the strikers were married-received a total payout of $38,607. That is a more diverse town and more employment opportunities are available there but it is essentially a heavy industry town. Those who went on strike were people in heavy industry and were not likely to have their income supplemented by their wives.

speech.para: From February to March 1981 at Broken Hill between 2,000 and 2,500 workers went on strike and 1,171 wives claimed and received benefits to a total value in excess of $369,000. Again, Broken Hill is a heavy industry town and there is not much risk of wives being offered jobs in mines where they could not work. In central Queensland-I am referring to big issues and big strikes-from July to September 1981, 600 miners went on strike and 482 wives, there is a very high marriage rate in that part of Queensland, claimed in excess of $444,000 in benefits. In Port Kembla there was a strike from August to September 1981-again, that is a heavy industry town-and 550 employees were on strike and 85 wives claimed benefits in excess of $41,000.

In Gove in the Northern Territory, which is not a place which has many alternatives of employment or many options for travelling to get employment, there was a strike from August to October 1981 in which 550 workers were on strike and 105 wives claimed a total benefit in excess of $96,000. In six disputes the figures, as I have just detailed, totalled $1,422,955. It all adds up and it is very clear that it is possible for a lot of money to be involved. I have indicated that a number of wives were paid benefits. In all cases a number of those wives applied for and received special benefits and they did not register for unemployment benefits. So presumably there were a number of wives who would have continued to receive benefits in any event.

Senator Haines made the extraordinary assertion that if this Bill had applied last year the incidence and length of strikes would not have been affected at all. I am not sure on what she bases that statement but one could draw the conclusion that if the non-payment of benefits would not have affected the length and incidence of strikes the strikers did not need the benefits; they could manage without them. I have no idea on what Senator Haines based that statement apart from an assertion or two. It may well be that this amendment would not affect the incidence or length of strikes. One thing it would affect is the payment of benefits to people who do not need them, who have other resources, who have decided to deprive themselves of income by going on strike and who think that other members of the community owe them some sort of a living .

I think it is worth stating what this amendment does. The purpose of clause 3 of the Bill is to prevent payment of unemployment benefit to the spouse of a person where that person is involved in industrial action or where that person has been refused unemployment benefit or has had that benefit cancelled or postponed. They are the conditions. The clause proposes to change the current position in relation to unemployment benefit by the insertion of a condition which would disqualify from receipt of unemployment benefit a married person whose spouse is not qualified to receive unemployment benefit because the spouse , or a member of the spouse's trade union, is involved in industrial action; or has been refused unemployment benefit on one of the grounds prescribed in the work tests other than the ground that the spouse was employed or was capable of undertaking paid work; or has had and unemployment benefit cancelled or postponed on certain prescribed grounds. These are: That a person was voluntarily unemployed; that a person was unemployed due to his own misconduct; that a person did not accept an offer of employment which the Director-General considered to be suitable. In each of these cases, the period of disqualification from unemployment benefit would be the period that the spouse of the married person is disqualified from that benefit due to that benefit being refused, cancelled, or postponed in the circumstances described.

In no case, in the course of either of these debates in the Senate, have Opposition senators-I refer particularly to Senator Haines-addressed themselves to those simple issues, the conditions under which the benefit would be taken away. We have had generalisations and assertions, some of which I have had the opportunity to demonstrate are just not true. Perhaps at some future time honourable senators opposite will correct that. On neither occasion that Senator Haines has spoken had she addressed herself in any serious way to the payment of special benefits, the exception that would be made. Tonight the honourable senator has spoken, as she did last November, in terms of heart-rending hardship . There is a hardship count out in this Bill. The exception is that in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support special benefit is payable to the spouse.

talk.start.para: —Maybe.

—Special benefit is payable to the spouse. We cannot win when we debate with the Democrats. It is not the first occasion on which this has happened in the Senate; it has happened in relation to other Bills that the Democrats have opposed. Instead of addressing themselves to what is in the Bill and the items that I have just outlined, they address themselves to what might be in some future Bill or what might be a future action of the Government. Frankly that is why it is so difficult to follow them. If I have misunderstood the honourable senator I apologise, but I think not. I did understand the points that the honourable senator was making in her first speech. I understood the points that others had some difficulty with or the honourable senator thought they had some difficulty with. The honourable senator made a point, as she said tonight, in her speech in November that there is a central issue here that we really need to understand. I shall try to keep a straight face as I repeat what was said by Senator Haines. She said that if these people are on strike it is very clear that they had jobs to start with and they were paying tax.
—You are not going to dispute that, are you?

—That is true. The difficulty is: What is the relevance, not the truth, of that statement? If the honourable senator is suggesting that because people are paying tax they have made a contribution to the public purse, therefore they have an entitlement to unemployment benefit, she is moving some distance towards contributory social security. If contributory social security is the Democrats' policy, terrific. They should proclaim it, argue it and explain how it would have applied in Gladstone during a 60 day strike. On the proposal that the honourable senator is putting forward, how long would someone have had to be in continuous employment in order to have an entitlement for 60 days? Senator Haines should explain how long those miners in Blackwater would have had to have been in continuous employment to make the necessary contribution under contributory social security to keep them on strike for three months. It would have been for long periods. Senator Haines can look at the record. If the honourable senator is serious and has looked at the subject of contributory social security she knows that in order to be out of work for that long one would have had to have worked for some time indeed. One very quickly runs out of credits when one goes on strikes that last for three months, two months or whatever. I do not think that that is possible. The fact that Senator Haines would like to see a contributory social security scheme, which I am sure an awful lot of employees in the community would not like to see, is interesting but not relevant because we do not have a contributory social security scheme; we have a tax system which provides the money for our unemployment benefit and other benefits.

speech.para: Those who work and pay taxes on a continuing basis provided something like $1. 5m in benefits for just the six disputes that I referred to this evening. There are many others. Senator Haines should do her sums on the amount of benefits paid and the amount of tax that might have been otherwise paid or contributed by those workers just as their share of the social security bill. She should not say that all the tax that they pay goes into the social security purse, because it does not. Remember, it would have to be just a share and then she might have a point to be made. But to argue that policy is not to deny the logic or justice of the case that the Government puts forward in this amendment. It is not denied either by ignoring, as the honourable senator has so consistently in debates on this issue, the hardship catch-phrase. I have heard Senator Haines talk many times about hardship that would be caused by this legislation. She overlooks the fact that hardship is taken account of. In doing so she misled the public. If she did not set out to mislead the public it happened because she misled herself .

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: —I rise briefly to point out the Opposition's attitude to the amendment moved by Senator Haines.
—I take it, Senator Grimes, that you are speaking to the amendment.

—I am speaking to the amendment, as did the previous speaker, Senator Martin, who seemed to spend her whole time destroying Senator Haines's amendment rather than justifying the legislation which has been brought before this House. I indicate that the Opposition opposes Senator Haines's amendment although, unlike Senator Martin, and Senator Walters who anticipated Senator Haines's amendment, I appreciate the motives of the Australian Democrats in bringing forward this amendment which provides that the benefit be paid after a period of 14 days.

speech.para: Senator Martin talked about Senator Haines's interest in sums. Senator Martin gave us some sums relating to a series of disputes in Queensland and in Broken Hill. She did not mention that a dispute in Gove in the Northern Territory cost the taxpayers of this country $1.4m. That is just about the amount of money that Senator Chaney cost the taxpayers of this country on one dispute, the Australian Clerical Officers Association's dispute, which he and his predecessor deliberately prolonged for political and grandstanding reasons. Yet, we have almost had tears of blood from Senator Martin tonight about the dispute in Queensland and other places which cost $1.4m. She did not tell us that the Blackwater dispute which she relied on so heavily was supported by her coalition partners in Queensland. The National Country Party members in Queensland supported the dispute and urged the miners at Blackwater to stay out and to defy the Treasurer (Mr Howard).

talk.start.para: —You are dishonest in saying that. You are a dishonest debater.
—Order! Senator Martin will withdraw that remark.
—I am sorry I claimed that Senator Grimes is a dishonest debater. I will withdraw the remark.

—Thank you, Senator, and thank you, Mr Deputy President. The simple fact is that Mr Bjelke-Petersen's colleagues in Queensland supported the miners in Blackwater. They said that their dispute was justified. The miners won their dispute. Senator Martin says that their wives should have gone without support and benefits yet the strikers won their dispute. The Treasurer of this country, a man praised to the heavens by Senator Chaney in the National Times last weekend as an honest, just and good man, agreed, in the end, that the strikers were right and they won their dispute. Is Senator Martin saying that these people, who were seeking justice and who apparently got justice, because the Government agreed with what they got, should not have received any benefit? This is the crux of the matter.

speech.para: Government members have gone on about this being social services legislation aimed at not giving benefits to people who do not deserve them. But Senator Martin, Senator Walters and later, Senator Chaney-if I can anticipate him as Senator Walters anticipated Senator Haines's speech-have made it perfectly clear that this is legislation about strikes, about depriving not the strikers of their incomes but the wives and their children of basic support. That is what this Bill is about and that is why we object to it. That is why we object to Senator Haines's amendment. That amendment does, in fact, do the same thing. The vast majority of disputes in this country last two days. Many disputes last for 10 days and therefore Senator Haines's amendment does not meet our principles.

We believe that if the Government wants to introduce legislation to alter the industrial relations system in this country it should get Mr Viner to introduce it. Let it argue on honest grounds about industrial relations legislation. It should not use social services legislation which is meant to protect people who cannot help themselves. The Government should introduce legislation under the industrial relations head so that we can argue and fight on that basis. It should not use the social services legislation to deprive innocent women and children of benefits. It should not tell us that there is a provision in this legislation for hardship. Even Senator Chaney, the Minister for Social Security, knows the stringent hardship provisions which relate to the payment of the special benefit. He knows that under the present legislation many people are caught up in disputes about which they have no knowledge. They are caught up in disputes which are started in another factory. They are involved secondarily. Under the present legislation, their wives and their children, under all sorts of circumstances, cannot receive the special benefit because of the hardship provisions that exist now, and those provisions will not be eased by this legislation.

I am amazed at the number of times we have heard Senator Martin talk in this place about the rights of women. I was amazed when Senator Martin stood up in this place and castigated people like Senator Harradine for having the temerity to speak for women. I was amazed when I heard her say in this place tonight that a woman who makes herself available for work, a woman who has no other form of support yet is willing to work, should be deprived of benefits, not because she is married to a man who is on strike but because she is married to a trade unionist who is on strike. That is the crux of this legislation.

The legislation is aimed at trade unionists, not non-trade unionists. It is aimed at people who are members of unions who are in dispute or who are out of work because of a dispute by members of their union in another place. We think this legislation is wrong in principle because of that. We believe that if the Government thinks it is justified in bringing in legislation to prevent industrial disputes it should do so in an honest way under the head of industrial legislation, not by the back door through social services. It should not try to prevent disputes in this country by affecting the income of women and children of people involved in disputes either directly or indirectly. That is why we maintain our opposition to the legislation. In fact, that is why we find the amendment moved by Senator Haines, however high her motives, unacceptable. We will continue to oppose this Bill at all stages.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek to make a brief personal explanation. I thought that when Senator Grimes commenced speaking that he genuinely misunderstood some words I had used in the course of my speech. When I spoke about amendments to Bills I was, of course, referring to amendments to the present Social Services Act. The Bill we are speaking to tonight is the Social Services Amendment Bill. It was the amendments contained in that Bill that I was addressing myself to. At no stage did I address myself to Senator Haines's amendment because, frankly, I did not think it was worth it.

speech.speaker: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

talk.start.para: —The Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) deals with the payment of unemployment benefit to spouses of persons involved in industrial action. Of course, before us we also have the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. I have looked briefly at the amendment and it seems to me it is not all that different from the position taken by the Government. If the Democrats were not so determined so consistently to oppose the Government they might be supporting the Bill with us tonight. I do not propose to confine my remarks so much to statistics. I hope not to confine my remarks to an emotional approach to this important Bill. I hope we can reach a commonsense view. I hope we can look at the Bill more particularly from a point of view of principle rather than the significance of the number of dollars that may or may not be involved.

speech.para: Whether to pay unemployment benefits to the spouses of strikers is the question that confronts us tonight. Of course, as we have learned during the passage of the last hour or two, there is a case to be made for both sides of the argument. I believe that probably one argument is significantly based more on emotion than on logic. On balance, I believe that the Government's proposition is realistic and responsible. It is responsible to the community as a whole. It is responsible to the Australian taxpayer. After all, the payment of employment benefits to people who cease to work and who are on strike is surely, when analysed, nothing more than yet another call-of whatever magnitude-on the Australian taxpayer. I do not believe that in this debate tonight we are involved in a discussion on the right to strike. Of course, the right to strike is an acceptable part of a free society just as is the right of free speech, the right of association, and a whole lot of other rights we are constantly talking about not only in this place but also in the Press or wherever Australians gather.

We are not discussing the right to strike. We are perhaps discussing whether the right to strike in a country existing under the rule of law should virtually be a last resort following negotiations in an attempt to come to a reasonable and responsible conclusion concerning the living and working conditions and wages and salaries that apply in the various industries in this country. Living as we fortunately do in Australia-and as people in a few other democratic societies around the world live-under the rule of law and as a free society surely we have to be aware of the consequences of strike action.

I believe that the consequences across the whole community of a great deal of strike action are very sad indeed. Certain honourable senators tonight have talked about the consequences that flow in certain circumstances to the spouse and children of a striker. The consequences of that sort of strike action which has been far too common in this country go much further. The consequences range right across the Australian community. The longer a strike lasts of course then the further those consequences extend into the middle and far distant future. Indeed, they can be so severe that they will not only threaten the development of this country, not only our capacity to supply goods and ultimately our ability to get and to assure ourselves of markets but also, consequent upon those things, threaten the capacity of this country to provide realistic, proper and useful employment for all its people.

In other words, strike action imposes an immense hardship on countless Australians. It is the Government's proposition that those Australians-as Australian taxpayers-should not be held responsible in any way for the payment of unemployment benefits to the spouses of people determined not to work, for whatever reason. The dispute can be, must be and ultimately will be solved by negotiation and discussion in the properly assembled and constituted conciliation and arbitration processes. Indeed, it is very often settled by negotiation in the work place between the employer and the employee group. There is no doubt that the strike will be solved. But there is no obligation on the Australian taxpayer. We must always remember that where we have rights we have obligations. There is no obligation on the Australian taxpayer to provide some sort of succour-beyond that for those in extreme hardship-for people who cease to work and who strike in order to achieve their objective, whatever it might be .

Considerable reference has been made to special benefits as if in fact they do not exist. If indeed a spouse and the children concerned are not in a position to carry on with whatever liquid funds they have and if they are in exceptional circumstances of hardship this legislation provides a measure to combat and to meet that need. I believe it would be appropriate, as there has been considerable concern about what is a special benefit and what constitutes it, to indicate from the speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on an earlier occasion exactly what constitutes a special benefit. The Minister said:

I will outline to the Senate the position with respect to the grant of that special benefit. Administrative guidelines have been prepared covering the test of extreme hardship which is the test required by the legislation and which is a precondition to the grant of special benefit under the amendment. These guidelines indicate that extreme hardship may be accepted if the current income and available liquid assets of a couple, for example, money in the bank and cash , are less than the equivalent of two weeks unemployment benefit at the single rate plus, where appropriate, additional benefit for children, after unavoidable fortnightly financial commitments other than general living costs have been deducted from the income and available liquid assets. In such cases special benefit will be paid at a rate sufficient to bring the total income of the couple up to the level of unemployment benefit at the single rate plus any additional benefit for children. Where an applicant is inelligible for special benefit because income and available liquid assets are sufficient to cover unavoidable financial commitments and the relevant rate of unemployment benefit, the position will be reviewed each fortnight.

By way of example, let me take a family with two children and outline a number of situations in which special benefit would not be payable and a number in which it would be payable. If a family had no liquid resources and unavoidable financial commitments, it would get the special benefits at the single unemployed rate with the addition for the two children. In other words, the family's position would be the same as if it were in receipt of unemployment benefits. It would get an amount of $89.70. If a family had liquid resources of, say, $50 a week but unavoidable financial commitments in excess of that amount, it would get $89.70. If it had liquid resources equal to its unavoidable financial commitments, it would get $89.70. If it had liquid resources $50 a week in excess of its unavoidable financial commitments, it would get $39.70. If it had liquid resources in excess of the amount of its unavoidable financial commitments, the single unemployment rate and the amount for children, it would get nothing.
I have given this definition of special benefit because it has been a matter of considerable discussion tonight. I think it appropriate that it be clearly outlined.

I want to return briefly to the Bill. The community in which we live is in every sense an interdependent community. The action of any group, large or small , has a much quicker and greater effect on a far greater range of Australians than may well have been the situation some years ago. As a community we must recognise, as I said earlier, that all the rights which we profess, which we talk about and which we defend carry with them obligations. It certainly is not the obligation of the Australian taxpayer to provide the funds to support an Australian who is on strike. It is the obligation and duty of this Government, and of any government, to make sure that the circumstances prevail in which industrial relations may survive and grow more peaceful. It is the obligation of this Government, and any government, to provide the proper machinery for discussion and for the solution of industrial problems.

Indeed, in this country of ours the conciliation and arbitration system, as it has been amended from time to time over the past 70-odd years, provides a basic mechanism whereby disputes are capable of being solved. I said before that this debate is not about the right to strike; it is about a responsibility of the Australian taxpayers. I do not believe, and the Government does not believe, that the Australian taxpayer has the duty or the obligation to support men or women who choose to strike. It is their responsibility; they have the right so to do. But they have an obligation in that circumstance basically to look after themselves. That is what we believe, with the proviso that where there is extraordinary or quite discernable hardship special benefits can and will be provided.

I do not propose to discuss this matter further tonight. The pros and cons of the argument, most of which are somewhat similar, have been canvassed for some considerable time. I close my remarks by again saying that in my view it is not the obligation of the taxpayer to support industrial unrest in the form of strikes-indeed, industrial unrest in any form. That is not to say that there is not a reason for striking, and in many cases perhaps it is a justifiable one. But the obligation for the maintenance of and for looking after the striker remains with the striker and his community.

speech.speaker: Coleman Sen R.N.

talk.start.para: —For the benefit of those who might happen to be listening at this late hour the Senate is debating the Social Services Amendment Bill for the third time. The Bill has been changed on a number of occasions but really there is no basic change to its structure. I was interested to hear Senator Scott say that this Bill does not deal with the right of people to strike. He then proceeded to give us a 10-minute dissertation on whether the consequences of that strike action were covered by this Bill. I think it would be true to say that the hypocrisy of the Government has to be seen to be believed. A matter of a few days ago we listened to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in an impassioned plea in his speech on the state of the nation, calling for 'an increasingly compassionate society'. He said: 'We seek an increasingly compassionate society'. Yet within a matter of hours of that plea from the man at the top-perhaps there were a few people in the community who really thought that he was genuine in making that statement-we found before us again this extraordinary Bill which lacks any for of compassion at all. But here we have the Prime Minister saying: 'We collectively the Government-seek an increasingly compassionate society'.

speech.para: We have here a Bill which is specifically designed to divide people, to put Australian against Australian and to attack people, particularly those who happen to choose to be members of trade unions. I contend that the people who would suffer most if this repressive piece of legislation were permitted to go through this chamber-it will not be-would be those who are not in any position to help themselves. It is particularly designed to impose on children the so- called 'sins' of their parents, be they male or female. This legislation is designed to impose a penalty on those children because their parent or parents have decided, whether or not knowingly, to participate in industrial action. The fact that those parents may not be directly involved makes this piece of legislation even more reprehensible. In my opinion it is just another exercise in the Government's continuing endeavours to bash trade unions. We on this side of the chamber are not prepared to sit back and see innocent members of those trade union families suffer because of a lack of compassion on the part of this Government. An increase in compassion was the very thing that the Prime Minister himself called for.

Senator Martin spoke a little earlier of the companies' role. I think that is a particularly interesting area and that she covered it in a particularly interesting way. She spoke of the Blackwater strike. Senator Grimes has now responded to her comments on that matter, but I think it is worth repeating that it was the Government's coalition partner which, as you would be well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, was encouraging those strikers to stay out until their demands had been met. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry if I cause you some embarrassment but you must remember the actions of your party at that time. The Blackwater strike has been raised here on many occasions during this debate. I think it is important also to note that businesses also are gettin a little tired of trade union bashing. This Government and the Government of Western Australia will not recognise that there are certain basic rights to which every Australian is entitled. They are suddenly finding themselves confronting a very large industry in Western Australia which is the subject of an article on the front page of today's West Australian, which, for those who have not read it, is headlined: 'No ticket-no job, says major builder'. The article relates the situation of a major construction firm which has put up signs at its Perth industrial works pointing out that if either members of its organisation or those people who sub-contract to it are not members of a union they will be denied the right to work.

talk.start.para: —Quite right, too.

—Definitely. As my colleague from South Australia, Senator McLaren, said that is quite right too. I think the attitude of Multiplex Constructions Pty Ltd in Western Australia-I might as well name the firm because everbody can read the front page of the West Australian-demonstrates that businesses are no longer prepared to sit back and be ruined by the attitude of various governments, be they Federal or State. This piece of legislation is designed to go to that same extreme.
—Even Charlie Court would recognise that.

—Even Sir Charles Court, when he was Premier of Western Australia, did recognise that. As Senator Grimes said earlier, it would have been much easier if this legislation had been introduced as coming within the area of industrial relations. Then we could have had a proper debate about industrial relations. Not only is it unfortunate but I think it is also inopportune of the Government to bring in the legislation as falling within social services. The Bill is designed, as I have already said, to impose a penalty on those people who are least in a position to help themselves. It has been introduced in an endeavour to preclude the spouses of persons involved in industrial action from receiving unemployment benefits. I ask: Who does the Government think the real victims will be? The cause may be in one place but the effect will be felt in a variety of places. We can have the situation which existed in the Ford dispute in Melbourne where people were on strike and others in Brisbane were stood down because no component parts were available. The Minister in charge of this Bill, Senator Chaney, refused those people in Brisbane unemployment benefits even though they had not voluntarily given up their jobs. Even though they were not even involved in the industrial action, those people were not able to claim unemployment benefits.

speech.para: Senator Grimes has already pointed out that it is members of the single income families, particularly those families with children, who will suffer most. There is a large number of these family units in Australia. There is an especially large number of these family units in places like the north of Western Australia where in a multitude of company towns accommodation may be provided, if it is available, for the workers and their families. As a general rule, accommodation is not available in or near those towns for family support systems, so that those people who are engaged in industrial action are isolated.

I know the Minister's second reading speech mentioned the insulation of some people under these circumstances but the people I am talking about are those who are isolated and who, if they are affected by the provisions of this Bill, will not have the family support systems to fall back on that perhaps would be enjoyed by people in a similar situation in a metropolitan area or in perhaps a larger country town that was not considered to be a company town. If honourable senators had ever visited or worked in a company town, they would know of the situation which is perhaps unique in that none of these towns has an office of the Commonwealth Employment Service or of the Department of Social Security where it would be anticipated that the spouse of a person involved in industrial action would be able either to apply for a position or to apply for social security benefits. They do not have that facility available to them. It is generally miles away.

talk.start.para: —How does the Bill change that?

—This Bill does not change that; it simply precludes those people from being able to get a benefit, if it is available, at an earlier time because of the delay required to get those applications to the various departments. Senator Martin made a very interesting statement. She said that the legislation is designed to prevent people obtaining unemployment benefits because they do not need them. I would like Senator Martin, or perhaps the Minister in charge of the Bill, to tell me exactly what is meant by the phrase ' because they do not need them'. Are they expecting that those people would all have money put aside of which they could readily avail themselves in the event that a union somewhere else decided to take industrial action and they were as a consequence stood down? Are they saying that perhaps these people will have a spouse who is working and therefore will not be entitled to unemployment benefits? Are they saying that the children of those family units are not entitled to food, shelter and clothing? Are they suggesting that if the spouse of a person who happens to be working as a labourer, perhaps in an under- educated type of position, is also an under-educated person without employment she and her family must suffer unless they claim hardship benefits?

speech.para: We have already heard of the situation with regard to hardship benefits. I put it to the Government that there is something just a little degrading about having to go to a government authority and admit that one is suffering hardship and is entitled to a benefit. The Government has introduced such requirements on a number of occasions. It has now made it possible for people who are disadvantaged to get medical benefits, as long as they declare that they are disadvantaged. The Government has taken away the very dignity, the very pride, of people by having them placed in a situation where they have to declare their poverty. That is exactly what this Bill provides for. If they declare that they are suffering hardship, they will get a hardship benefit. That is tremendous. If one has not been in that position, one does not know what that does to the little bit of pride a person has left. It is obvious that this Government does not give a damn about pride, dignity or anything else.

I turn very briefly to the situation in regard to work tests. Some extraordinary situations have developed because of failures to pass the work test. I wonder whether the Government has deliberately confused the officers who apply this test to people who are looking for jobs. I wonder whether it has set out the deliberations in such a confusing way that people working in the Department are automatically confused or whether it is a deliberate plot. We have seen how people have failed the work test because they have refused to travel up to 30 kilometres a day and spend dollars they can ill afford. Because they will not take a position in those circumstances they are deemed to have failed the work test.

As Senator Colston said, it is unfortunate that we live in a society where people do not know that they have access at least to Labor members of Parliament . I know that many people in the community recognise that they do not have access to Liberal and National Country Party members of Parliament. Unfortunately, we still live in a community where there is a large number of people who would never dream of going to a member of Parliament, possibly because they would see him or her as part of the bureaucratic wall that would take away, once again, some of their remaining pride and dignity if they had to confess that they had refused to take a job which would disadvantage their families further, and, therefore, they have been deemed to have failed the work test and do not meet the criteria for unemployment benefit.

I spoke a little while ago about the situation in company towns. One of the facts I failed to mention was that it is almost impossible for both partners to obtain employment in a company town. If they both work they work for the company so that they are both involved in any industrial action. I think we have covered most of the clauses of the Bill that pertain to the rights of people. We have heard Senator Martin and Senator Scott say that people have to accept responsibility. I think that honourable senators on this side of the chamber recognise that people accept their responsiblities when they accept their rights to particular things, such as Australian citizenship and employment. They accept their responsibilities to the people who provide them with the opportunity for employment.

But ever since this Government has been in office it has taken action against people who want to be involved in their associations. It was interesting that a previous speaker on the Government side said that he recognised the right of people for form an association and to become members of an association. One has to presume that in that instance he was not referring to employer associations but to trade unions. Of course people have a right to belong to trade unions. Under the provisons of all trade unions, under the provisons of basic human decency, every worker has one inalienable right, and that is the right to strike . This Government is intent on taking that right away from workers. In an endeavour to force them to recognise that it will hold the reins it is prepared to penalise the innocent parties to a partnership which may exist purely and simply to provide those people with a decent standard of living.

People are getting tired of this type of legislation. They are certainly getting tired of the union bashing tactics of this Government. As I have already demonstrated by referring to the actions of Multiplex in Western Australia, businesses are also getting tired of this union bashing. The Opposition will continue to oppose any legislation, whether it be industrial relations or social security legislation, which serves to take away the rights of people to a decent standard of living.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I think it most inappropriate for this matter to be considered on this most auspicious day. Many people in the chamber will understand that this is St Patrick's Day. I would have thought that we would have had a more pleasant subject to debate than this most contentious issue.
—I think it is very Irish.
—It is Irish all right. I think it is almost tantamount to an Irish joke to bring this piece of legislation back to the Senate for the third time.
—It is 17 March.

—Yes, it is 17 March. I would have thought it was most inappropriate to bring it in for the third time as it were on this particular day. But what does the Government really want? It is not really interested in this legislation. No representations have been made to it by employers or unions about this matter. Let the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) stand up now and tell us what unions and what employers have made representations to the Government to amend the Social Services Act in this manner. Absolutely no union and no employer in Australia has suggested this action to the Government.
—Not even Mr Polites.

—Indeed, Mr Polites, the Executive Director of the Confederation of Australian Industry would not have made this suggestion because he would understand that the Social Services Act is no vehicle with which to implement industrial relations policy.

speech.para: What does this amending legislation seek to do? It seeks to deny the single unemployment benefit to spouses of trade unionists involved in strike action and to spouses of unemployed persons denied benefits because they have failed the work test as a result of alleged unemployment or dismissal for alleged misconduct. In addition it seeks to deny special benefit provisions to spouses of persons who would have been eligible to receive those benefits if they had failed any of the conditions I have just mentioned. It is draconian legislation which is not supported in any shape or form by anybody I know from my experience who has a great deal of knowledge of the industrial relations arena. What we therefore have to ask ourselves as a Senate is this: Why does the Government persist with these amendments in the face of total silence from persons experienced in the industrial relations arena? I can only come to the conclusion that the Government is doing so to lay the foundations for a double dissolution. The Government will fail if it seeks to suggest, quite wrongly, to the people of Australia that the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and I are attempting to obstruct in the Senate some policy measure of the Government to improve industrial relations. I will line up, and I know that a number of my colleagues here will line up, a whole host of people at the next election from both the employer side and the union side to say that the Government's clumsy attempt to involve industrial relations in social security measures is quite contrary to orderly industrial progress.

talk.start.para: —What was the Chifley Government attitude?

—The Minister asks what the Chifley Government attitude was. As the Minister would well know, during the time of the Chifley Government the basic wage was based on a family wage concept-a man, wife and two children. This is where the Government is wrong and this is why the Bill ought to be sent to a select committee so that it can be studied.
—That is irrelevant.

—It is not irrelevant. The basic wage, at that particular time , in other words the wage paid to the worker, was based on a man, a wife and two children. From memory, ever since 1967 that concept has been out the door. The Minister is trying to relate his comments to a situation in the Chifley era when the basic wage was based on a man, wife and two children. In other words, the basic wage had a family concept, and now it does not. It behoves the Parliament to be very careful indeed about withdrawing rights from the family, from the spouse of the striker, rights which, most importantly by decision of the 1967 national wage case are the responsibility of this national Parliament. Let us not refer again to what the Chifley Government did because the circumstances between the wage concept at that time and the wage concept at this time have no relevance whatsoever.
—The Minister is not even listening.

—I think the Minister probably agrees with me. I assume that the Minister has been directed by Cabinet to do what he is doing. He is doing a pretty good job with it, but his heart is not in it. I am quite sure of that.
—He has an essentially kind nature.

—Yes, he has an essentially kind nature. He is quite perceptive when it comes to matters of this nature. Let us deal objectively with the matters in hand. I had always considered that the Minister for Social Security had an empathy for the one-income family. Does he know that this Bill is an attack on the one-income family?
—Nonsense.

—It is an attack on the one-income family. It seeks to deny unemployment benefit to the spouse of the striker only in the one-income family situation; that is all. Where there are two incomes there is no effect whatsoever. This measure is an attack on the very people that the Minister himself, through the length and breadth of this country, has attempted to defend ; that is, the one-income family. This measure will attack the one-income family and nobody else. That is why I believe the heart of the Minister is not in this proposition and that is why I believe that the Minister would be glad to see the Senate reject this piece of legislation.
—Which it will.
—Yes, it will, Senator Haines. There is no doubt about that.
—The Minister will cross the floor.

—I do not think he will go that far. Let us take up the matter which Senator Grimes mentioned earlier this afternoon, that is, the question of involvement. That is a very important question indeed. If this legislation goes through the Parliament, we could see a situation where a spouse of a worker who has voted against a strike or, indeed, who has no vote at all as to whether the strike takes place, will be denied a right that she and her children have under existing legislation. Let us take as a very practical example Victoria. I remind the Senate that Victoria is a State of significant political consideration at the present moment. Geelong is a city which has a stable population and a stable work force. Let us look at the Ford plant at Geelong which makes the Ford engines and the blocks for the engines. They are then assembled into the motor vehicles at the Broadmeadows plant.

speech.para: Members of the Senate, who are familiar with industrial relations in Victoria, know that over a period of years there have been a number of strikes at the Broadmeadows plant. Those strikes have of course affected the operations of the Geelong plant. Let us imagine that another strike develops at the Broadmeadows plant. That creates a log-jam and Ford lays off workers at the Geelong plant. The workers at Geelong do not have a say in whether the Broadmeadows workers go out on strike and yet the Government intends to penalise those people in a decentralised area because of the action taken at Broadmeadows. Is that fair? Is that equitable? Of course it is not. Let the Minister examine what happened in 1974 or thereabouts when Broadmeadows went out on strike for quite a long period . There was a great deal of agitation at Geelong, so much so that one of the officials of the union concerned was almost chased out of town. Despite the attitude that might be taken by those workers in Geelong, the Government proposes to penalise not them but their wives and children. There is no element whatsoever of social justice in that proposition. I ask the Government to reconsider its attitude on this matter. I ask it to examine what it seeks to achieve out of this proposition.

I take as another example a matter which was discussed in another place. I refer to an accident that occurred on a job site in Victoria where one worker fell from a considerable height and injured himself. The workers immediately went on strike because of unsafe working conditions. As I understand it, one week later, after an investigation had been made into that accident and a recommendation had been made-I understand almost an instruction was made to the employer to remedy the unsafe practice, but that had not occurred-another worker experienced a similar accident. The workers of course went on strike until that situation was remedied. If that situation had been extended for over a week the Government would have denied to the wives of those workers, who after all were only protecting their livelihood, the entitlement that they should receive under this legislation. That is the proposition. Is that just? Is that fair? Is that reasonable? Is that going to do anything for industrial relations in Australia? I will be proposing that this whole piece of legislation be referred to a select committee or a standing committee for futther consideration before it is debated .
Debate interrupted.

debate.sub1.title: 'New Legislation of the Australian Parliaments'-Yarrabah Aboriginal Reserve- Printing Industry in the Australian Capital Territory

proctext.para: 'New Legislation of the Australian Parliaments'-Yarrabah Aboriginal Reserve- Printing Industry in the Australian Capital Territory

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

interject.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Coates Sen J.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I speak on the adjournment motion to bring your attention and that of Mr Speaker to the publication called New Legislation of the Australian Parliaments-that is what the publication says on the front cover. On its inside cover it calls itself 'New Legislation of the Australian Parliament'. At the foot of every page it calls itself 'New Legislation of the Australia Parliaments'. To start with, it is not a very well put together publication. It is one that began, I think, in 1973. It is now up to issue No. 24.

speech.para: The publication provides a reprint of ministerial second reading speeches on Bills introduced into this Parliament. I do not believe it started off in this way, but it appears to me that these reprints now are generally, in almost all cases, direct facsimiles of Hansard. I wonder, Mr President, whether you would investigate this practice to see whether this is a correct use of Hansard. I presume that copyright would apply to Hansard as printed as distinct from the words which make up speeches, which, I guess it is fair, can be reproduced in any form. I wonder whether permission was sought for this use of Hansard. If so, who gave the permission and why? It seems to me that it is not right for a private publication to make a financial gain from the typesetting performed by the Commonwealth Government Printer. This publication makes it clear that it is an independent non-government publication. It does not actually have the name of a publisher written anywhere on it that I can find although it gives its address as P.O. Box 158 Pymble, 2073, New South Wales. It contains advertising as well as some other editorial matter that appears to be linked to that advertising; that is, certain advertisers get an extra plug in the publication. Overwhelmingly the publication consists of reprints of Ministers' second reading speeches.

I think it is probably a waste for most people to subscribe to the publication because it would be a lot cheaper for them to subscribe to Hansard. People do not get much more from this publication than what Hansard provides. So, it is a fairly useless publication. It is a commercial publication. I think in its misuse of Hansard it deserves investigation. I suppose that some people would say: 'Well, it is not much different from people photocopying a couple of pages of Hansard and distributing them for the information of their constituents'. I think the big difference that is involved is that it is a commercial publication which is sold, which contains advertising and which misuses Hansard by publishing pages precisely as typeset by the Government Printer. I suggest that you, Mr President, and Mr Speaker might wish to investigate this matter. Perhaps the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) should do so as well. It might be appropriate if I tabled this copy of issue No. 24 of New Legislation of the Australian Parliaments. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I have taken notice of what Senator Coates has said tonight. I shall look into the matters raised and, in due course, report back to the Senate on them.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I should like to draw the Senate's attention to the plight of certain parts of the printing industry in the Australian Capital Territory. There are about 45 small businesses, many of them family businesses, which have been particularly affected by the cutback in government spending which occurred on 12 February. About 600 people are employed by these firms. It has always been an industry in Canberra which has relied heavily on government contracts for its work. As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in April 1981, when the work of the Government Printer was seriously cut back, these printing firms have had work from the Commonwealth which has amounted to about 70 per cent of their total business. Many of them, as a result, have bought new equipment and entered into new financial commitments, leasing and other arrangements, to meet the demand that was then placed upon them.

speech.para: As a result of the freeze on 12 February, the impact on these small firms has been quite devastating. There has been significant loss of finance already. Many of them have employees who may have to be retrenched, and many of them are running into difficulties in meeting their financial commitments. Some of them no doubt will even face bankruptcy. I am told that about 300 people are likely to lose their jobs in the quite near future.

The other matter of concern, of course, is that, having run down the activites of the Government Printer and relied on these firms, if the Commonwealth gets around to printing on the same basis as it has done in recent times, the service may no longer be available in the national capital, and the Commonwealth may then find itself delayed in getting its orders filled. That would be a great pity both for the efficiency of government business and, of course, for the firms to which I have referred. If then the Commonwealth had to go interstate to get printing done, it would be a great deal more costly.

It is difficult for any man in business to plan his affairs when he is subject to overnight cuts of this nature. It is certainly something that has a serious effect on the economy of this community, even if only in a small section of it. There are other areas in which these cuts have had an effect, but it is the effects on our small printing industry that I refer to tonight. It needs its work at a steady and constant rate to sustain the industry, and it involves a group which has suffered as a result. I wish tonight merely to draw the Senate's attention to the impact on this group in the community.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talker.name: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
talker.role: Minister for National Development and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I have taken note of Senator Reid's comments. I shall ensure that the relevant Ministers put them under study and contact her on the matter.

speech.speaker: Bonner Sen N.T.

talk.start.para: -Late this afternoon I had a visit from some people from the north of Queensland. They brought to my attention a matter that is rather important in the light of the fact that the Government of Queensland is looking at the position concerning the reserve lands in my State of Queensland. I made a speech here last Thursday evening about the reserve lands in Queensland and what the Queensland Government was doing in relation to the return to the Aboriginal people in my State of those reserve lands.
