I want to bring to the Senate's attention a matter that gives a great deal of concern to the people of an Aboriginal settlement in north Queensland, namely Yarrabah, which is a settlement very close to the city of Cairns. I think that it is rather indicative that, whilst the Queensland Government is talking about handing over these Aboriginal reserve lands to Aboriginal people in a very short space of time, these two young people came to me with a matter of grave concern to the Aboriginal people and the traditional owners of the land that has been for a number of years set aside as an Aboriginal reserve in the area of Yarrabah just outside Cairns.

speech.para: The matter that was brought to my attention, I think, is and should be of very great concern to this Parliament. I am sorry that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, is not in the chamber tonight. Because of a number of events, I did not have the opportunity of bringing this matter to his attention in the last few hours. These young people who came to speak to me are concerned about a place which is part of the reserve land of the Yarrabah community, namely, Kings Beach. On the part of the reserve land of the Yarrabah community which takes in Kings Beach there is a sacred site which is very important to the Aboriginal people, the traditional owners of the area. A sacred water hole and a sacred cave with Aboriginal paintings in it have great significance for the traditional owners of that area, namely, the Gon-gangie people.

We have learned recently that a number of survey pegs have been established in the area of Kings Beach. In addition, past the settlement of Yarrabah and across a rather extensive flat, water reticulation has been laid heading towards Kings Beach. Also, the electricity commission responsible for the Cairns area has laid electricity cables across this area, finishing up nowhere but heading towards this beach which is part and parcel of the Yarrabah community and which has been set aside by governments for a number of years. The things that these two young people told me about the water reticulation pipes and the electricity cables that have been laid across this area heading towards this beach surely must make anyone suspicious about what is happening in the area. The young people have not been able to get any kind of information from the State Government, from the people responsible for the provision of electricity or from the people responsible for the provision of water reticulation. They are concerned about what is to happen to this area which for a number of years has been set aside by the Queensland Government as an Aboriginal settlement.

I come back to the speech I made in this place last Thursday in relation to the Queensland Government's attitude towards setting aside Aboriginal reserves and the kinds of things that the Queensland Government seems to want to do as far as Aboriginal reserves in Queensland are concerned. During that speech, I think I pointed out a number of things that could be done by the Queensland Government and the Queensland Minister for Lands and Forestry. If I am correct in all those things that I stated in my speech last Thursday, we must now look at what is going to happen to the Aboriginal community at the Yarrabah settlement, which is on the coast south of Cairns in north Queensland.

If the information that I have is correct, I think that the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs should look closely at what is projected for that community. If our suspicions are correct, the Queensland Government is going to set aside part of that reserve for some other purpose. At this moment I do not know what the purpose is. It does seem strange that a government would go to the expense of setting up water reticulation for an isolated area. If the Queensland Government, through whatever department it may be, is going to provide electricity to that isolated area, I want to know what it has in mind for that part of Kings Beach on the coast south of Cairns, which is part of an Aboriginal community. What does it have in mind for the future development of that area? Without any consultation with and without the knowledge of the Aboriginal community of Yarrabah and without any consultation with the local Aboriginal council, the Queensland Government is taking this action. What is its purpose? If that is what is going to happen to Aboriginal communities in Queensland, what is the Federal Government going to do to preserve and protect the Aboriginal communities on those reserve lands in Queensland? What protection are we going to give to the Aboriginal people?

We have heard and we have been told by the Federal Government and by the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that negotiations have been going on behind the scenes by the Department and by the Minister to bring about justice for the Aboriginal people of Queensland. I, for one, have listened to him and given him a great deal of support. I will continue to give that support. But I want to know what we are going to do about this matter. We have before us information that the Queensland Government is working in a clandestine way in this Aboriginal community. It should, by all accounts, be one of the communities which, under proposals put forward by the Queensland Government, should have complete autonomous use of its land. But we find that in a very underhand way, through whatever departments or other instrumentality, survey pegs have been placed on that beach and the installation of water reticulation is heading towards it. Electrical facilities are being projected towards that beach which is part of an Aboriginal community. What is going to be set up on that beach, on a part of an Aboriginal community that has been set aside and which will come under the cloak of the proposal by the Queensland Government? That is the question that needs to be answered.

I have indicated in my speech what the Queensland Government is intending to do which is not in the interests of the Aboriginal people on the reserve land in Queensland. We now have evidence-it may seem flimsy-because Aboriginal people have brought to my attention the types of things that are happening in that area . What else can we expect in the 19 Aboriginal communities in my State of Queensland? If this happens in one community and we in the Federal Parliament sit still and allow these kinds of things to happen, what hope is there for the remaining Aboriginal communities? We should exercise the right and the power that we have vested in this Commonwealth Parliament under the terms of the 1967 referendum. What hope is there for the Aboriginal community of this nation unless the Commonwealth Government has the intestinal fortitude, the courage, to take the steps that need to be taken to ensure that justice is not only done but seen to be done for the indigenous people of this country?

I am sorry that I have taken up the time of the Senate tonight but I believe it is important that I do. I know that I will attract criticism from many quarters because it may appear that I continually fight the battle of the indigenous people of this country. Mr President, I ask you and all Australians to recognise that out of 64 senators and all the honourable members who sit in the other place there is only one Aboriginal voice. If that voice is not raised in support of the indigenous people of this country there will not be any voice raised. I raise my voice this evening and support the people of that small community of Yarrabar because they are concerned, and I share their concern, that something is going on that needs to be investigated. I hope that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) will investigate what is happening to that community and ensure that the Aboriginal people have justice.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talker.name: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
talker.role: Minister for National Development and Energy)

talk.start.para: —by leave-I will make sure that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has his attention drawn to the comments made by Senator Bonner and that he puts them under study.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

(2) In what ways will general decisions made in the Review of Commonwealth Functions to: (a) reduce by two per cent the number of Commonwealth employees in areas subject to staff ceilings over two years; (b) reduce by three per cent the departmental expenditure on furniture, repairs, property, leases and administration; and any other general decisions in the Review, affect the Minister's Department.

question.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

question.para: (1) What overpressures are generated by fuel air explosives (FAEs) under typical operational conditions and how do these compare with the overpressures generated by tactical nuclear weapons and ordinary high explosive bombs?
(2) What are the effects of FAEs on:
(a) human beings;
(b) armoured vehicles;
(c) anti-tank minefields;
(d) anti-personnel minefields;
(e) surface structures;
(f) bunker and field fortifications;
(g) antennae for electronic equipment; and
(h) warships?
(3) Can FAEs be used for tree 'blow down'?
(4) Have Australian authorities been given access to results of United States Navy Tests on the effectiveness of FAEs against warships?
(5) What is the effective radius of a typical FAE?
(6) What are the tactical uses of FAEs?

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Some estimates of the peak overpressures obtainable from FAE, conventional explosives and nuclear devices are given in the following table:
Peak Overpressure in kilopascals
Nuclear Distance
FAE HE (small) (metres)
(30 kg) (130 kg) (literature data)
0 2,000 above 100,000 Indeterminately high 7 700-900 700 Indeterminately high 35 20 18 More than 10,000
Footnotes:-
(a) 2,000 kilopascals is equivalent to 300 pounds per square inch or 20 atmospheres.

(b) Peak overpressure is only a partial measure of the potential for causing blast damage. The duration of the blast wave and geometric factors such as the position, orientation and strength of blast reflecting surfaces must be also considered.

(c) The predominant damage mechanism for FAE is blast; HE weapons cause damage through blast and fragmentation; nuclear weapons cause damage by means of blast, thermal radiation and nuclear radiation effects. The blast output of even a small nuclear warhead is equivalent to that produced by 1,000 to 10,000 tonnes of HE.

(2) No trials have been conducted in Australia to assess the effects of FAEs against any of the targets listed. Some classified data is available through the Technical Co-operation Program that involves the US, UK, Canada, NZ and Australia.
(3) and (4) See (2) above.
(5) The radius of the FAE cloud from a 30 kg charge is about seven metres; its effectiveness would depend on target type.
(6) There is no Australian tactical doctrine for use of FAEs.

question.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

question.para: (1) Did the then Defence Standards Laboratories develop fuel air explosive (FAE ) technology in 1973-74 and test canister FAEs at Puckapunyal in 1973 and 1974?
(2) Was the then Minister for Defence informed of the project; if not, why not; and if so, to what extent was the Minister informed?
(3) Has the Royal Australian Air Force or the Royal Australian Navy been equipped with:
(a) FAE weapons of overseas manufacture, and/or
(b) FAE weapons of Australian manufacture?
(4) Are there any plans to equip either Service with FAE weapons.

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No. The technology already existed overseas. In 1973-74 DSL undertook some research and a few experimental trials to ensure that our defence scientists understood the technology sufficiently well to be able to provide soundly based advice to the Services on this topic.

(2) At the time that this research was conducted, DSL was part of the then Australian Defence Scientific Service (ADSS) which was then responsible to the Minister for Supply. A report on the FAE work was made to the then Minister for Supply in October 1973.
(3) (a) and (b) No.

question.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

question.para: (1) From what source was Australian fuel air explosive (FAE) technology acquired, and when.
(2) Was the source the United States of America; if so, does this imply American policy on the proliferation of this technology has changed since President Carter banned its sale to Israel in 1977.
(3) Was the source another country; if so, was this technology transferred to Australia with the knowledge and consent of the United States, and when.
(4) Was the technology independently developed in Australia; if so, would the government agree to its sale to Israel, if the Israeli Government made such a request.
(5) Has the Israeli Government made such a request; if so, what was the response of the Australian Government.

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) From scientific reports that have been published during the 1960s and 1970s relating to the principles of FAEs; these are freely available to all countries; and

Through the Technical Co-operation Program involving the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Canada, New Zealand and Australia; results of United States and United Kingdom research were obtained. Details of military hardware are outside the terms of reference of the program.
(2) See (1) above. The technology exchange above occurred prior to 1977.
(3) See (1) Above.

(4) No. DSL research in 1973 and 1974 depended on prior knowledge of the principles of FAEs as reported by overseas defence scientists. The aim of DSL research was to independently verify existing overseas information.

talk.start.para: —On 17 February 1982 (Hansard, page 77) Senator Evans asked the following question:

answer.para: Has the Minister seen the reports of the decision yesterday by the Queensland Supreme Court in the Pine Vale case, drastically reducing the investigative powers of the National Companies and Securities Commission and making a nonsense of the practical operation of the takeover code? Does the Minister agree, following the extraordinarily narrow and technical interpretations of Mr Justice Sheahan in this case and the equally narrow and unadventurous decision of Mr Justice Needham in the Industrial Equity Ltd case last December, that there is a need for urgent amendment of the legislation and an urgent meeting of the Ministerial Council to set that in train? In particular, will the Commonwealth propose the insertion in the relevant legislation, not only of specific remedial provisions but also a provision along the lines of section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, requiring the courts to have regard to the manifest purpose of the legislation? Finally, has this course of events concentrated at all the mind of the Government any more clearly on the utility and virtue of unilateral Commonwealth legislation in this field, rather than having to rely on the cumbersome and disjointed procedures of the present co- operative scheme?

Is the Minister, amply briefed as he is, aware that the main section in issue is not in the new takeovers code or any other legislation but the NCSC parent Act, section 36, which relates to the general investigative powers of the Commission? Does the Government have any idea in its collective head as to what it proposes to do about the text of section 36 in the light of its emasculation by the Queensland Supreme Court yesterday?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I am aware of the judicial decisions to which the honourable senator refers.

The National Companies and Securities Commission has held discussions with officers from the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs about a number of proposals for the urgent amendment of the scheme legislation in the light both of recent court decisions and experience gained in the administration of the legislation.

The National Companies and Securities Commission has now submitted a paper to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities recommending a number of amendments to the co-operative scheme legislation having regard, among other things, to the judicial decisions referred to by the honourable senator.
These amendments are a matter for the Ministerial Council and are now before it.

talk.start.para: — On 17 February 1982 (Hansard page 75) Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

answer.para: (1) Is it an inflexible rule of the Government never to protest about apparent human rights violations in overseas countries?
(2) Are any exceptions ever made?
(3) Does it depend on the severity of the case or the volume of noise from people in Australia or, indeed, on the colour of the eyes of the individual senator making the request?
(4) If not, why the different approach taken by the Government on such cases?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

No, the Government does not of course apply an inflexible rule. Australia has made representations concerning human rights to a variety of countries across the broad political and geographical spectrum and will continue to do so should the circumstances justify such approaches. Recent subjects for such representations include the situation of Baha'is in Iran and human rights violations under martial law in Poland. Australia's commitment to upholding and promoting human rights, both in multilateral fora and through direct bilateral representations to countries involved, is unshakable.

As there is no such inflexible 'rule', the question of exceptions does not arise. I should mention, however, that some factors influencing the Government' s decision to make representations include the nature and gravity of alleged violations involved, the status of evidence introduced to establish the validity of the allegations and an assessment of the likely effectiveness of the representations (and the related concern about possible counterproductive results). Domestic concern expressed in Australia about the human rights violations in individual countries is naturally also a factor which the Government takes into account in making decisions whether or not to make representations. In short, Australia's approach to human rights is neither arbitrary nor capricious.

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —On 24 February 1982 (Hansard, page 394) Senator Lewis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

answer.para: Will formal courses of instruction for members of the defence forces be affected by these constraints in any way? What type of training, if any, is to be curtailed? Can the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that surveillance duties performed by the defence forces will not be curtailed
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Formal courses of instruction in Service schools and colleges will continue, albeit at a reduced level consistent with maintaining minimum training levels and expenditure restraint. Training and exercising operational capabilities will continue although there will be some curtailment of single service, joint and combined exercises. Surveillance duties performed by the defence forces will not be curtailed.
